bug.short_desc: OslcClient::lookupQueryCapability logic assumes that an oslc:QueryCapability element contains an oslc:usage or oslc:resourceType sub-element

long_desc.thetext:
The OslcClient::lookupQueryCapability logic assumes that an oslc:QueryCapability element contains an oslc:usage or oslc:resourceType sub-element. However, these elements are optional sub-elements of the (occurs = zero-or-many) oslc:QueryCapability element. As a result, it will never be able to find the following query capability within the catalog:
<oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://www.acme.com/xmlns/test#"/> <oslc:queryCapability> <oslc:QueryCapability> <oslc:queryBase rdf:resource="https://localhost:9443/test/query"/> <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal">Test Query Capability</dcterms:title> </oslc:QueryCapability> </oslc:queryCapability>
This is fixed by the changes for Bug 394337

bug.short_desc: ConcurrentModificationException loading LDP sample webapp

long_desc.thetext:
The problem happens after
JenaLDPService.getJenaRootContainer().getGraphStore().getGraph("urn:x-arq:UnionGraph");
followed by
ResIterator subjects = m.listSubjects(); // error here!
Something in the recent factoring has introduced the problem. Here is the full stack trace:
java.util.ConcurrentModificationException: Iterator: started at 18, now 21 at com.hp.hpl.jena.tdb.sys.DatasetControlMRSW.policyError(DatasetControlMRSW.java:157) at com.hp.hpl.jena.tdb.sys.DatasetControlMRSW.access$000(DatasetControlMRSW.java:32) at com.hp.hpl.jena.tdb.sys.DatasetControlMRSW$IteratorCheckNotConcurrent.checkCourrentModification(DatasetControlMRSW.java:110) at com.hp.hpl.jena.tdb.sys.DatasetControlMRSW$IteratorCheckNotConcurrent.hasNext(DatasetControlMRSW.java:118) at org.apache.jena.atlas.iterator.Iter$4.hasNext(Iter.java:293) at com.hp.hpl.jena.tdb.store.GraphTDBBase$ProjectQuadsToTriples.hasNext(GraphTDBBase.java:194) at org.apache.jena.atlas.iterator.Iter$3.hasNext(Iter.java:179) at com.hp.hpl.jena.util.iterator.WrappedIterator.hasNext(WrappedIterator.java:90) at com.hp.hpl.jena.util.iterator.Map1Iterator.hasNext(Map1Iterator.java:48) at com.hp.hpl.jena.util.iterator.NiceIterator.asSet(NiceIterator.java:206) at com.hp.hpl.jena.util.iterator.NiceIterator.toSet(NiceIterator.java:197) at com.hp.hpl.jena.graph.GraphUtil.listSubjects(GraphUtil.java:75) at com.hp.hpl.jena.rdf.model.impl.ModelCom.listSubjectsFor(ModelCom.java:1244) at com.hp.hpl.jena.rdf.model.impl.ModelCom.listSubjects(ModelCom.java:1250) at org.eclipse.lyo.ldp.sample.VisualizationService.getVisualization(VisualizationService.java:63)

There seems to be a problem making concurrent requests to
/ldp/resources
and
/ldp/resources/visualization
I suspect we're not properly locking the model/dataset, and it's getting updated somewhere as we're processing the 'visualization' request.

bug.short_desc: JenaModelHelper OslcResourceShape annotation warning on all Link objects

long_desc.thetext:
I am getting the following log messages:
Mr 21, 2017 11:49:48 PM org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper handleLocalResource WARNUNG: Could not serialize Link because it does not have an OslcResourceShape annotation (class: VersionResource, method: getIsVersionOf)
Resources were generated with Lyo modelling tools, simply point to an AbstractResource. And links are serialised into a Model.

Link has no Shape annotations, so the warning is valid.
Question is why/when does the generator set the attribute type of a resource property to Link.
Need to rethink the types of attributes generated.
Bug in JenaModelHelper, specifically its private method

Bug in JenaModelHelper, specifically its private method handleLocalResource.
handleLocalResource marshalls the value of each of the instance's properties.
I tested for properties of type (a) Link (b) HashSet<Link>, but problem below should occur for any other Java object than Link.
1. For a Link property that is null, handleLocalResource does not handle it correctly, and result in a warning guessing (wrongly) that the property has no annotations. (null cannot be expected to have OSLC annotations)
Suggestion: handleLocalResource has a series of ifelse statements to check for String, Date, URI, etc. Add a check for a "null" value, and simply do nothing for such values.
2. For a HashSet<Link> property, if one of the HashSet members is null, handleLocalResource fails with an exception, since it tries to do getClass on the null, on the first line of its code. This exception is handled very silently.
Suggestion: Maybe handleLocalResource should explictly check for nulls, and simply ignore them.
3. For a HashSet<Link> property, if one of the set members is "new Link()", handleLocalResource will (similar to 1 above) result in a warning guessing (wrongly) that the property has no annotations. Note: handleLocalResource is being called for each member of the HashSet.
Suggestion: Solving 1. above, will solve this problem.

bug.short_desc: There should be a Bugzilla component for OSLC4J itself

long_desc.thetext: Since this is one of the primary deliverables of the eclipse/Lyo project, and since defects might be raised against that deliverable vs. its internal components, we should have a Bugzilla component for OSLC4J itself.

Correct me if I am wrong, but Bugzilla is just a sample project. As we keep them under lyo.docs repo, I would expect issues to be filed under 'docs' component.
I think it might be wise to rethink repository organisation, but in general I am in favour of having one component per repository (i.e. we should stick to the same criteria when assigning project to a repository/component). The only exception I think should be general (cross-cutting) concerns, like release/build engineering, documentation (i.e. updating a wiki pages makes a valid bug if the page is outdated).

There is a component that defines OSLC4J itself: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build. This eclipse project has a parent POM file that includes modules for all the components of OSLC4J - *except* org.eclipse.lyo.client.java. I'm guessing that's left out to separate the client and server parts, and/or to allow the release build to process the client side separately so the javadocs for the client are separated from the rest. But I don't know for sure.
Note however that none of the modules defined in the parent POM declare that POM to be their parent. So there is no common dependency management across OSLC4J - each module (possibly redundantly) declares its own dependencies and versions.
But there is no eclipse.org Bugzilla component for capturing defects on OSLC4J as a whole. See: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/describecomponents.cgi?product=Lyo
This bug is suggesting an OSLC4J Bugzilla component be added to the Lyo project. This is unrelated to the org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla sample OSLC4J client and server samples.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #2) > There is a component that defines OSLC4J itself: > org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build. This eclipse project has a parent POM file > that includes modules for all the components of OSLC4J - *except* > org.eclipse.lyo.client.java. I'm guessing that's left out to separate the > client and server parts, and/or to allow the release build to process the > client side separately so the javadocs for the client are separated from the > rest. But I don't know for sure. > > Note however that none of the modules defined in the parent POM declare that > POM to be their parent. So there is no common dependency management across > OSLC4J - each module (possibly redundantly) declares its own dependencies > and versions. > > But there is no eclipse.org Bugzilla component for capturing defects on > OSLC4J as a whole. See: > https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/describecomponents.cgi?product=Lyo > > This bug is suggesting an OSLC4J Bugzilla component be added to the Lyo > project. This is unrelated to the org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla sample > OSLC4J client and server samples.
I am terribly sorry, I initially thought you meant a 'bugzilla' component. Please disregard my first comment.
In regard to OSLC4J, I see no reason for it to exist. I don't see any difference between lyo.core and oslc4j. So whenever I see mention of oslc4j, I think "Lyo core".
The build project is just an aggregator project, not a parent [1,2]. I would be in favour of making a parent project, though. Before we do that, we need to figure out what constitutes a parent project. These ones don't:
* oslc4j.adaptormodel defines Adaptor Interface and Toolchain metamodels, as well as a few Domain Specifications. It belongs in lyo.tools. * oslc4j.codegenerator generates an OSLC adaptor (server) when given an Adaptor Interface of Toolchain model. It belongs in lyo.tools. * oslc4j.registry seems to logically fit into lyo.server repository. * oslc4j.stockquote is a sample application, should be under docs (I would suggest to rename it to lyo.samples actually) * oslc4j.wink also fits in lyo.server.
On the other hand, I would move test projects from the lyo.testsuite to lyo.core and lyo.server.
I think our discussion on parent-child and project-repository relationship should be split into a separate cleanup issue discussion. Regarding the subject matter, I am in favour of eliminating OSLC4J (it also adds confusion when we talk to people not familiar with Lyo) in favour of Lyo Core and using Core component for all questions regarding it in the meanwhile.
[1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1725579/maven-making-child-projects-that-can-be-independent-of-their-parent [2]: http://books.sonatype.com/mvnref-book/reference/pom-relationships-sect-pom-best-practice.html#pom-relationships-sect-multi-vs-inherit

I'm just figuring all this out, so this could be incorrect or incomplete.
There are 4 related things:
1. The OSLC4J SDK distribution - used by developers creating OSLC client and server apps.
2. org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build - the parent module (eclipse maven project) that defines and builds the components of OSLC4J (except for the java client)
3. the org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core eclipse project - contributes one of the 8 jar files for OSLC4J, oslc4j-core-2.1.1.jar
4. org.eclipse.lyo.core git repository, contains all of the eclipse project that contribute to OSLC4J, except the clients which are in the org.eclipse.lyo.client repository. Also contains a significant number of other eclipse projects that use, test, provide samples for, etc. OSLC4J.
This introduces the possibility of some repository, and project refactoring to have less confusing naming, better identity of deliverables, and better separation of concerns. This is something that we should consider, but perhaps not for OSLC4J 2.x. The cost/benefit of such a refactoring for 2.x may be difficult to justify.

bug.short_desc: Support the generation of Domain Specifications

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, we only support the generation of one or more adaptors (ie, resources, and their services).
We also support the modelling of a set of domain specifications, (for example the oslc domains defined in the org.eclipse.lyo.tools.domainmodels project, in the org.eclipse.lyo.tools repository).
From such domain models, it would be desired to generate the corresponding java classes, without necessarliy associating these classes with any particular adaptor.
Such classes can be generated to form reusable libraries of OSLC resource classes, which in turn can be included in adaptor projects (generated or otherwise).

bug.short_desc: Address a few issues with release 2.1.1

long_desc.thetext:
There are three simple issues with release 2.1.1 that we want to address with service release 2.1.2:
1. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=499848: java client cant be built. Since 2.1.1 was released, the net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4:jar:20090617 dependency was removed from Maven Central and can no longer be retrieved. We need to update this dependency.
2. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=511492: Add TLSv1.2 support back into the java client.
3. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=503995: The provenance of this release is not clear. The version used was 3.0.0-SNAPSHOT, and that includes about 80 commits, most of which had to do the with code generator. That may have had no impact on OSLC4J, but we aren't entirely sure.
In any case, a 2.1.1 release should be built off 2.1.0, and be labeled as 2.1.1 in the pom.xml files so the JAR file names correspond to the release. To address this, we are going to add the missing tag for release 2.1.0, create a branch off 2.1.0 and cherry-pick the changes included in 2.1.1.
We are planning on including the other changes on the 3.0.0-SNAPSHOT master branch, merging in the change from 2.1.2 as part of a future 2.2.0 release that addresses the dependency updates and code generator changes.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/92036

Jad, Jim,
I would appreciate code review on:
* Change 92035 - set artifactId to 2.1.2-SNAPSHOT * Change 92034 - cherry-pick all changes from 2.1.1 * Change 92036 - cherry-pick commits for 2.1.2
because Stephanie from EMO (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=512813#c3) is urging us to file for release review PMC approval and Jim is busy with his work commitments. I think we might need a code freeze before that (so I need to merge those patches in), but I will clarify.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/92189
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/92036 was merged to [2.1.2-service]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=91fa6e8307738b6b219befea2b05d203765e7708
Jim, I think all fixes have been merged into 2.1.2-service and deployed to maven under 2.1.2-SNASHOT. Please close this issue if it works for you.
Closing

bug.short_desc: Consider deprecating the Eclipse version of the Lyo workshop in favor of the open-services.net version

long_desc.thetext:
The Lyo tutorial on Eclipse at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/OSLCWorkshop may be obsolete. For example, it references a version of a Bugzilla server that is no longer available, and the latest version of that server does not work with lab 3 of the tutorial due to security issues.
The tutorial at http://open-services.net/resources/tutorials/integrating-products-with-oslc/ appears to be more recent and robust. However, the .pdf document associated with that tutorial is out-of-sync with the HTML version.

bug.short_desc: 2 different conflicting configurations of code generator

long_desc.thetext:
Since it is possible to generate code per adaptor (bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=521222), there are now two different ways of generating code, which result in code being produced in 2 different locations.
1. Generation of whole toolchain based on the tools.codegenerator.ui plugin. This generates code assuming the base path of the eclipse project where the model resides.
2. Generation of each adaptor based on a context meny item defined in the Sirius model. In this geenration, the user is prompted for the base path.
Make sure these 2 generation approaches are consistent in behaviour for the user.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/111804

/org.eclipse.lyo.tools.codegenerator.ui/plugin.xml
Has two problems:
1) org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus is deprecated 2) objectContribution (should be menuContribution) needs a child Visibility

(In reply to Yash Khatri from comment #2) > /org.eclipse.lyo.tools.codegenerator.ui/plugin.xml > > Has two problems: > > 1) org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus is deprecated > 2) objectContribution (should be menuContribution) needs a child Visibility
Are these problems due to teh new change, or have they existed before? because the plugin has been working before.

bug.short_desc: Headline OSLC link on landing page has a typo to http://olsc.co which does not exist

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: NA
The main lyo project page found @ http://www.eclipse.org/lyo contains a headline sentence with a hyperlink. This sentence "The Eclipse Lyo project focuses on providing an SDK to help the Eclipse community to adopt OSLC (Open Services for Lifecycle Collaboration) specifications and ..." has a bad hyperlink for the OSLC acronym. It refers to the url: http://olsc.co rather than http://oslc.co
New users will be confused and the link is in a very prominent spot.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to eclipse lyo landing page @ www.eclipse.org/lyo 2. Click on OSLC link found within the headline sentence at the top. 3. Validate that the browser fails to take the user to the the OSLC spec website.
Made the quick fix
Verified the link is good now

bug.short_desc: Group Javadoc packages

long_desc.thetext:
As OSLC4J (Lyo Core) contains many packages, it would be good to group the ones that contain public classes/interfaces together and separate them from all kinds of impl/internal packages.
I got the inspiration from https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-java/pull/738

Let's see where we are after we address the refactoring of the repos to separate OSLC4J SDK from the samples, test suite, and OSLC domain reference implementations, and determining if some of eclipse/Lyo could be migrated to GitHub to open things up a bit and simplify the process to promote contribution.
Refactoring existing SDK code could lead to unanticipated compatibility issues.

bug.short_desc: Generated java classes corresponding to an OSLC Service keep changing names

long_desc.thetext:
The java classes corresponding to an OSLC Service are generated with a different file name with different generations. The ordering of the resource names (which are part of the file name) appear to change randomly.
If a service manages many resources, the file name is too long to be pratical.

Could the services class name be generated from the name of the domain the service supports? That may not always work because a service provider could have multiple services for the same domain. In this case, the generator could add a number at the end 1, 2, ...

An adaptor can have a number of ServiceProvider (types) which can overlap in the domains they cover. Plus, I have a feeling domain names can be quite long, which makes for cumbersome class names.
I looked at the class names for the SPs and they will also cause some conflicts so I am trying to rethink both.
I will test a bit and propose some naming to see what you think. There will also be conflicts but if you Jim have a complixated enough scenario and think the proposal is good enough it should be good enough to many.
(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #1) > Could the services class name be generated from the name of the domain the > service supports? That may not always work because a service provider could > have multiple services for the same domain. In this case, the generator > could add a number at the end 1, 2, ...

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J downloads zip files do not unzip properly when downloaded with Firefox

long_desc.thetext:
On MacOS, downloading org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip with Firefox 45.6.0, and double-clicking to expand with Archive Utility results in the creation of org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip.cpgz instead of actually unzipping the file. Attempting to unzip this file creates a copy of org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip. This could be a sign of a corrupt download. See: http://osxdaily.com/2013/02/13/open-zip-cpgz-file/
org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip downloads and expands fine using Safari.
We should look to see if there's something about how the zip file is created that makes it not unzip properly when downloaded with Firefox.

I can confirm that Archive Utility does this. I use Keka & Unarchiver so I never noticed anything similar.
Seems like it's a JAR renamed into ZIP.
$ file org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.no_dependencies-2.1.1.zip: Java archive data (JAR)
We should make ZIP files ourselves (even though a quick look at zipinfo output seems OK).
Cleaning up "3.0.0" bugs.

bug.short_desc: Incorrect null checks after Model.getResource()

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
The test suite contains several null tests like this,
catalog = (Resource) rdfModel.getResource(currentUrl); assertNotNull("Failed to read Catalog resource at URI: "+currentUrl, catalog);
According to the Jena Javadoc, Model.getResource() never returns null, however.
http://jena.sourceforge.net/javadoc/com/hp/hpl/jena/rdf/model/Model.html#getResource%28java.lang.String%29
"Return a Resource instance with the given URI in this model. This method behaves identically to createResource(String) and exists as legacy: createResource is now capable of, and allowed to, reuse existing objects."
If the resource isn't in the model, it gets created, so the tests are not really checking if the resource is there.
Reproducible: Always

Created attachment 206369 Use Model.contains() instead of Model.getResource() to see if a subject is in the model
I updated the tests to match the original intent (checking if the resources are really in the model), and removed the null checks for objects that will never be null.

Resolved by the following commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=c1445c5a6612f738eb13901fdfab0e62ae0c4040
Closing...

bug.short_desc: Lyo JazzFormAuthClient login processing not correct in cases where oauth tokens required

long_desc.thetext: For certain providers (example: IBM Rational Design Manager), the processing performed by JazzFormAuthClient.formLogin() is incomplete. Trying to GET a resource after an apparently successful login results in a 401 while other Jazz applications using the same login processing will succeed. From debugging the login process it seems there are additional OAuth-related cookies in the response to the initial GET on /auth/authrequired which must be used to trigger some additional redirects to pick up OAuth tokens.

There is an oddity with IBM Rational Design Manager where the first get of a protected resource after form login must have an Accept "*/* header or else a 401 is not returned. Using this bug, I made some improvements to the OslcClient and JazzFormAuthClient to:
- OslcClient: do a better job of following redirects on all resource operations - JazzFormAuthClient: removed some extraneous HTTP flows from formLogin()
There will be an additional check-in/commit for bug 405503 to add a working DM sample to illustrate how to successfully use IBM Rational DM using the client. The sample will do a dummy GET on the catalog using the Accept = "*/*" and this successfully triggers the required redirects to collect the required OAuth-related cookies.

Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=fd8a06ccb6888fc760c149f2edcaca9598102e9b

bug.short_desc: ChangeRequest class shouldn't be final

long_desc.thetext: The class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.changemanagement.ChangeRequest is currently final. That means an OSLC provider that wants to handle custom properties (i.e. tool specific properties, not part of the Core and CM specifications) cannot reuse this class as is. Typically the bugzilla sample has its own (non final) copy. Or is this package deprecated and not to be used anymore?

Sebastien, we have this in a lot of places unfortunately. I'm not sure why so many OSLC4J classes were originally declared final as it seems natural to extend them to add properties specific to your tool.
I wouldn't say the package is deprecated. We've have some discussion on the mailing list about moving some of the resource classes from the lyo.rio to lyo.core where it makes sense. We have some copies in the lyo.client repository as well.
For now, I'll remove the final qualifier.

bug.short_desc: RQM Automation Adapter continues to GET the requests which have already been cancelled on RQM server

long_desc.thetext: Create a lyo script type in RQM Enter parameters as 'Path' and 'Log Format' Create a script and a testcase in RQM. Run the testcase. The Eclipse Lyo adapter will error out (filed another bug on that) Now go to RQM -> Execution -> Adapter Console Select the Lyo adapter and press Cancel Tasks Go back to eclipse and restart the adapter Note that the adapter errors out and shows same message that Log Format whereas there are no Execution tasks currently pending on the adapter. Expected : The adapter should poll only for the new requests and not unassigned.
@pmcmahan Let me know if this should go to someone else

@vaibhav the sample lyo adapter initializes itself by getting its server side representation from RQM. This server side representation contains a property "rqm_auto:assignedWorkUrl" that provides the sample adapter with the URL it should use to poll for assigned work. The sample adapter trusts the RQM server that the list of AutomationRequests returned by GETing this URLS is an accurate representation of the assigned work, and doesn't second guess by inspecting the AutomationRequests further.
It looks like RQM creates the URL for the rqm_auto:assignedWorkUrl property by constructing a query URL that looks like this:
-------------- https://rqm.ibm.com:9443/jazz/oslc_auto_test/contexts/_stJVgGfqEd24KMoDcFLfcQ/resources/com.ibm.rqm.execution.ExecutionRequest?oslc.where=rqm_auto%3AexecutesOnAdapter%3D%3Chttps%3A%2F%2Frqm.ibm.com%3A9443%2Fjazz%2Foslc_auto_test%2Fcontexts%2F_stJVgGfqEd24KMoDcFLfcQ%2Fresources%2Fcom.ibm.rqm.execution.ToolAdapter%2F_Q5lbYrZ8EeKG-92BKy917g%3E+and+rqm_auto%3Ataken%3Dfalse --------------
If you decode the query you can see that the "where" clause look like:
-------------- rqm_auto:executesOnAdapter=<the adapter url> and rqm_auto:taken=false --------------
RQM should probably also append the following to the query URL:
-------------- and oslc_auto:state!=<http://open-services.net/ns/auto#canceled> --------------
as well as any other states that should not be included the query result.
Alternatively, the sample adapter could check the state of the automation request in the query results, but that would really defeat the purpose of using the rqm_auto:assignedWorkUrl property, and could also lead to performance problems since the response that is returned to the adapter polling would continue to grow when tasks are canceled.

bug.short_desc: There is no option in OSLC4J RDF XML serialization to suppress the RDF type for a extended property

long_desc.thetext:
I implemented a resource class that supports a series of extended properties and I see that OSLC4J does the job of mapping Java types to corresponding RDF types.
However, there is no way to inform OSLC4J not to add the RDF datatype in the serialized RDF XML for a specific property. In the application I am writing, I did not want the RDF datatype to be explicit for String properties. For my use case, preventing 'rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#string"' from being serialized would make the XML file less verbose.
Thanks

We specify the datatype for extended properties so that if you write to RDF and then read it back in you get the same properties. Otherwise, you'd lose the types when reading things back in. All literals would be read in as a string.
Having said that, data types shouldn't be necessary for strings. I'm not sure if there is a lot of value specifying an RDF data type for string literals, and it could cause problems if we ever need to support language tags, which can't be used with data types.
My proposal is to continue using the data types for dates, numbers, etc., but just use a plain literal for strings in extended properties.

Ok, that makes sense
By the way, for annotated properties, the RDF type is not serialized for some Java types, as I reported on bug 411535. Is your idea of serializing all RDF types but string applicable to annotated properties as well ?
Thanks

Yes. How does that sound?
I have changes ready for both, but haven't committed yet. Thanks for your input, Givanildo.

Yes, having RDF type serialization working the same way for both annotated and extended properties addresses my needs.
Thanks
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=b02207c8513b3bdea64a756cda7a651818b51b88

bug.short_desc: Code Generator: Missing generated constants

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 248224 The model that is used for the generator.
When generating from a model some constants for some generated resources (e.g "TYPE_ANALYSISFUNCTION") are not generated.

In addition to the constants, the corresponding java classes of these resources are also not generated. The reason is that the resources are not identified as "relevant" by the generator.
When does this problem occur? Consider the following case: Your model defines a service (creation factory, query capability, etc.) for a resource TypeA, that has a property with a Range on a resource TypeB. Also, consider that TypeB is defined to extend the resource of TypeC, and/or that TypeB has a property with a Range on a resource TypeD.
All code of relevance to resources of TypeA & TypeB will be generated. The generator however currently - wrongly - misses that TypeC and TypeD need to be generated.
I "simply" need to recursively identify resources of relevance.
How to remedy until bug is fixed: Define in the model some extra services that are to manages resources of TypeC & TypeD.
please assign to me.

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #1)
Assigned. Thanks, Jad.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/38750/
This bug was filed against 2.1.0 (not 3.0.0) and the fix was likely released in 2.1.2.

bug.short_desc: Refactor JenaModelHelper

long_desc.thetext: * Stop using static methods * Assign meaningful class name (I would vote for OslcResourceMarshaller) * Stop using the system properties and instead pass the configuration class OslcResourceMarshallerConfig or (even better, whenever possible) pass all the necessary parameters explicitly. * Provide a OslcResourceMarshaller factory method that will invoke an OslcResourceMarshallerBuilder with the properties fetched from the system. This will allow using this approach in the old webapps and do whatever I want (as you have guessed, not system properties) in new non-container applications (say, Google Guice). * Enforce Single Responsibility Principle to reduce code duplication and allow to retrieve an intermediate result for processing. * Deprecate relevant JenaModelHelper methods

Perhaps we need a use case describing what outcome we expect to come from this effort. If its the ability to marshall/unmarshall any OSLC domain instance, standard or custom, into a single java Resource class/object that uses reflection to provide the data, then great. Let's think about some use cases where such a feature would be useful and compare and contract with the more specific generative approach where a specific java class is created for each domain class.

bug.short_desc: Need more flexibility for user editing in resource HTML and creator JSP

long_desc.thetext:
Lyo Designer {resource}smallpreview.jsp puts the whole body inside protected code so the developer is free to change the generated content and the changes will be preserved. To regenerate, the developer simply deletes the file and let it get regenerated.
The same thing would be very useful for {resource}.jsp and {resource}creator.jsp. Since the {resource}.jsp is used by default for the large preview, developers might need to modify, format or reorganize the content on that page. And there are often read-only fields, or fields the user can't provide data for (e.g., links) in {resource}creator.jsp that should be removed.
Probably putting the whole generated file inside a user code protected block is fine. There probably little point providing specific customization points, and then protecting the whole body. It is that body that would need to reference other things like page imports, session attributes, etc.

bug.short_desc: Release Lyo 2.2.0

long_desc.thetext:
Last release of Lyo happened in Mar'14 [1]. Many issues were resolved since [2]. Recently one of the dependencies of Lyo Client was removed from Maven Central which caused projects that depend on it to fail to build (fixed in bug 499848). There also was a bug 502182 that had been fixed in the master branch but never released properly. At the same time, no support for OSLC 3 has been committed to the lyo.core (only to lyo.ldp). Hence, it is safe to release current changes as 2.2 instead.
This is an issue to coordinate the release process and the subtasks that will arise in the process.
TODO:
* add a 2.2.0 milestone in bugzilla * generate an IP Log for 2.2.0 (https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#ip-iplog) * ensure dependency version convergence * update build configurations and test the release artefacts * hold a Wednesday Release Review (https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#release-review) * deploy the release artefacts to Eclipse Maven * update the website * send a newsletter to the mailing lists

Jad, I looked through the list of CQs [1] and none mention "acceleo" or "sirius". I think you need to do some CQs and we should do it quickly to put the 2.2.0 label on the plugin you have just finalised recently.

In re: CQs for bundles
-------------- The IP Team must review a third-party library if:
* the Java/OSGi manifest for one of the project bundles makes a direct reference to a third-party library (either the library bundle or a package from the library); * project code includes an import statement for a package from a third-party library; * project code uses reflection or other means to reference a librarys APIs and implementation; * project code uses OSGi Services to make a reference to a specific implementation of a service; or * project code invokes a "command line" tool.
This list is not intended to be exhaustive. --------------
This means we need to do CQs (the first rule and the one before the last apply)!

Okay, I have now filed a CQ for the reuse:

I will also write about many bundles we don't limit the version of.

bug.short_desc: Lyo does not build on OSX due to Javadoc errors in Maven

long_desc.thetext:
Maven fails to install (build) on Mac OSX using the oslc4j.build pom.xml because it is unable to locate javadoc.exe. This appears to be because of the way Mac sets up JAVA_HOME. Even after setting up the proper version of the JRE in Eclipse Properties > Java > Installed > JREs, Maven does not use the correct JRE for Javadoc.exe (although setting the installed JRE works on OSX for Maven for all other purposes).
Adding the following tag to each pom.xml file called by oslc4j.build will fix this problem in the individual builds:
<properties> <javadocExecutable>/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_79.jdk/Contents/Home/bin/javadoc</javadocExecutable>
</properties>
This is only a local solution because developers will use different JREs and different locations. This tag will need to be added and parameterized, and setup instructions provided on how to set the parameter so the correct javadoc.exe is referenced.

The fix uses the Maven Profiles XML tag to identify when it's running on a Mac. If so, it uses the parameter mac_local_javadoc_exe to set the location of the local javadoc.exe. The absolute location on the Mac is entered into the parameter in the Build OSLC4J launch. So when that launch is used on a Mac, the various pom.xml files will use mac_local_javadoc_exe to fill in the location of the javadoc.exe file.
A better solution would be to use a local settings file to store the value of mac_local_javadoc.exe, instead of editing the launch config. I've been unable to find a good way to do this however. The solution outlined above should have no impact for non-Mac users.
See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=472557 for changes to the OSLC4J setup as a result of committing this fix.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/51893
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/51893 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=b2531a6747666a3f322f8c899ad4fc8699ce8c67

I think the right way to do it is via JAVA_HOME (and launchd.conf for GUI programs) http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13961615/unable-to-find-javadoc-command-maven#comment40683719_13961656. I have followed those instructions and javadoc executable is located automagically.
I will check if merged fix is conflicting with the preferred approach.

There's another issue with generating JavaDoc. Java 1.8 runs with DocLint enabled by default. This needs to be turned of in order generate the JavaDocs for the existing OSLC4J code. Another option would be to update the javadoc comments.
To turn off DocLint, add this configuration to the maven-javadoc-plugin:
<configuration> <additionalparam>-Xdoclint:none</additionalparam> </configuration>
Regarding JAVA_HOME on MacOS, the best solution is to use EnvPane (https://github.com/hschmidt/EnvPane) which re-enables ~/.MacOSX/environment.plist support which Apple removed. This ensures JAVA_HOME is seen by Applications run from launcher. With this `javadoc -veraion` works from a shell command and should be found by Maven.

Thank you for mentioning EnvPane, Jim. The doclint was already disabled by this bugfix, I'll check later what errors fail the build if the option is removed.
I also checked if pom file needs to be changed, but setting JAVA_HOME fixes the build even though pom file has this profile activated for Mac:
<profile> <id>mac</id> <activation> <os> <family>mac</family> </os> </activation> <properties> <javadocExecutable>${mac_local_javadoc_exe}</javadocExecutable> </properties> </profile>
So I think the info we have discovered can be put into wiki and no changes are necessary.
Thank you for help.
Andrew

bug.short_desc: Need more flexible ways of setting the server's base URI

long_desc.thetext:
The generated server base URI is currently specified using a context-param in the web.xml deployment descriptor file. For example:
<context-param> <description>Base URI for the adaptor.</description> <param-name>com.ibm.oslc.adaptor.iotp.servlet.baseurl</param-name> <param-value>https://rlia4iot.raleigh.ibm.com:9443</param-value> </context-param>
The Lyo Designer generated ServletListener class use the ServletContext getInitParameter() method to read this property, and if it is not specified, uses http://localhost:8080 as the default.
This works fine, but in practice results in the need to edit the deployment descriptor file in order to deploy the generated OSLC toolchain component on different servers.
Perhaps an additional option would be to provide the baseuri as a System property that can be set from the command line that could be used in addition to the context-param in web.xml and the default. The System property should have the highest priority (used first), followed by the context-param, followed by the default.

1. Jim! If you can provide me with the desired code for the contextInitialized() method, I can match it in the generator.
2. I suggest we also change DEFAULT_BASE to be non-final. At the start of the contextInitialized() method, I can have a //TODO comment to inform programmer that they can override this value of DEFAULT_BASE.
3. This would also be an opportunity to deal with the https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=519474 (Rename default servlet name from "JAX-RS Servlet" to "oslc-servlet")

From my email reply:
I use context.xml in Tomcat to override the value in the descriptor. No web.xml changes inside the WAR file are needed. Every AS allows that.
Quick search turns this https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/SSAW57_8.5.5/com.ibm.websphere.nd.doc/ae/rweb_custom_props.html
So I see no reason to go back to Java system props, I prefer to use the Java EE container configuration facilities.

bug.short_desc: Incorrect text in the wiki http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildClient#Running_the_Lyo_Client_samples_in_Eclipse

long_desc.thetext:
In the OSLC client tutorial (http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildClient#Running_the_Lyo_Client_samples_in_Eclipse) the following is stated:
"To run the sample you first need to follow the instructions to build and run the Change Management Reference Implementation. Then you can create a launch configuration in eclipse to run GenericCMSample as a java application, passing in values for the command line arguments as shown below:"
But - if following the steps in Change Management Reference Implementation you will get a server running with address: http://localhost:8080/rio-cm, and the screenshot instructs you to point at server with address: http://localhost:8080/OSLC4jRegistry/catalog/1 - which will cause an error.
Suggested solution: The screenshot in the wiki should be updated to show correct parameter (i.e. http://localhost:8080/rio-cm). Note: Doing this will cause need for some code sample updates - filed as separate bugs.

There are new change management samples in Lyo which is a source of confusion. We will likely retire the older samples (rio-cm) which you stumbled on using those instructions.
I've updated the web page referenced in your bug description to point to the correct CM sample (aka OSLC4JChangeManagement). The directions are here:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildingOSLC4J
Sorry for the confusion.
*** Bug 393069 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: OSLC-Generator: Parameters passed to BugzillaChangeRequestService.addChangeRequest() have null values

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 241458 The BugzillaAdapter project
When trying to create a new change request by POSTing to the generated adapter, the parameters for productId and changeRequest get null values. In the Lab5 example, they get are initialized, so something is wrong with the generated adapter code.
This can be reproduced by the following steps:
1. Clone the org.eclipse.lyo.core repository 2. Import the projects: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.adaptormodel org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.generator 3. Clone the http://git.md.kth.se:8080/scm/git/se.kth.md.iee 4. Import the BugzillaAdaptor project 5. Set a breakpoint in BugzillaChangeRequestService.addChangeRequest() 6. Build and run the BugzillaAdapter 7. Browse to http://localhost:8080/BugzillaAdapter/services/catalog and login 8. Use a REST client to POST to create a new change request - see attachement. 9. Note that productId and aBugzillaChangeRequest have null values
Doing the same exercise with the Lyo_OSLC_Workshop Lab5 code show that they should have been initialized. Steps 1 + 2 are note required to reproduce this, but allows the generator to be run and thus updating the generated BugzillaAdapter project.
Attaching the BugzillaAdapter project (since it is from the "KTH" repo) and the "POST" message for creating a new bug/CR.
Created attachment 241459 How to POST to create a new bug/CR to reproduce the problem
Ping jad@kth.se
Please assign this bug to me

Did some furhter debugging and noted that in the "Lab5" code, the constructor of BugzillaChangeRequest is called before the call to BugzillaChangeRequestService#addChangeRequest, while no such call to the constructor is made in the generated adapter.

I have now submitted a patch that solves this problem (https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/24344/). Please review.
The POST function was simply not yet implemented, although the generator produced a skeleton function that returned null (The way LAB3 of the workshop did it.)
Also note that your uploaded RDF has some problems as well. I have also attached here a change to the suggested RDF that will work. If you compare to the original rdf, you will note the following:
1. <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://update"> is changed to <bugz:bugzillaChangeRequest> * It seems critical that the element has the same namspace and name as the annotations @OslcNamespace & @OslcName of the BugzillaChangeRequest class. If not, the parameter aBugzillaChangeRequest of the function createBugzillaChangeRequest will be null. That's how I guess OSLC4J does its magic to be able to match the rdf element to a function parameter. * If you test with the rdf from "oslc-lyo-workshop/Lab5/src/test/resources/newBugzillaChangeRequest.xml", you will need to change from <oslc_cm:ChangeRequest> to <bugz:bugzillaChangeRequest>, because the generated code actually defines a different namespace for BugzillaChangeRequest!
2. <oslc_cm:priority> is changed to <bugz:priority> * It is also important that each resource propertys name and namespace matches the defined annotations on that property (in the resource class)! In your case, priority is defined under bugz and not oslc_cm. If you use oslc_cm, the value of the priority property will be null.
Created attachment 241523 changes to the uploaded rdf that should work with the new patch
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/24344/

bug.short_desc: Property "extends" should have a visual representation

long_desc.thetext: When creating Domain Specification in the Specification Diagram, the "extends" property should have a graphical representation in order to indicate the inheritance between two resources.

I just managed to push the change to the master branch! https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.tools.git/commit/?id=7b7941e0e906383c7a1e1dc099352f3776109195
Will share a plugin update for testing.
Created attachment 268857 illustrates the suggested changes.

Any feedback and suggestions on the following is appreciated:
The relation from a Resource to its parent resource(s) will be shown with a hollow arrow (like in a UML class diagram).
In some cases, some of these parent resources are not graphically shown in the same diagram. (Since a Domain Specs can be structured into many diagrams).
The suggestion is to include the text "extends Parent1 & ..." to the label of the resources. See attached figure on how this would look like. Note the difference between whether 1 or more parents are missing.
Is this intuitive enough? Any other suggestions?
This looks good. I'm not sure the extends parent... is needed in the label since its readily available in the properties view by just clicking on the class.

The visualization looks good. Regarding the extends non-visible-parent part, I think that having an indication of such scenario is useful. In my case, I have complex hierarchies with many "extends" relations but they do not belong to the same diagram.
What you propose as a visualization for this scenario seems ok. If you have the possibility, maybe it's even more elegant to have a simple graphical symbol decorating a resource (in order to reduce clutter) and indicating that I should check the properties view.

bug.short_desc: Lyo Automation Adapter sample is unable to handle parameter with space values

long_desc.thetext: Define a Lyo script type in RQM Define a parameter type String with spaces like "Log Format" and try running the test. The adapter errors out and cannot handle spaces. Now modify the parameter name to "LogFormat" Create another script which uses this parameter Start another instance of Lyo adapter Execute the test script and adapter is able to handle the parameter value.
@pmcmahan Let me know if this should go to someone else

@vaibhav this actually looks like a bug in RQM's implementation of the OSLC Automation spec. It is creating illegal URIs as the id for input parameters. For example if you create an input parameter with the name "input parameter 1" then the RDF/XML for the automation request looks like
<rdf:RDF ...> <oslc_auto:AutomationRequest rdf:about="..."> ... <oslc_auto:inputParameter> <oslc_auto:ParameterInstance rdf:about="urn:com.ibm.rqm.planning.VariableValue:_Vf6GQLZ8EeKG-92BKy917g:input parameter 1"> <rdf:value rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#string">asdf asdf</rdf:value> <oslc:name rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#string">input parameter 1</oslc:name> </oslc_auto:ParameterInstance> </oslc_auto:inputParameter> ... </oslc_auto:AutomationRequest> </rdf:RDF>
Note that the URI for the ParameterInstance is
rdf:about="urn:com.ibm.rqm.planning.VariableValue:_Vf6GQLZ8EeKG-92BKy917g:input parameter 1">
Which leads to a failure in the Lyo client:
Caused by: java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in opaque part at index 68: urn:com.ibm.rqm.planning.VariableValue:_Vf6GQLZ8EeKG-92BKy917g:input parameter 1 at java.net.URI$Parser.fail(URI.java:2810) at java.net.URI$Parser.checkChars(URI.java:2983) at java.net.URI$Parser.parse(URI.java:3020) at java.net.URI.<init>(URI.java:577)
So it looks like RQM should be escaping the space with %20 when it creates the URI, and probably escape any other invalid characters at the same time.

bug.short_desc: OslcClient insists on using TLS and won't use SSLv3

long_desc.thetext:
In trying to connect to a server that supports only SSL and not TLS I was unsuccessful because the OslcClient refused to communicate over SSLv3. Looking at the OslcClient source it seems that if no "secure socket protocol" is provided then it prefers "TLS" only to SSL_TLS. (The order of preference is TLS, SSL, SSL_TLS).
There is a function setConfiguredSecureSocketProtocol(string) which should allow me to choose SSL_TLS rather than TLS but the value this method sets is only consumed in the class constructor so setting it later has no effect.
Perhaps there is another way available to enable SSL in the client but I haven't found it. This prevents me connecting to a DOORS Next Generation server running in Tomcat with the default configuration.

Dominic, can you try the change here and let me know if it fixes the problem? If so I'll merge it.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/25435
It should allow you to call setConfiguredSecureSocketProtocol(), but still work with self-signed certificates. You can cherry pick the change with this command:
git fetch git://git.eclipse.org/gitroot/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client refs/changes/35/25435/1 && git cherry-pick FETCH_HEAD

Unfortunately I discarded the code that wasn't working and used a JazzRootServicesHelper instead, which seemed to work. I've gone back and tried to reproduce the problem with your fix applied and the fix appears to work for me, I can now connect to my server. thanks -Dominic

(In reply to Dominic Tulley from comment #2)
Thanks, Dominic. I've merged the change.
Marking verified per comment #2.

bug.short_desc: Resource containing xsd:decimal property in the extended properties returns Integer object instead of Decimal

long_desc.thetext:
The problem is related to a resource that contains a xsd:decimal (with the data type explicitly passed) in the map of extended properties. After parsing the resource, OSLC4J returns a java Integer object in the map of extended properties instead of a Decimal object.
Example of resource with decimal property:
<rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:rr="http://www.ibm.com/xmlns/prod/tivoli/registry" xmlns:crtv="http://open-services.net/ns/crtv#" xmlns:vm="http://open-services.net/ns/vm-monitoring/1.0/"> <crtv:ComputerSystem rdf:about="http://test.ibm.com/osl4j/computer-001"> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/ns/ism/registry#RegistrationRecord"/> <oslc:serviceProvider rdf:resource="http://localhost:9080/oslc/providers/1356025969942"/> <crtv:decimalProperty rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#decimal">2700.0</crtv:decimalProperty2> </crtv:ComputerSystem> </rdf:RDF>
I already have a fix for this problem and can make a contribution. The problem is in JenaModelHelper.java class, in the method: handleExtendedPropertyValue. When the data type is passed as decimal, the following line of code is returning an integer object: final Object literalValue = literal.getValue();
literal.getValue() is from Jena library, I'm not sure if it is possible to fix it. My sugestion is to add the following piece of code for this problem:
if (XSDDatatype.XSDdecimal.getURI().equals(literal.getDatatypeURI())) { return new BigDecimal(literal.getString()); }
Please, let me know what you think about this.
Thanks, Fabiana

I checked the Jean code. They use BigInteger only when they need to (i.e., the number has at least 64 bits). Otherwise they return an integer. See XSDBaseNumberType.cannonicalizeInteger(BigInteger).
Does this behavior cause a problem?

Hi Sam,
Yes, this is a problem for us, as we don't have the information of the data type that was provided in the original resource, we need to have the correct object to be created for the given data type. In this case, as the original resource has a xsd:decimal property, the object returned should be a BigDecimal and not an Integer.
Thanks, Fabiana
https://git.eclipse.org/r/15368

bug.short_desc: Loss of precision in floating point properties

long_desc.thetext:
When I post a resource with this property: <crtv:testFloat2rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float">-6.000000052154064E-3</crtv:testFloat2>
I get back: <crtv:testFloat2rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float">-0.0060</crtv:testFloat2>
Although this is not critical, it's still very important, as information is being lost after going through OSLC4J.
Hello. Any expectation as to when this could be fixed? Thanks.

Floats are notoriously imprecise. If precision is important, doubles are better (although not perfect).
I'm not sure what we can do in Lyo to address the problem. I don't think it's possible to go from an internal floating point representation to a text representation and back without losing precision, at least for some values, because they use a different base.
Closed due to inactivity.

bug.short_desc: a QueryCapability with no associated resourceTypes causes generation warnings, as well as code that does not compile
PUT on DirectContainer can duplicate membership triples from other graphs

long_desc.thetext:
For DirectContainers that have different member resources or use ldp:isMemberOfRelation, we don't store the membership triples in the container graph. We store in the graph of the subject resource. We add membership triples to GET responses on the container, however.
The problem is if a client does a GET and then a PUT on the DirectContainer itself. Since the membership triples are in the GET response, they are added to the container graph after the PUT. Now they're stored in two graphs.
Later container GET requests with a Prefer header might not behave as expected, and this could cause problems deleting resources.

Resolved by commit:
https://git.eclipse.org/r/28829
Also included is some refactoring that I did as I was initially debugging the problem.

bug.short_desc: The generator does not have a stable ordering of types and methods, leading to code changes upon regeneration

long_desc.thetext:
The generator does not have a stable ordering of types and methods, leading to code changes upon regeneration.
Particular cases where ordering of lists varies:
* In a Resource java class, the list of interfaces implemented by the class. * In the html representation of a resource, the list of resource properties * in the POST method within a resource service, the list of resource properties being read through the httpServletRequest.getParameterValues() method
The main reason for this problem is that a resource's properties consists of (a) the directly declared resource properties (b) the set of inherited properties from each of the extended classes (can be more than 1).
We need to list these properties in an intuitive way (simply ordering properties alphabetically may represented the resource in an intuitive fashion.)

long_desc.thetext: I have a candidate fix, so I'd like to have it assigned to me.

We will also need a way to generate a resource without RDF type. So, in the fix I add the RDF type only if @OslcName value is not an empty string (""). This allows to generate a resource with only RDF types defined by setTypes() methods, and it also allows to generate a resource without RDF type (when no types are added via setTypes method). It will also not break clients that do not specify annotation @OslcName (keeps current behavior of adding class name as default RDF type).

bug.short_desc: oslc4j: Return unabbreviated RDF/XML for application/rdf+xml media type.

long_desc.thetext:
OSLC4J needs to return the following representations:
application/rdf+xml : unabbreviated RDF XML application/xml : abbreviated RDF XML application/x-oslc-compact+xml : abbreviated RDF XML

bug.short_desc: OSLC4JUtils.getPublicURI() vs OSLC4JUtils.getServletURI() have different ending

long_desc.thetext: Public URI does not come with a slash, but a Servlet URI does.

Not having a slash is better in my opinion:
<%= OSLC4JUtils.getPublicURI() %>/delegatedUI.js reads better than <%= OSLC4JUtils.getPublicURI() %>delegatedUI.js

Certainly consistency is preferred.
Regarding URLs and terminating /'s, I'd suggest each part of a URI had something that designates that part, making it easy for humans and computers to parse and understand the role of the part. A URI that ends in /name is ambiguous. There's no way to tell if name is a resource with a default prefix or a path entry designating a logical container that might eventually be followed by something else. /name/ removes this ambiguity and makes it very clear what the URL element means.
So I think this is the preferred approach and provides motivation for Andrew's preference.
That said, this is a compatibility breaking change as existing code is likely to have already addressed this, preferably with a path builder that automatically deals with the / as needed, but if not, the code will break.

Indeed they are unintentionally different. publicUrl is: http://localhost:xxxx/some-adaptor while servletUrl is: http://localhost:xxxx/some-adaptor/services/
With Jim's motivations, it seems that we do want the ending '/' in the servletUrl.
publicUrl is more like a baseUrl. And from that perpective, it would make more sense to not end with a / (since one wants to concatenate with a relative full path starting with a '/')
Given that, adn the backward compatibility risk, maybe worth keeping as it is?

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J: StackOverflowError when trying to retrieve a xml describing a Service Provider containing extended properties with circular reference

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 230866 Stack Trace received after executing the request to retrieve the Service Provider
When trying to retrieve a Service Provider with a circular reference in it, OSLC4J behaves strangely and does not send the Xml response file properly and throws the an StackOverflowError caused by : org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.RdfXmlAbbreviatedWriter.serializeStatement(RdfXmlAbbreviatedWriter.java:469)
The full stackTrace is attached.
The following snippet was used to recreate the problem:
@POST @Path("test") @Consumes({ JaxRsApp.MEDIA_TYPE_RDF_XML, MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON }) @Produces({ JaxRsApp.MEDIA_TYPE_RDF_XML, MediaType.APPLICATION_XML, MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON }) public Response testServiceProvider(@Context UriInfo ctx, ServiceProvider serviceProviderInfo) { Response response = Response.ok().entity(serviceProviderInfo).build(); return response; }
In addition to that, The following payload corresponds to the Service Provider to be retrieved:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:oslc_cmx="http://open-services.net/ns/cm-x#" xmlns:ns1="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/process/1.0/" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:calm="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/"> <oslc:ServiceProvider rdf:about="http://test:9999/inlineResources/circleReference002.xml"> <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal">TEST PROJECT</dcterms:title> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <calm:home> <calm:Home rdf:about="http://myURL1.com"> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/HomeXXX" /> <calm:link rdf:resource="http://myURL2.com" /> </calm:Home> </calm:home> <calm:home> <calm:Home rdf:about="http://myURL2.com"> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/HomeYYY" /> <calm:link rdf:resource="http://myURL1.com" /> </calm:Home> </calm:home> <oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/cm#" /> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdf:RDF>

It looks like this has been fixed in a later version. I know Mike Fiedler had delivered some fixes for circular references previously. When I use the XML you provider, I get back this response from the abbreviated writer:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:calm="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:ns1="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/process/1.0/" xmlns:oslc_cmx="http://open-services.net/ns/cm-x#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/"> <oslc:ServiceProvider rdf:about="http://test:9999/inlineResources/circular.xml"> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/cm#"/> <calm:home> <calm:HomeYYY rdf:about="http://myURL2.com"> <calm:link> <calm:HomeXXX rdf:about="http://myURL1.com"> <calm:link rdf:resource="http://myURL2.com"/> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/Home"/> </calm:HomeXXX> </calm:link> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/xmlns/prod/jazz/calm/1.0/Home"/> </calm:HomeYYY> </calm:home> <calm:home rdf:resource="http://myURL1.com"/> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal">TEST PROJECT</dcterms:title> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdf:RDF>
I do plan to commit the JUnit test I've written for this.

bug.short_desc: Paging of results does not produce more than one page

long_desc.thetext:
Using the RQMFormSample as test driver. Scenario A with paging does not work as expected.
I have a RQM project with 100+ test result that has verdict passed.
I was expecting to see the QueryResult presented as several pages with 10 items listed in each (using 10 as page size argument to the OslcQuery::constructor), but I only get 1 page (with 10 items).
If I change the pages size argument to 100, I get 1 page with 100 results.

The trigger is that RQM does not retain the order of the query parameters as sent by the consumer and OslcQueryResult::initializeRdf() assumes it will. The fix is to get the real subject of the oslc:ResponseInfo resource and use it when looking for the nextPage.
The suggestion in comment 1 is one approach. The drawback would be if somehow multiple oslc:nextPage predicates are in the model, need to loop them looking for one that is in an oslc:ResponseInfo resource.

Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=9f9f5fc55cf2e0ee86b59e96adfa4eb8452c7c50

may need to be reopened if we plan to release more than lyo.core and lyo.client in this 2.1.2.

Another option might be to configure maven-assembly-plugin to include jar-with-dependencies.
It would be a lot to ask casual OSLC4J users to track down all the dependencies if they are not using Maven. I'm not sure we should assume that. Instead we could distribute two sets of JAR files, one with and one without dependencies. The jar-with-dependencies will be quite a bit larger of course.

bug.short_desc: Provide a way to serve abbreviated XML responses (depending on a system variable)

long_desc.thetext:
DOORS 95 is picky and we have discovered that it does not handle catalogs correctly.
DOORS team has had a look, from what they can gather the responses from the Lyo provider has a reliance on reified statements (local resources referenced via the rdf:NodeID value). For example every resource reference in the Service Provider Catalog uses one.
Talking to DOORS development this is a primary difference between Lyo catalogs and other catalogs. Although valid RDF XML the area of reified statements is a murky one as to whether it sits outside the formal OSLC specification and there is no shortage of discussion / opinion.
Jazz products champion their use but others (such as DOORS) take a more formal line.
Unfortunately DOORS client doesn't use an RDF parser, and aside from a few exceptions exceptions it doesn't play nicely with reified statements.
Sam has suggested to make a change in AbstractOslcRdfXmlProvider in OSLCJenaProvider, so it can server abbreviated responses when a system property is set.

Some OSLC consumers expect abbreviated RDF responses. Even though they should use an application/xml accept header, we can give providers the ability to always generate abbreviated RDF even if application/rdf+xml is requested (after all, abbreviated RDF is still valid RDF).
Gerrit review: https://git.eclipse.org/r/14083
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=95d0ccdf1a6583996ad26571ddd8245cf5bdfd69

bug.short_desc: "Default Layer" in DomainSpecs is not visible in existing projects.

long_desc.thetext:

For existing projects, the layer "Default Layer" is not enabled when the project is opened, which means the user only sees 1 tool to create Domains. It is not possible for user to even see how to create Resources, Properties, etc.
Maybe for some time now, we should always have these layers always enabled, until peole discover the layers. After some time, we can make them hideable.
I agree this is a problem. Maybe custom extensions should hide the layers programmatically.
We need to put together an explanation for the release newsletter.

bug.short_desc: [Bugzilla] in rootservices page: wrong rootservices URI

long_desc.thetext:
The rootservices about URI given in the rootservices page is:
http://<server name>:<port>/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/rootservices,
instead of:
http://<server name>:<port>/OSLC4JBugzilla/rootservices
The reason is that the rootservices servlet:
org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla.services.RootServicesService (http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.docs.git/tree/org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla/src/main/java/org/eclipse/lyo/oslc4j/bugzilla/services/RootServicesService.java)
is forwarding the request to the jsp:
cm/rootservices_rdfxml.jsp (http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.docs.git/tree/org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla/src/main/webapp/cm/rootservices_rdfxml.jsp)
with the Attribute "baseUri" which value is: http://<server>:<port>/OSLC4JBugzilla/services
And in the jsp, the line 28 is: <rdf:Description rdf:about="<%= baseUri + "/rootservices" %>"
What is suggest is either:
for the servlet to add another URI without the "/services" in the request attribute (BugzillaManager.getServletBase()) and to use it in the jsp for the rootservices about
or to change the value of baseUri (replace the line 46 in the servlet by: request.setAttribute("baseUri", BugzillaManager.getServletBase());)
and add "/services" after baseUri for all the other services URI

bug.short_desc: Java arrays of OSLC4J objects are not recognized by OSLC4J - JAXRS media body writer when using Java 7

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
Our code returns an array of ServiceProvider objects in a javax.rs.Response object to Wink. It get correctly serialized in both application/rdf+xml and application/json media types.
Once we switched our WAS server (8.5 Beta) to use a Java 7 SDK, the OSLC4J media body writers are no longer matching those collections.
Here is a link to the corresponding issue in Apache Wink 1.1.3 (latest) https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WINK-363
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Have a JAX-RS method that returns a ServiceProvider[] (java array) wrapped inside a javax.rs.core.Response object. 2. Set your application server container to use Java 7 3. Attempt to invoke the method, Wink will return an HTTP 500 status code because it cannot match any of the OSLC4J Array or Collection media body writers 4. Switch your application server container back to Java 6. The method invocation will work correctly.
Are you suggesting code changes are required in OSLC4J?

Updated the Lyo pre-req to Apache Wink 1.2.1 which fixes this issue. Other groups have coded around it by using Collections instead of Arrays.
Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=466ad6aa47980b3e8f5d537f159bb006539e34f3

bug.short_desc: Plan the 2.3.0 release

long_desc.thetext:
There are many ideas on what to include in Lyo next. I think we should aim for the quickest 2.2.0 release and plan the 2.3.0 release after it.
Possible improvements can be made in a few areas.
Tech debt:
* Jena 3 migration. Many new libraries rely on Jena 3 and they can't be used with Lyo that relies on Jena 2. * Wink migration. At least from 1.2.1-INCUBATION to its latest 1.4 release. We also need to consider keeping Wink alive (see its dev mailing list) or plan for Jersey/Dropwizard migration. * oauth library migration. Google abandoned their old oAuth library around 2010 and it can no longer be considered secure.
New features:
* Library for interacting with triplestores within OSLC adaptors. * New and more approachable materials for the beginners (NB: clean up lyo.{docs,server} sample code).
Deployment and general updates:
* cleanup of all projects (use of aggregator projects, proper use of dependencyManagement, new library versions, fix javadoc errors for build under JDK8 without suppressing them) * better deployment (automatic javadoc/site deployment, signing the artefacts, maven central release) * Common release cycle with Lyo Tools for Eclipse (generator and modelling tools) * Mavenise projects in lyo.tools repository using Eclipse Tycho.
Please suggest your ideas for the 2.3.0 roadmap.

Other possibilities: * Improve resource shape decoding (@Nick Crossley would have more to say on this) * SSO and TLS support (IBM JTS code and abstract it for general use) * Support 1 or 2 major use case basic flows, e.g. a higher-level API that can authenticate, find the query service for a project, retrieve the desired work item, and modify it in a single transaction. Purpose is to make it easier for people to do some common task instead of making all the individual API calls. The specific use case(s) to implement are TBD. * Build system technical debt. Improving/understanding naming conventions, reconsider how JAR files should be distributed, remove unused build routines, document build system use/capabilities, etc.

re: "Support 1 or 2 major use case basic flows", would org.eclipse.lyo.client.java satisfy these requirements? It appears to be the a higher level API that does most of the listed items.
This is part of OSLC4J, but doesn't get included in org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build. The build/release process must do it separately as it is included in the distributed jar files.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #2) > re: "Support 1 or 2 major use case basic flows", would > org.eclipse.lyo.client.java satisfy these requirements? It appears to be the > a higher level API that does most of the listed items. > > This is part of OSLC4J, but doesn't get included in > org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build. The build/release process must do it > separately as it is included in the distributed jar files.
We need to understand the supported use cases and the extent of the support. Ideally we can document these APIs better so they're more accessible. We may also want to review what would be useful in the OSLC world today and see if they should be improved, expanded, replaced, etc.

Packaging of a client-only library would be useful.
For shape handling, it would be useful to have helpers to find creation factory shapes, and then from creation shapes or instance shapes for updates: * find the mandatory properties * find allowed property values for a given property name * find allowed values with given enumeration labels, or with given owl:sameAs values using the representations described at https://jazz.net/wiki/bin/view/LinkedData/BestPractices * etc.

Some commonly used classes are missing support in Lyo today. One example is foam:Person, used for many of the dcterms properties (creator, contributor, etc.). It would be fairly low cost to add these.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4JUtils.resolveURI() returns incomplete URI

long_desc.thetext:
A request made to this URL
http://ADMINIB-ROFAE1L.br.ibm.com:9080/oslc/rr/registration/collection?oslc.select=*
produces a response where the about property of both the ResponseInfo resource and the collection (that holds the rdfs:member's) resource are missing part of the URI:
<oslc:ResponseInfo rdf:about="http://ADMINIB-ROFAE1L.br.ibm.com:9080/rr/registration/collection?oslc.select=*"> <oslc:totalCount>14</oslc:totalCount> </oslc:ResponseInfo> <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://ADMINIB-ROFAE1L.br.ibm.com:9080/rr/registration/collection"> <rdfs:member> ...
Specifically the "/oslc" component is missing in the about URIs, which are returned by OSLC4JUtils.resolveURI(). After initial investigation, we found out that the missing component can be retrieved by invoking http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/servlet/http/HttpServletRequest.html#getContextPath%28%29 on the request object passed to resolveURI().
This looks the same as Bug 397561. Francisco, do you have the latest OSLC4J?

(In reply to comment #1) > This looks the same as Bug 397561. Francisco, do you have the latest OSLC4J?
We do have the latest OSLC4J. Bug 397561 added the servletPath to the URI, but we also need the contextPath. I believe the correct sequence is: contextPath + servletPath + pathInfo
We can contribute a fix. If you agree, please assign the bug to phleal@br.ibm.com. Thanks.
Looks right. I'll assign the bug. Thanks.

Francisco, Paulo, see my comment in Gerrit.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/15097/
Configured public URI roots should include the context. Changing this behavior will break others using OSLC4J with a configured public URI root.

(In reply to comment #4)
Francisco, Paulo, does putting the context in the public URI root work for you? This is how it's intended to work.
If you don't object, I will close this bug as invalid.
(In reply to comment #5) Yes, your suggestion does solve the issue. Please go ahead and close the bug. Thanks.

(In reply to comment #6)
Thanks for confirming. Resolving as invalid.
Closing...

bug.short_desc: AbstractOslcRdfXmlProvider not considering annotations defined on interface or super-class

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
the AbstractOslcRdfXmlProvider does have an extra check for the accepted media type, which only considers the annotations of the implementing method.
To my understanding, this code is totally redundant. It is already checked by the Jax-Rs framework (e.g. Jersey). If the Jax-Rs framework could not match the required media type (and returned object) with that provider, we would not get called at all.
I would like to implement a fix for this, so it can be reviewed.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/110896
Reassigning to Jad to do the second vote on a patch.

The code looks redundant, but I am not sure in what case it is harmful. I am reluctant to change the code, unless/until we identify a problem with this redundant code.
Judging from the title of this bug, I assumed that the code breaks when JAX-RS annotations are not properly handled when only defined at the super-class level.
So, I created a JAX-RS service that inherits from a parent service. Annotations are only set at the parent level. The code behaves as expected.
Ca you please detail the scenario that is causing problems for you?

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #4) > The code looks redundant, but I am not sure in what case it is harmful. I am > reluctant to change the code, unless/until we identify a problem with this > redundant code. > > Judging from the title of this bug, I assumed that the code breaks when > JAX-RS annotations are not properly handled when only defined at the > super-class level. > > So, I created a JAX-RS service that inherits from a parent service. > Annotations are only set at the parent level. > The code behaves as expected. > > Ca you please detail the scenario that is causing problems for you?
Thank you for your elaboration, first. I'am using Jersey 2.26 as Jax-Rs framework.
The use-case is to have an interface class and an implementation class. On interface class, I have annotated methods with @GET, @Consumes and @Produces: @Produces("application/xml")
The implementation class has no annotation for this methods defined.
My investigation so far has shown that Jersey 2.26 does pass only annotations of the implementation class into the MessageBodyReader/Writer. Since no annotations are defined on implementation class, the AbstractOslcRdfXmlProvider is not serializing the OSLC Object (like Requirement or RequirementCollection).
Maybe Jersey is wrong here, and they need to consider also annotations of the interface.

Interesting, we have not migrated Lyo to Jersey yet. Would you be able to share a repo on Github running Jersey, one interface and one service implementation to have us debug the minimally breaking example, please?
I tested with child-parent class hierarchy, and with Wink. So if you can share some code, it would make it easier to replicate the problem.

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #7) > I tested with child-parent class hierarchy, and with Wink. > So if you can share some code, it would make it easier to replicate the > problem.
Please see https://github.com/benjaminr-ps/lyoIssue526717
Set neon.equinox.target, found in lyoIssue526717 project, as target platform. Use LyoIssue526717.launch to start Jetty server on port 8080 Open http://localhost:8080/service/publisher and you should get an Internal Server Error response.

(In reply to Benjamin Roehl from comment #8) > (In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #7) > > I tested with child-parent class hierarchy, and with Wink. > > So if you can share some code, it would make it easier to replicate the > > problem. > > Please see https://github.com/benjaminr-ps/lyoIssue526717 > > Set neon.equinox.target, found in lyoIssue526717 project, as target platform. > Use LyoIssue526717.launch to start Jetty server on port 8080 > Open http://localhost:8080/service/publisher and you should get an Internal > Server Error response.
Thank you, Benjamin. I try to debug it over the weekend and get back to you shortly.

Benjamin, I am able to reproduce "MessageBodyWriter not found" exception that is solvable by adding annotations on the Impl class. Please stay tuned.
I will keep you updated.
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/110896 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=4269a1079557d8a08cf4e3179178e3c6d874c7f6

bug.short_desc: RDF resource type included in Queryresult

long_desc.thetext:
The method OslcQueryResult::getMembersUrls() returns the TestResult rdf type once for each query executed (and for subsequencial fetch of nextPage results)
<rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/qm#TestResult"/>
The result is a unnecessary call to open-service.net!
We discoverd this bug while beeing offline (e.g. not connected to Internet) and running towards a local installed RQM server.

The ideal thing to do would be to get the resource shape for the Query Capability and determine the oslc:name of the members of the query result and then only return those resource references.
However, resource shapes are not required so this would not catch all cases.

Looking at doing some refactoring in OSLCClient to use more OSLC4J marshalling and POJO instead of all of the Jena processing being done now. Would give consumers access to POJOs for ServiceProvider, Service, etc.
We can safely ignore rdf:type predicates when the subject is the query capability.

Resolved with the changes for :
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=07cd9df3f8db12cf82f63137d191a8f445aa3a32
