bug.short_desc: Investigate uplift of TestSuites to Apache HttpClient 4.1.x

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
The test suites see occasional failures where the http client gets into a bad state - usually do to the failure of an earlier test.
The pattern used in the suites to consume the response content is known to have issues in the HttpClient 4.0.1 libraries we are using.
HttpClient 4.0.3 and up use a new pattern (HttpEntity#consumeContent()) which I am investigating as a possible solution to these issues.
Please assign this bug to Michael Fiedler
Reproducible: Sometimes
Steps to Reproduce: Run the CM test suite against the CM RIO you will see connection failures for the final tests. These are caused by the http client getting into a bad state due to [1].
[1] - https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=357277

Created attachment 205812 Update Apache httpclient to 4.1.1. Consume response correctly in event of error.
I wrote all this code and have the rights to contribute it to Eclipse under the eclipse.org web site terms of use

The attached patch allows SimplifiedQueryXmlTests to continue in event of error. It fixes the "Incorrect use of SingleClientConnManager" error subsequent tests would get due to improperly closed connections.

Going to make an additional change to hit all usage of the deprecated HttpEntity#consumeContent method. The current patch fixes the specific issue with leaked connections but we should use the new EntityUtils#consumeContent everywhere.
Created attachment 205831 Replace use of deprecated http client API

Committed http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=398d434621e15f3e384b55ef54ccbca80b41f7e2 http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=1728bc910b31abcfa36e7900ca8cc3440d5224b7
See comment 5
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

attachment.desc: Update Apache httpclient to 4.1.1. Consume response correctly in event of error.
Replace use of deprecated http client API

bug.short_desc: Architecture Management Resource not compliant to OSLC AM 2.0

long_desc.thetext:
The range annotation for service provider property is not set properly in the POJO of AM Resource, thus unmarshalling an AM Resource fails, if multiple service providers are defined in AM Resource.
Stacktrace: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.exception.OslcCoreMisusedOccursException: OSLC012: Multiple values for method setServiceProvider of class org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.resources.ArchitectureResource that supports at most one value at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper.fromResource(JenaModelHelper.java:879) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper.createObjectResultList(JenaModelHelper.java:457) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper.fromJenaModel(JenaModelHelper.java:395) at org.eclipse.lyo.core.utils.marshallers.OSLC4JUnmarshaller.unmarshal(OSLC4JUnmarshaller.java:62)
Thanks, we will look into that.

Benjamin, is it something you have a ready patch for?
Also, are you sure that it's a wrong range and not the type. I would think you want to change the 'setServiceProvider(final URI serviceProvider)' to 'setServiceProvider(final Set<URI> serviceProvider)'?
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/122641
GitHub Pull Request 2 created by [berezovskyi] https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.client/pull/2

The pull request needs some adaption.
I am not familiar with the Lyo Designer at all, thus I would fix it by hand again.
If would like to prefer to fix it with the help of Lyo Designer, please go for it.
I just wanted to make clear that my fix is not valid in this state yet.
Jim, Jad, I recally you had some comments about generating those resources but I can't seem to find them. What's your opinion?

The classes will be produced in the new Lyo.domains repo. It is part of this issue which I am working on.
https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.domains/issues/2
Benjamin! You dont need to know Lyo Designer, we will just use it to produce the classes. Once produced, I will look to see how your patch here differs from our latest.

The range should be oslc:ServiceProvider.
The other issues I had with the Lyo AM domain resulted from properties with missing types or incorrect cardinality, or properties that were taken from the draft AM 3.0 spec which I believe OASIS Domains TC is going to abandon.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #8) > The range should be oslc:ServiceProvider. > > The other issues I had with the Lyo AM domain resulted from properties with > missing types or incorrect cardinality, or properties that were taken from > the draft AM 3.0 spec which I believe OASIS Domains TC is going to abandon.
Jim! I believe the problem is not the range, but the cardinality of the property. The specs (both 2.0 and 2.1) state zero-or-many. Yet, the implementation has annotation "one".
Benjamin! If you want to use the implemenations under the new repository, we will be ensuring that these java classes are more up to date. https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.domains

Jad, how shall we proceed with this issue? There is a PR that needs to be re-applied on updated master again:
https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.client/pull/2
Also, there is a new lyo.domains repo. But then, could Lyo Client users instruct it to use classes from Lyo Domains instead? Still, we should then remove old classes or mark them deprecated at the very least.

(In reply to Andrii Berezovskyi from comment #10) > Jad, how shall we proceed with this issue? There is a PR that needs to be > re-applied on updated master again: > > https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.client/pull/2 > > Also, there is a new lyo.domains repo. But then, could Lyo Client users > instruct it to use classes from Lyo Domains instead? Still, we should then > remove old classes or mark them deprecated at the very least.
The classes in the lyo.domains repo can surely be used with the lyo.client. They are like any other oslc4j-annotated classes.
I am not keen to remove the old classes though, until we agree that lyo.domain is such a "reference" implementation.
I suggest we wait on this, until we work out if there is interest in providing 2.1 implementations.

long_desc.thetext: the net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4:jar:20090617 dependency can not be retrieved via maven since the specified version seems not to be available on central anymore.

Same for me, here is the output:
[INFO] Scanning for projects... Looks like the dependency is wrong in the pom.xml file. I should be:
<dependency> <groupId>net.oauth.core</groupId> <artifactId>oauth-httpclient4</artifactId> <version>20090913</version> <scope>compile</scope> </dependency>
Version 20090617 is of oauth-httpclient3.

I have updated the pom.xml to depend on latest versions of net.oauth libs. I discovered in the process that some of the dependencies were used indirectly through another dependencies:
[WARNING] Used undeclared dependencies found: [WARNING] log4j:log4j:jar:1.2.16:compile [WARNING] org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core:oslc4j-core:jar:3.0.0-SNAPSHOT:compile [WARNING] xerces:xercesImpl:jar:2.8.0:compile [WARNING] org.mockito:mockito-all:jar:1.8.5:test [WARNING] xml-apis:xml-apis:jar:1.3.04:compile [WARNING] org.apache.httpcomponents:httpcore:jar:4.1:compile [WARNING] javax.ws.rs:jsr311-api:jar:1.1.1:compile [WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found: [WARNING] net.oauth.core:oauth-consumer:jar:20090617:compile [WARNING] org.glassfish:javax.servlet:jar:3.1-b33:compile [WARNING] org.powermock:powermock-module-junit4:jar:1.4.9:test [WARNING] org.powermock:powermock-api-mockito:jar:1.4.9:test
I updated all of them, below is the diff-like list of changed versions (full trees are below for your convenience) and the corresponding CQ links for the fast-track review:
org.apache.jena:jena-core:jar:2.13.0:compile (version update from 2.7.1) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=8438 for reuse org.apache.jena:jena-iri:jar:0.9.2:compile (transitive, org.apache.jena:jena-core) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6575 for reuse org.slf4j:slf4j-log4j12:jar:1.6.4:compile (transitive, org.apache.jena:jena-core) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6782 for reuse log4j:log4j:jar:1.2.17:compile (transitive, org.apache.jena:jena-core) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=8600 for reuse xerces:xercesImpl:jar:2.8.0:compile (transitive, org.apache.jena:jena-core) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6583 for reuse net.oauth.core:oauth:jar:20100527:compile (version update from 20090617) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=5849 net.oauth.core:oauth-consumer:jar:20100527:compile (version update from 20090617) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=5850 net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4:jar:20090913:compile (version update from 20090617) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6940 org.apache.httpcomponents:httpcore:jar:4.1:compile (transitive, net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4)
org.apache.wink:wink-client-apache-httpclient:jar:1.3.0:compile -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=7195
org.mockito:mockito-all:jar:1.8.5:compile (was transitive dep of org.powermock:powermock-module-junit4:jar:1.4.9, removed) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=7713 javax.ws.rs:jsr311-api:jar:1.1.1 (transitive, org.apache.wink:wink-common) -> see https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6579
Transitive dependency means that our pom.xml included dependency A that itself included dependency B, but our project was directly calling the code not only of A but also B (see the report below). Now all such uses are 100% explicit.

Yes, the dependencies are a bit out of date and poking one often results in issues with many others. I have done a technical debt sweep of all of eclipse/Lyo and updated all the dependencies and built everything. The updated dependency for oauth-httpclient4 was built in that context on my local machine.
In order to deliver all these changes I need to do CQs for all the new dependency versions. Unfortunately I have not had time to address these this year, but will start working on them the first of the year.

Thanks for a prompt reply, Jim!
If you don't mind, we'll start figuring out how to fill the CQ questionnaires next week with Jad. All packages have at least one earlier version approved for reuse and everything except oauth, wink, and mockito has the approval for the exactly matching version. So I hope we'll qualify for the parallel IP process.
Have a nice weekend!
Andrew

bug.short_desc: Query capability is broken when a custom base URI is set

long_desc.thetext:
The client response on the QC of a deployed adaptor with the custom base URI is empty due to the mixup in the URIs in the response RDF:
<rdf:Description rdf:about="http://git.md.kth.se:8081/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/projectfiles"> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="https://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/fileResources/-1312126449"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="https://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/fileResources/-113038093"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="https://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/fileResources/308087035"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="https://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/fileResources/1685611991"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="https://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/fileResources/661711032"/> <oslc:totalCount rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#int">5</oslc:totalCount> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/core#ResponseInfo"/> </rdf:Description>
The result cannot be read due to the fact that the OSLC4J Client checks resource membership (https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.client/blob/master/org.eclipse.lyo.client.java/src/main/java/org/eclipse/lyo/client/oslc/resources/OslcQueryResult.java#L258) and the resulting iterator is empty.
Minimal failing example:
OslcQuery query = new OslcQuery(client, queryCapability); OslcQueryResult result = query.submit(); Iterable<FileResource> fileResources = result.getMembers(FileResource.class);

Are you sure about this analysis? I had a similar problem recently.
The problem may be due to the fact that the URI of the query resource being returned in the response is "http://git.md.kth.se:8081/...".
But, your client has requested a query resource with a different URI, and hence it is not seeing a resource at all (let alone its members) I am guessing that you are making a request to http://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume-demo-code-data/resources/projectfiles ?

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #1) > Are you sure about this analysis? I had a similar problem recently. > > The problem may be due to the fact that the URI of the query resource being > returned in the response is "http://git.md.kth.se:8081/...". > > But, your client has requested a query resource with a different URI, and > hence it is not seeing a resource at all (let alone its members) > I am guessing that you are making a request to > http://aide.md.kth.se/assume-code/services/file-management-services/assume- > demo-code-data/resources/projectfiles ?
Yes, that was my analysis as well, perhaps I did a bad job at describing the bug. The report is about the wrong URI used to generate the query resource.
Server hostname and Tomcat port are "http://git.md.kth.se:8081/"
However, the ".servlet.baseurl" context param is set in web.xml to "https://aide.md.kth.se/" (https instead of http, different hostname and different port). I think it might be actually a bug in the generator. I will need to regenerate with the latest version of it to confirm, but for now that adaptor is stuck on the old version with the UI preview & Bootstrap support.
So the bottom line is that I expect the ".servlet.baseurl" context param to be used for all URIs, but it was not the case here.

I don't know if it is connected, but I think I had the exact similar issue a while ago with members of QC, but only when the provider was deployed on the localhost, not with tomcat though.
My issue was solved by invoking OSLC4JUtils.setHostResolutionDisabled(true); in the contextInitializeServletListener of the provider.

(In reply to Frederic Loiret from comment #3) > I don't know if it is connected, but I think I had the exact similar issue a > while ago with members of QC, but only when the provider was deployed on the > localhost, not with tomcat though. > > My issue was solved by invoking > OSLC4JUtils.setHostResolutionDisabled(true); > in the contextInitializeServletListener of the provider.
Frdric, we had this bug before and decided to implement a better fix in Bug 517298. This bug is occurring only because the adaptor was generated using an old version of the generator. We have almost resolved Bug 519699 for the new templates, but the Bug 494303 is awaiting for me or Jad to pick the link preview apart from the template and (unfortunately) for the IP legal review, which got problematic because the Dojo library had some code with questionable copyright before. So this bug is a RESOLVED/INVALID for now (but I will keep it open and assign you to it for you to follow up) until the same issue is reproduced with the latest version of the code generator and OSLC4J core libraries.

(In reply to Frederic Loiret from comment #3)
Frederic, these bugs have now been resolved, could you please test with the latest build of the plugin? (we finally set up the auto-build!)
http://download.eclipse.org/lyo/p2/edge/
Just use the link above as the update site.
If the issue still persists, please reopen this bug.

bug.short_desc: License of the generated code

long_desc.thetext:
I was refactoring today a resource class generated by the modelling tools into a separate library and finally noticed that we kept generating the license header on the generated files as well.
I believe this was not intentional, i.e. you don't expect me to open-source all generated code of the adaptor under EPL if I use it?

We had this discussion when we first released the generator to Lyo. The conclusion was that the generated code does fall under the same license as the generator itself. (Not sure of exact legal formulation, but that's my interpretation).
But if you append/modify this generator code, I guess there is no expectation to make that code open-source.

I think this might be a big problem for the users of the generator (IANAL). An adaptor alone is not a derivative work of the Lyo project and thus does not require us to disclose the source code. However, when you put the EPL license on the generated code, the generated adaptor with my modifications becomes a derivative work that triggers a provision of EPL, which requires the users to open-source the generated adaptors with the modifications (see https://www.eclipse.org/legal/eplfaq.php#MODDIST).

bug.short_desc: Client: OslcQueryResult fails when other triples exist in the members resource

long_desc.thetext:
This can happen in many cases. If there are no query parameters on the URL, the ResponseInfo and members resource are actually the same resource. This means there are other triples like oslc:totalCount that cause runtime errors.
The other situation is if the provider just decides to add additional triples (for instance, adding in an rdf:type to the member resource). OslcQueryResult.getMembers() will treat the rdf:type as part of the query result.
Really the query result show use the value from the query shape for the provider, or rdfs:member if non query shape exists. I think the best solution is to allow consumers to set the member predicate and default to rdfs:member when it is missing. We can add a system property to default to the previous behavior in case a client is relying on it, but they really should be looking at the query shape.

Here is an example of a query response that causes errors:
GET /provider/query HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/rdf+xml
<?xml version="1.0"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"> <oslc:ResponseInfo rdf:about="http://example.com/provider/query"> <oslc:totalCount rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#int">0</oslc:totalCount> </oslc:ResponseInfo> </rdf:RDF>
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/18229/

(In reply to Samuel Padgett from comment #2)
Change merged.

bug.short_desc: Problems building core using the eclipse builder

long_desc.thetext:
Although most of the org.eclpse.lyo.oslc4 projects are maven projects, it is quite useful for those using eclipse for these project to build in eclipse. With Project > Build Automatically turned on, errors in Java files are immediately available, the Problems view is up to date, and search and content assist will all work properly and completely.
I have the following problems building all the projects in git repository org.eclipse.lyo.core using the latest master - 2.2.0-SNAPSHOT. Note that this repository contains a number of projects that are not distributed with OSLC4J SDK, but are used to test it. Also OSLC4J includes content from git repositories org.eclipse.lyo.client and org.eclipse.lyo.server (the OAuth projects) that also need to be built.
[ ] org.eclipse.lyo.core.query is missing a source directive to include the generated parsers so the eclipse build will work
The pom.xml installs, but Maven > Update Project does not appear to be sufficient to configure the .settings and/or .classpath so that the eclipse build runs. That's probably because the parsers are generated source and aren't in the java build path sources.
Adding target/generated-sources/antlr3 to the java build path sources fixed this problem. What should be added to the pom.xml file for this to happen on Maven > Update Project?
[ ] org.eclipse.lyo.oslcrj.adaptormodel has a bin folder
Should this be removed?
[ ] org.eclipse.lyo.oslcrj.codegenerator is not a maven project, so deleting its .settings and .classpath will cause the build to fail. These shouldnt be deleted. It no longer builds
Its .settings and .classpath should be restored and not ignored.
Perhaps the build fails because the Acceleo build isnt properly configured? Is /bin the right target folder?
[ ] org.eclipse.lyo.oclc4j.provider.json4j wont build with eclipse builder, pom.xml is missing <project.reporting.outputEncoding>UTF-8</project.reporting.outputEncoding> <maven.compiler.source>1.8</maven.compiler.source> <maven.compiler.target>1.8</maven.compiler.target>
[ ] org.eclipse.lyo.oscl4j.test wont build in eclipse, pom.xml is missing: <properties> <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding> <project.reporting.outputEncoding>UTF-8</project.reporting.outputEncoding> <maven.compiler.source>1.8</maven.compiler.source> <maven.compiler.target>1.8</maven.compiler.target> </properties>
-----------------------
Removing the .settings and .classpath from git is ok except for projects that are not maven projects: * org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.adaptormodel * org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.codegenerator
The settings for these projects were lost on master and need to be restored.

[ ] Maven > Update Project does change a few .project files: modified: org.eclipse.lyo.core.query/.project modified: org.eclipse.lyo.core.trs/.project modified: org.eclipse.lyo.core.utils/.project These changes need to be checked in

Jim, I have removed the project files from all but plugin project and updated the README with the project build instructions.
Jad, perhaps this change would require some changes to the wiki.
*** Bug 518475 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
.project files still need to be removed.
I think the bug is resolved, Jim?
Jim, please reopen if the issue persists.
Yes, I think all these issues have been resolved. Thanks for the great work!
Will land in 2.3.0

bug.short_desc: Client getResource accepts inner local Resource

long_desc.thetext:
This is difficult since the API comes from Wink client. We could look at the request URL when available and try to match it to the resource in the model. I'm hesitant to do that, however, since people might be using the API like this intentionally, and we could break them.
I agree we need a way to fetch more than one resource. This could be mandatory when we add W3C LDP support, which will be part of OSLC 3.0.
Note that if you read the response into a Jena model, you could use JenaModelHelper.fromJenaResource() to get the specific resources you want, but it's a little extra work.
Cecilia, if you agree, I suggest we close this bug and open a new enhancement to support getting multiple resources.
I agree, we close this.

(In reply to Cecilia A Lindgren from comment #2)
Thanks, Ceceilia. Closing.

bug.short_desc: NPE when entering non existing Project area

Bug encounted in RQMFormSample::main
OslcClient::lookupServiceProviderUrl (called in Step 5) returns null when entering a non-existing project area. This creates a NPE in Step 6.
at org.apache.wink.client.RestClient.resource(RestClient.java:112) at org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.OslcClient.getResource(OslcClient.java:125) at org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.OslcClient.lookupService(OslcClient.java:259) at org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.OslcClient.lookupQueryCapability(OslcClient.java:227) at org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.samples.RQMFormSample.main(RQMFormSample.java:108)
The proper way to handle this situation is to throw an ResourceNotFoundException.

Need better errors for any of the lookups (rootservices, catalog or service provider). Add a new ResourceNotFoundException with a message in the bundle and inserts to indicate what could not be found and where we were looking.

bug.short_desc: Extended property value containing invalid value is created as String property instead ou throwing an error

long_desc.thetext:
The problem is related to a resource contaning an invalid value in an extended property when the data type is explicitly passed. In this scenario, instead of throwing an exception, OSLC4J creates a given property as String property.
Example of resource containing an invalid boolean property:
<rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:rr="http://www.ibm.com/xmlns/prod/tivoli/registry" xmlns:crtv="http://open-services.net/ns/crtv#" xmlns:vm="http://open-services.net/ns/vm-monitoring/1.0/"> <crtv:ComputerSystem rdf:about="http://test.ibm.com/osl4j/computer-001"> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/ns/ism/registry#RegistrationRecord"/> <oslc:serviceProvider rdf:resource="http://localhost:9080/oslc/providers/1356025969942"/> <crtv:booleanProperty rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#boolean">invalidValue</crtv:booleanProperty2> </crtv:ComputerSystem> </rdf:RDF>
The problem is in JenaModelHelper.java class, in the method: handleExtendedPropertyValue. When the data type is explicitly passed, the following line of code throws an exception: final Object literalValue = literal.getValue();
At the bottom, there is a try-catch block for this, that instead of throwing an exception, just return the property as String:
catch (final DatatypeFormatException e) { return object.asLiteral().getString(); }
Please, let me know if you have any question on this.
Thanks, Fabiana
https://git.eclipse.org/r/15420

bug.short_desc: LyoStore fails with an exception when trying to get a resource that does not exist.

long_desc.thetext: Andrii! I can do the change, but I know you have opinions about returning nulls. So, what is the alternative.

Well, did you forget to call the contains method?
Otherwise I suggest throwing a custom exception.

Okay, I had a look and identified two issues:
* the method should have thrown NoSuchElementException in this case * you should have called resourceExists(graph, resource) before calling the getResource() method
We can deal with the first issue, you should fix your code to deal with the second.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/100909

(In reply to Andrii Berezovskyi from comment #2) > Well, did you forget to call the contains method? > > Otherwise I suggest throwing a custom exception.
by contains, you mean the method? boolean resourceExists(final URI namedGraphUri, final URI resourceUri)
I did not. And, we can't enforce that the user does that check first. so we do need to deal with the exception.
Plus, that would be 2 database hits just to get a resource. I'd rather get it in one hit. But throwing a meaninful exception (as currently patched) is fine for me.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J returns ServiceProvider's XMLLiteral fields without corresponding type

long_desc.thetext: By definition of Service Provider: http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecification?sortcol=table;up=#Service_Provider_Resources it has 2 XMLLiteral fields: dcterms:title, dcterms:description. I can create ServiceProvider with following payload: ServiceProvider_A1 Base on that I got following RDF+XML: <b>ServiceProvider_A1</b> But it should be ServiceProvider_A1 or equivalent: <b>ServiceProvider_A1</b> You can verify it using RDF-VALIDATOR: http://www.w3.org/RDF/Validator/ by following payload: <b>ServiceProvider_A1</b> ServiceProvider_A2 <b>ServiceProvider_A3</b> It produce 3 triples. 2 with type XMLLiteral and 1 without any type. OSLC4J produce payload without type.

Resolved with the following commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=5a1d8418815287175e06873b17977f1595f59cad

I think this defect wasn't fixed. I get latest nightly build: May 22, 2012 6:15:27 PM
And send following payload: POST http://localhost:9080/oslc/pr/collection Content-Type: application/rdf+xml <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:oslc_data="http://open-services.net/ns/servicemanagement/1.0/"> <oslc:ServiceProvider > <dcterms:title> 1 < 2 </dcterms:title> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/monitoring/1.0/"/> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdf:RDF>
It was accepted and as return I have:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#"> <oslc:ServiceProvider rdf:about="http://rsobczyszyn.krakow.pl.ibm.com:9080/oslc/providers/1337945796229"> <dcterms:title rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#XMLLiteral" > 1 < 2 </dcterms:title> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/monitoring/1.0/"/> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdf:RDF>
As you can see cterms:title is <dcterms:title rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#XMLLiteral" > 1 < 2 </dcterms:title>
Which is equivalent to: <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal"> 1 < 2 </dcterms:title>
which is incorrect XMLLiteral. Build seems to be correct because previous one doesn't return rdf:datatype.

bug.short_desc: Take consideration of Vocabulary definitions in the generated resource classes

long_desc.thetext: The code generartor does not currently consider the rdfs:class refered to from a resource (shape). The resulting "describes" property points to the implicit rds:class value which is the shape defintion itself. Instead, it should refer to the defined rdfs:class from the vocabulary model.

I think it is more conceptual problem: shapes provide property definition of OSLC resources and RDF classes are used for representing class hierarchies. Lyo Designer's resource allows both to be defined and uses them to output a single Java class per resource.

(In reply to Andrii Berezovskyi from comment #1) > I think it is more conceptual problem: shapes provide property definition of > OSLC resources and RDF classes are used for representing class hierarchies. > Lyo Designer's resource allows both to be defined and uses them to output a > single Java class per resource.
I am not sure I identify the problem you present. what we call "resource" in the model is actually a "shape" (but I have to live with the names I chose in the meta-model some time ago). It is a resource/shape that maps to a Java class.
Prior to the availability of Vocabs models, a resource/shape also implied an rdfs:class of the same name as the shape. This is still the default case, since I think it is most convenient for most users.
Now, for some advanced cases, people needed to specify an rdfs:class and associate a shape (or more) that have a different name than the shape.
it is the latter case that we now support in the model. But, the generator is still completely unaware of the vocab model.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/119527
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/119527 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.tools.git/commit/?id=0fe3c9b7d3e3ac71ad8645ad4415423444d18736

bug.short_desc: Allow DomainSpecifications to override the default packagenames and locations of their resulting javaclasses

long_desc.thetext:
When generating the resource classes, the classes are generated in each Adaptor based on the javaClassBaseNamespace and javaFilesBasePath paramter set on each adptor.
Provide (optional) settings on each Domain Specification, to override the javaClassBaseNamespace and javaFilesBasePath parameters set on each adaptor.
This also allows all adaptors to share a common set of java classes, being generated onto a common class library.

Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/101245 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.tools.git/commit/?id=0cd53b0d842ff845f4c8240f4e3b8bde0649dfd9
Looks like it has been resolved, closing as fixed.

bug.short_desc: Non-matching entity tags should still be quoted strings.

long_desc.thetext:
The test suite currently uses the value Bogus when it sends an Etag which will not match. It expects a 412 in response. However, the value is sent un-quoted and when it is un-quoted, RRC returns a 400 instead of a 412.
I initially thought this was an RRC issue, but per section 3.11 of RFC 2616 (HTTP 1.1), valid entity tags must be quoted, so a 400 from RRC seems fair.
The test suite should be corrected to quote entity tags it does not expect to find matches for.
It is actually the If-Match header on PUT request that needs to be modified since the test suite is in the consumer role.

Resolved by
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=88183aeef4bed3b11e496dc105ee248d56bae387

bug.short_desc: Use JSP fragments to render Resource representation

long_desc.thetext:
Current generator adds HTML code generation methods to the Resource class. This is basically violation of MVC by putting V into M.
We should use some way (some sources suggest custom JSP tags as the best approach, but jsp:include should be the easiest) to separate the resource template from the general page template.
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3698068/jsp-include-with-parameters-usage and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14580120/whats-the-difference-between-including-files-with-jsp-include-directive-jsp-in

bug.short_desc: Stop using arrays in the Manager class

long_desc.thetext:
Some methods shall return arrays, some lists. It confused a new user during the live pair programming session.
Would also be good to init the resources list to an empty arraylist, so that we can just append in the protected block.
Finally, the suggestion was to let exceptions like URIexcetion to bubble up to the service and be handled there (declare Manager methods as throws URIException).

Concerning arrays vs lists: Agree. But to be clear only the method getServiceProviderInfos() expects an array. the rest is consistently Lists.
Concerning "init of list": I thought List is an interface, and we want to let the developer use any implementation, and not just arrayList?
Concerning "let exceptions bubble up": I don't see any exceptions being caught in the Manager class!
As Jad said, "only the method getServiceProviderInfos() expects an array. the rest is consistently Lists."

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.test.ResolveURITest can fail due to non-independent unit tests

long_desc.thetext: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.test.ResolveURITest contains two unit tests which are not independent of each other: testPublicURI()and testDisableHostResolution(). If testDisableHostResolution() is performed before testPublicURI(), the testDisableHostResolution fails. If testPublicURI is performed first, the publicURI variable in the OSLC4JUtils class will be initialized, and testDisableHostResolution will succeed. However, if testDisableHostResolution is performed first, the publicURI variable in the OSLC4JUtils class will not have been initialized and testDisableHostResolution will fail. As a solution, I propose to separate both tests into separate Java classes.

Axel, thanks for the report.
I believe this was fixed with Bug 420620. When I run just the testDisableHostResolutionTest by right-clicking it in Eclipse, it passes. Do you still see the problem?
I see this was opened against 2.0.0 and the fix was in 2.1.0. Resolving as works-for-me for now. Please reopen if I'm mistaken.

bug.short_desc: Set the value of publicURI in OSLC4JUtils

long_desc.thetext:
OSLC4JUtils.getPublicURI() is needed by methods within Core.
When not set, there is a difference between the base uri used in the application, and those produced within Core. For example, the method OSLCResourceShapreResource:getResourceShape() depends on OSLC4JUtils. When the publicURI is not set, the resulting URI used in the resource about property is "http://localhost:8080/MyAdaptor", yet the request is "http://localhost:8080/services/MyAdaptor"
THis method is expected to be set via a System property of value "OSLC4JConstants.OSLC4J_PUBLIC_URI" (See OSLC4JUtils class)
Instead of setting this system property, call the method OSLC4JUtils.setPublicURI() from the ServletListener class, where the ServicesBase is being set anyway.

bug.short_desc: Deleting a reference property allocated to a resource, wrongly deletes the property itself

long_desc.thetext:
If I delete a literay property (example dcterms:title) from the list of properties allocated to a resource, the allocation itself is deleted, by the property itself is still defined (under dcterms).
Similarly, if I delete a reference property (example dcterms:creator) from the list of properties allocated to a resource, the allocation itself is deleted, by the property itself is still defined (under dcterms). this property is normally shown as an arrow.
BUT, - sometimes, if I delete a reference property (example dcterms:creator) from the list of properties allocated to a resource, the property itself is also deleted (from under dcterms).
When does this occur? When the reference property is NOT represented as an arrow, but is instead listed together with literal properties. This in turn occurs when the resource being referenced is NOT in the same diagram, hence we have nothing to point the arrow to!
See attached picture for hte scenario.
Created attachment 274366 bug

I'm kind of confused as to what is mean by missing test coverage dealing with AM resources. First, by AM do you mean Asset Management? Second if that is the case, in the GetAndUpdateXMLTests class there are a tests that upload, create and remove Artifacts from an Asset. An Asset is also manipulated in that class. If you also look at CreateAssetXMLTest you will find tests that create and delete different assets. However you won't find tests for headers because the CreateAndUpdate Test class in the base package already test for that. So that is why I am confused by no tests being found. Now if AM means Architecture Management then, I was not aware that they were needed under the Asset Management tests.

Tim,
First of all, am stands for Asset Management in this context.
Secondly, this is to evaluate and increase testing coverage on AM resource specific properties. For instance
http://open-services.net/wiki/asset-management/OSLC-Asset-Management-2.0-Specification/#Asset Listed many Asset specific properties, such as oslc_asset:guid, oslc_asset:version, oslc_asset:abstract, etc.
Do we have tests to cover verifying these properties? Maybe we do but buried in GetAndUpdate test. Please check.
You can take a look at the org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.cm or org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.qm packages to see how the CM or QM resources and their properties are being tested.
Let me know if there is clear,
thanks

long_desc.thetext: New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/100103

I have added the patch, but I am reluctant to accept it for a number of reasons:
* It seems to be a workaround for another hack (of modifying the PROPERTY_ALLOWED_VALUE not through the intended interface) * There is no unit test for the fix * You must edit my commit message and replace the line "Contributed by Nick Crossley (ECA)" with a "Signed-off-by: Nick Crossley <xxx@ema.il>" at the bottom of the commit message.
Until then I have given the patch a -1 review.
Agree that there should be no case where the values aren't a collection. However, it may be out of our hands to prevent setting the value to a singleton unless setValues prevents it.
Well, setValue(Collection) prevents the wrong values from being assigned but the underlying map can be directly manipulated through getExtendedProperties().put(k,v).
Thank you a lot, Nick, we should investigate the root problem then. I will look at it in the coming days.
Sorry, don't think I will have time to investigate soon. Please take a look at the patch and adjust as needed. In any case, Nick, you will need to edit the commit message and sign off on it.

Hi Nick,
Are you interested in putting a bit of effort to resolve this bug in the upcoming 2.3.0 release (ETA before the end of the year)?
/Andrew
As with bug 518809, yes, I would like to work on this, but I am not able to do so until after February 2018.
Targeting the bugfix for 2.4.0 (see bug 518809).
What's the status of this bug? Are we still intending to fix? Or shall I abandon the Gerrit patch?
I added a Gerritt review comment - let me know if I did not put that in the right place, or if there's something else I need to do to get this change in.
I think instead of this patch we need to fix the root issue, even if that means changing Lyo code.

If the method JenaModelHelper.fromJenaModel is to be rewritten imminently, then I'd be fine with not applying this fix. However, until that method is fixed not to construct single allowed values as scalars instead of signal-element collections, then Lyo will break trying to read any existing object with a single allowed value.
If a rewrite of JenaModelHelper.fromJenaModel is to be 2 or more releases in the future, it seems having this patch or something similar as at least a temporary fix is preferable to hang Lyo code fail with an exception when trying to read perfectly valid RDF.

(In reply to Nick Crossley from comment #15) > If the method JenaModelHelper.fromJenaModel is to be rewritten imminently, > then I'd be fine with not applying this fix. However, until that method is > fixed not to construct single allowed values as scalars instead of > signal-element collections, then Lyo will break trying to read any existing > object with a single allowed value. > > If a rewrite of JenaModelHelper.fromJenaModel is to be 2 or more releases in > the future, it seems having this patch or something similar as at least a > temporary fix is preferable to hang Lyo code fail with an exception when > trying to read perfectly valid RDF.
1) Could you please give me an example Turtle of a Shape that would allow reproducing this? Also, please provide a list of calls starting with fromJenaModel() till you trigger a cast exception.
2) I don't see any wrong code in JMH.fromJenaModel(). So either the root cause is somewhere above, or we need to add to JMH.fromJenaModel() some special logic. But then it's no better that the logic in your patch.

bug.short_desc: XMLLiteral datatype is not added to extended properties

long_desc.thetext: There is no way to explicitly define the types of extended properties. In general, this is not an issue, as (most of the time) the proper rdf:datatype is inferred from the corresponding Java type. However, there is no Java type for XMLLiteral, so extended properties of such type end up being handled as plain strings (the XMLLiteral datatype is lost). There should be a way to explicitly set the type for extended properties, similarly to what is accomplished via the @OslcValueType annotation.

Francisco, if you add an org.w3c.dom.Element to the extended properties, it should be serialized as an XMLLiteral. I believe that XMLLiterals are read in as strings, however. This is an inconsistency.
The problem with org.w3c.dom.Element is that it requires the content to be enclosed in start/end tags. However, XMLLiteral allows for more general text, including strings with no markup at all.

I have a change set that adds an XMLLiteral object that can be used for literals in an extended properties map.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/14386

Resolved by commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=d8dc855bee7443639223e1e165d580aa968873b7

bug.short_desc: Invoking updateResource() on Test Plans & Cases Removes Existing Links to Requirement Collections, Requirements, Test Cases and Test Scripts

long_desc.thetext:
I'm experiencing the following with org.eclipse.lyo.client.java
Environment: CLM 4.0.5
To Reproduce:
Manually: 1. Manually create a test plan; link it to an RRC requirement collection 2. Add a test case to the plan 3. Link the test case to a requirement 4. Link the test case to a test script
in code: 3. GET the test plan 4. Put it back with updateResource(). I'm putting it back like so:
rqmClient.updateResource(oslcTestPlan.getAbout().toString(), oslcTestPlan, OslcMediaType.APPLICATION_RDF_XML, OslcMediaType.APPLICATION_RDF_XML);
Expected: No change has been made to the plan Actual: links to test cases and requirement collection are gone
5. GET the test case 6. Put it back with updateResource()
Expected: No change has been made to the case Actual: links to requirement and test script are gone
What seemed to be a bug was my own error in how I was using the API.

bug.short_desc: OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider does no work with Response.ok().entity(List<MyClass>)

long_desc.thetext: While calling Response.ok().entity(object) passing a List, when the OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider.isWriteable() is called the Type genericType is lost. In my case, I pass an ArrayList<MyClass> and the genericType is ArrayList, instead of MyClass. Thats why the OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider is not working when using the Response.ok().entity(List<MyClass>).

I don't think it's possible to support this as written due to type erasure in Java. It's the reason the JAX-RS generic entity class exists.
Is the problem with ResponseInfoCollection?
Sam, as per your suggestion, we're encapsulating the response in a GenericEntity object, which works just fine. So I think you can go ahead and close this bug. Thanks.

(In reply to comment #2)
Thanks, closing based on comments 1 and 2.

bug.short_desc: Link class contains no equality methods

long_desc.thetext: Lack of equals() & hashCode() methods prevents proper checks of HashSet<Link> etc.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/94116
What's the use case? Do we consider link labels as contributing to semantics or are they just decoration?

Both link URI and its label are serialised into RDF. The use case is our implementation of TRS and versioning, we want to be able to do 'resourceA.getLinksToOtherResource.equals(resourceB.getLinksToOtherResource)', where 'HashSet<Link> getLinksToOtherResource()'.
I think if you want to discard some data from the equality op, you can use a wrapper class or some similar idea.

Jim, I now take my arguments back. On the second thought, it makes no sense to allow two links with the exact same URI and different labels. So it makes sense if there are two links L1 and L2 with the same URI but different label to have
links.contains(L2)
return true even if only L1 was added. From the RDF side it also makes sense to add multiple labels to a single resource, you won't be able to serialise them into two separate RDF resources.
So I have adjusted the equality operator according and submitted it for the review.
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/94116 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=8b2fe91514ea8c1919eb5faf3f7ffc44258e5208

bug.short_desc: TODO markers cannot be removed after generation

long_desc.thetext:
TODO markers are inserted to remind the developer to implement certain portions of code. However, after implementing the necessary code, the markers cannot be removed.
The proposed solution is to move markers under the protected code block so that the developer can remove them.
Also, there is a mix of tabs and spaces in the code. I think we have agreed on using spaces (due to, among other things, lack of tab settings support in Gerrit as well as bugs in Eclipse diff tools). I suggest converting all tabs to spaces and trimming all trailing whitespaces in the mtl files.
Finally, while going through the code, I found many irrelevant comments in the service template file that were copied from Bugzilla sample adaptor. I wasn't able to generalise them well enough (because a single method template was used to generate code for manipulating a single resource as well as lists of resources maybe I was wrong with this one) so I think it's best to remove those comments from the generated code as to not to confuse the beginners.
I have a patch for this bug, please assign me to it.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/87358
I have uploaded a new patch with the reduced scope (to fixing the originally discussed TODO markers) and extracted two other issues into Bug 509394 and Bug 509395.

bug.short_desc: Serializer throwing 500 error without stack trace when missing OslcResourceShape annotation

long_desc.thetext:
The OSLC4J serializer throws a HTTP 500 error when it attempts to serialize a class that is not annotated with the @OslcResourceShape annotation.
This was observed with 3.0.0-SNAPSHOT from https://repo.eclipse.org/content/repositories/lyo-snapshots/, while attempting to serialize to Turtle.

If the resource in question is the top-level resource, I suspect the 500 error is coming from Wink since it can't find any MessageBodyWriters to use. The problem is there might be other writers that can handle the media type that are not Lyo, so we shouldn't necessarily flag this as an "error." Rather we just tell Wink the resource is not writeable.
We might provide better logging when this happens. Default to the WARN level, and provide some documentation on how to troubleshoot these problems.
There is probably some logging you can enable in Wink as well.
Cleaning up "3.0.0" bugs.

bug.short_desc: OslcRdfXmlArrayProvider treats any array as an OSLC Query response

long_desc.thetext:
If you try to createModel(new Object{a, c, d}) where a points to b and c through links of its localresource (a.getB() is a of type B and has Link to c and d), looping property will appear:
<a> rdfs:member <a>, <c>, <d> .
First one causes Bug 531984, the latter are just incorrect.

My apologies, factual incorrectness:
new Object{a, b, c} is being serialised
but 'b' is a localprop of a and is already linked from it via a HashSet.

Okay, forget everything I wrote here. I will also rename the issue.
The offending code is OslcRdfXmlArrayProvider! It thinks that any array that we return is an OSLC Query response, which is, obviously a huge nonsense!
Unfortunately, I guess many people may rely on this behaviour so we have to introduce a new system property lyo.doNotJumpToConclusionsWhenProcessingArraysOrCollections :)

bug.short_desc: ninacrm hostname should be "localhost" to simplify setup

long_desc.thetext:
The hostname variable across NinaCRM is set to "oslc".
However, the OSLC4J Bugzilla adapter that NinaCRM chats with runs by default at localhost.
So, if you don't set up something in /etc/hosts, NinaCRM makes requests to http://oslc:8080/ that don't resolve.
I was able to "fix" by changing the hostname variable in a few files:
NewDefect.java DataLoader.java index.jsp
After a updated install, that got it working.

https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.docs.git/commit/?id=ac97a1c40edb0efc8849b7e2874bed523a215eef

bug.short_desc: Generate client-only adaptors

long_desc.thetext: Code generator implicitly assumes that a ServiceProviderCatalog exists, even though the model allows an adaptor that does not include a SPC. long_desc.thetext: New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/100110
Thank you Nick, I have uploaded the change. Please add the Signed-off-by (you can edit the patch online).
Nick, I was not able to add you to the Gerrit review. Could you please sign in there and make sure your account is up and running?

I do not currently have a Gerrit account, or the software. I had hoped to set that up before I left on vacation next week, but that will not now happen, so I'll try to do it after I'm back in the middle of July.

Jim, Jad, just reread the patch messages. Do you have any ideas on the Exception message to throw?
Nick, you might want to look at the discussion thread on Gerrit (the link is above in this bug thread "New Gerrit change ...") and see if the proposed solution would work for you. Briefly, Jad suggests to throw an exception or a stronger log error instead of "swallowing" an; we agreed on an Exception.
ResourceShape::property is Zero-or-many, so it is not an error for there to be no properties. No exception should be raised.

Hi Nick,
Are you interested in putting a bit of effort to resolve this bug in the upcoming 2.3.0 release (ETA before the end of the year)?
/Andrew
Yes, I would like to help with this and other Lyo fixes and new development - but realistically, that will not be able to be until after February 2018: I am fully committed until then.

Sure, Nick, I understand. We will tentatively target the bugfix for 2.4.0, but will look into it if we get extra time before the release. I think we will begin working on it around mid-January and it should land next spring.
What's the status of this bug? Are we still intending to fix? Or shall I abandon the Gerrit patch?
I added a Gerritt review comment - let me know if I did not put that in the right place, or if there's something else I need to do to get this change in.
Nick, Jim, please take a look at the comments I left on Gerrit.

bug.short_desc: make building the OSLC4J RIOs (and testsuites) easier

long_desc.thetext:
It is annoying to have to build all the projects for one of the OSLC4J RIOs or domain testsuites in order. e.g. the instructions here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildingOSLC4J#Run_the_Change_Management_sample_provider
instead, lets have a build project for all the oslc4j projects in the org.eclipse.lyo.rio repository
I've got a simple Maven project that you can do the Maven Install or Maven Clean on and have it handle that job for all the related projects, in order.
This is similar to the already existing org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.build project in the org.eclipse.lyo.core repo.

If I'm the owner, I can push my changes to Gerrit for review.
A related question: what should be the name of the new project? (again in only builds the OSLC4J projects in the org.eclipse.lyo.rio repo) currently I have: org.eclipselyo.oslc4j.rio.build but I could see it being called either of: a) org.eclipse.lyo.rio.build.oslc4j b) org.eclipse.lyo.rio.oslc4j.build (The current name, org.eclipselyo.oslc4j.rio.build seems more in line with the oslc4j build project in the core repo.)
A slightly less-related question: should the OSLC4J RIOs be renamed to include "rio" in their names? e.g. org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.changemanagement > org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.changemanagement.rio ?

(In reply to comment #1) > what should be the name of the new project? (again in only builds the OSLC4J > projects in the org.eclipse.lyo.rio repo) > currently I have: org.eclipselyo.oslc4j.rio.build > but I could see it being called either of: > a) org.eclipse.lyo.rio.build.oslc4j > b) org.eclipse.lyo.rio.oslc4j.build > (The current name, org.eclipselyo.oslc4j.rio.build seems more in line with > the oslc4j build project in the core repo.)
org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.rio.build seems to make sense to me.
> A slightly less-related question: > should the OSLC4J RIOs be renamed to include "rio" in their names? > e.g. > org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.changemanagement > > org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.changemanagement.rio > ? Looking at these recently, I don't like any of the names ;)
I'd prefer: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.cm as the "parent" project identifier for all things developed using oslc4j for CM and then attach right "sub names" such as: ".rio", ".client", etc.
Perhaps we could add on to Sam's lyo-dev thread about project names for this one.
the discussion about project naming has been moved to the mailing list: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/lyo-dev/msg00419.html
*** Bug 413245 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Verified the change. Thanks, Sean!
I'll look at updating the wiki
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildingOSLC4J

bug.short_desc: Unexpected lexical representation for floating point infinity

long_desc.thetext: As per the XML Schema datatypes spec (www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2), sections 3.2.4.1 and 3.2.5.1, positive & negative infinity have a lexical representation of INF & -INF respectively. However, OSLC4J is returning these values as Infinity & -Infinity respectively.

Hi, Fancisco. When does this happen? Serializing an object with Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY as a property value?
I see this was opened against 1.1. We did recently add better support for RDF data types in Bug 411535, which might have fixed this.

Hi Sam. I work in the same project as Givanildo, so we're using the build you guys provided with a few fixes on top of 1.2 (so bug 411535 does not help here). The specific test we ran was trying to serialize float negative infinity. We were expecting: <crtv:testFloat2rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float">-INF</crtv:testFloat2> but we got: <crtv:testFloat2rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float">-Infinity</crtv:testFloat2>
Thanks, I'll take a look.

Francisco, it looks like Infinity, -Infinity, and NaN are not supported by the JSON spec.
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4627.txt
"Numeric values that cannot be represented as sequences of digits (such as Infinity and NaN) are not permitted."
I have a fix for RDF/XML and Turtle, but not JSON. The JSON provider will give an error if you try to serialize these values. Is that acceptable?

Change set for review:
https://git.eclipse.org/r/14408

Thanks, Sam. >>"The JSON provider will give an error if you try to serialize these values. Is that acceptable?" That's OK, but we need more details about this error to be able to handle it properly. Is it an exception? Could you point us to the code that gives the error?

Sam, in discussing this issue internally, we believe it may not be acceptable to give an error when trying to serialize Infinity/NaN in JSON. Would it be possible to have the JSON provider serialize such values as follows: Infinity -> highest positive value (double or float) -Infinity -> lowest negative value (double or float) NaN -> null Apparently a few serializers already do something like that.
Let me investigate more. I've committed the RDF/XML change, but I've left the bug open to look at supporting it in JSON.

It looks like the Wink JSON4J provider serializes Infinity, -Infinity, and NaN as null.
For another data point, GSON throws IllegalArgumentException by default, but has a flag to allow these special values, serializing them out as the JavaScript keywords.
http://google-gson.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/gson/docs/javadocs/com/google/gson/GsonBuilder.html#serializeSpecialFloatingPointValues()
I think I would prefer this to be an error by default, but to give a flag to do something with these values. I'm not sure the largest or smallest float is right, though. Would the strings "INF", "-INF", and "NaN" be better? Possibly null for NaN?
Longer term, I think JSON-LD is the right answer (Bug 404683).

Returning an error is bad because we may have RDF/XML clients posting resources with such special values and JSON clients trying to retrieve them. The current behavior for JSON (positive/negative infinity and NaN are all mapped to null) is OK for the time being.

(In reply to comment #10)
Playing devil's advocate, this could be an example of why we *should* return an error. Otherwise, we are silently returning incomplete or incorrect data. The resource can't be represented in the OSLC JSON format.

The problem from a client perspective is that they might be doing a general query, not retrieving a specific resource, and if the query fails, there is no way for the client to react to that. Even though only one property is not representable in JSON, the client has no way of knowing which property of which resource that is, and they can't retrieve data for other resources using that query. The behavior of substituting a valid JSON value will at least allow the client to retrieve all of the other data in the query results. We can discuss what the best value to substitute would be, and perhaps null is OK, but failing the request would be a problem.
With JSON-LD this will not be a problem, because all values are represented as JSON strings, rather than trying to use other JSON types for non-string values.

The JSON changes were made in this commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=348550a3937639900b35f06d0c854f149363652f
It introduces the following system properties (both true by default):
org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.readSpecialNumberValues org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.writeSpecialNumberValues
The change avoids errors with the JSON representation and allows for round-tripping without data loss. The values set in JSON are "INF", "-INF", and "NaN".
(Part of the change was accidentally delivered with project renames, patch set 2.)

bug.short_desc: LDP reference implementation: Respond with text/turtle when no Accept header present

long_desc.thetext:
https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/ldpwg/raw-file/default/ldp.html
4.3.2.1 LDP servers must provide a text/turtle representation of the requested LDP-RS whenever HTTP content negotiation does not force another outcome [turtle]. In other words, if the server receives a GET request whose Request-URI identifies a LDP-RS, and either text/turtle has the highest relative quality factor (q= value) in the Accept request header or that header is absent, then an LDP server has to respond with Turtle.

bug.short_desc: ResponseInfo does not return in the about URL query parameters not started with "oslc."

long_desc.thetext:
Mariana,
Apologies for not commenting sooner.
I can't reproduce this problem. I tried this with the OSLC4JChangeManagement sample:
http://localhost:8080/OSLC4JChangeManagement/services/changeRequests?oslc.select=*&my_param=true
I get this ResponseInfo back:
<oslc:ResponseInfo rdf:about="http://localhost:8080/OSLC4JChangeManagement/services/changeRequests?oslc.select=*&my_param=true"> <oslc:totalCount>3</oslc:totalCount> </oslc:ResponseInfo>
OslcRdfXmlProvider is looking at the query parameters just to see if there is a "oslc." parameter in the URL, but it adds the full query string to responseInfoURI.
Let me know if you still disagree.

bug.short_desc: AdaptorManager cannot return an immutable list of Resources

long_desc.thetext:
If we return an immutable list (e.g. https://google.github.io/guava/releases/snapshot/api/docs/com/google/common/collect/ImmutableList.html), the generated adaptor will break due to the subsequent List.remove calls by the framework (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/List.html#remove-int-).
We should instead call List.sublist (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/List.html#subList-int-int-) and document the n+1 behaviour in some generated Javadoc.

bug.short_desc: createResourceAndUpdateIt failed when ran JUnit test "Test RIO-CM"

long_desc.thetext:
When ran JUnit test "Test RIO-CM", org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.CreationAndUpdateRdfXmlTests createResourceAndUpdateIt() failed by below error.
java.lang.AssertionError: HTTP Response body: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" > <oslc:Error> <oslc:statusCode>500</oslc:statusCode> <oslc:message>Invalid If-Unmodified-Since Header</oslc:message> </oslc:Error> </rdf:RDF> expected:<200> but was:<412> at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:91) at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:645) at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:126) at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:470) at org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.CreationAndUpdateBaseTests.createResourceAndUpdateIt(CreationAndUpdateBaseTests.java:220) at org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.CreationAndUpdateXmlTests.createResourceAndUpdateIt(CreationAndUpdateXmlTests.java:88) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:60) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:37) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:611) at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod$1.runReflectiveCall(FrameworkMethod.java:44) at org.junit.internal.runners.model.ReflectiveCallable.run(ReflectiveCallable.java:15) at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod.invokeExplosively(FrameworkMethod.java:41) at org.junit.internal.runners.statements.InvokeMethod.evaluate(InvokeMethod.java:20) at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:76) at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:50) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$3.run(ParentRunner.java:193) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$1.schedule(ParentRunner.java:52) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runChildren(ParentRunner.java:191) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.access$000(ParentRunner.java:42) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$2.evaluate(ParentRunner.java:184) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.run(ParentRunner.java:236) at org.junit.runners.Suite.runChild(Suite.java:128) at org.junit.runners.Suite.runChild(Suite.java:24) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$3.run(ParentRunner.java:193) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$1.schedule(ParentRunner.java:52) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runChildren(ParentRunner.java:191) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.access$000(ParentRunner.java:42) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$2.evaluate(ParentRunner.java:184) at org.junit.internal.runners.statements.RunBefores.evaluate(RunBefores.java:28) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.run(ParentRunner.java:236) at org.junit.runners.Suite.runChild(Suite.java:128) at org.junit.runners.Suite.runChild(Suite.java:24) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$3.run(ParentRunner.java:193) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$1.schedule(ParentRunner.java:52) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runChildren(ParentRunner.java:191) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.access$000(ParentRunner.java:42) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$2.evaluate(ParentRunner.java:184) at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.run(ParentRunner.java:236) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit4.runner.JUnit4TestReference.run(JUnit4TestReference.java:50) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.TestExecution.run(TestExecution.java:38) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:467) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:683) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:390) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:197)

It looks like this might be a test suite bug. From Postman REST client, I did a GET followed by a PUT with an If-Unmodified-Since header, copying in exactly what the provider gave me. It succeeded.
The test suite is supposed to do the same. It should copy the Last-Modified value and put it in the If-Unmodified-Since header to test PUT. Here is the method to look at:
org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.CreationAndUpdateBaseTests.createResourceAndUpdateIt(String, String, String, String)
The RIO-CM check is at:
org.eclipse.lyo.rio.services.RioBaseService.checkConditionalHeaders(HttpServletRequest, OslcResource)
Nothing jumps out at me scanning the code. I think we'll need to run this under a debugger to see what's happening.
Feng, do you mind taking a look?

According to the HTTP 1.1 spec, the all datestamps should also be in GMT.
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec3.html
The RIO-CM implementation Last-Modified header isn't in GMT. This might be a second bug.
Created attachment 236727 Working PUT request in Postman REST client

bug.short_desc: Fix application/xml as a supported media type in the trs reference app

long_desc.thetext:
Bug 396890 "Allow finer grained registration of Producers and Consumers" changed the behaviour that the TRS reference application was implicitly relying on to produce application/xml.
A potential fix here is just to remove application/xml from the content type that the ref app can produce.
The other would be to add OslcXmlProvider to the list of registered providers for wink to use.
Unless anyone feels otherwise, we'll remove the application/xml as a content type from the app.
+1 to removing application/xml. That is really a holdover from oslc 1.0
+1 to removing application/xml. That is really a holdover from oslc 1.0

In chatting with Kevin, he brings up some good points on keeping the application/xml media type
1. Browsing the endpoint with Chrome, Firefox and Safari, those browsers know how to render the application/xml MIME type 2. Other applications built on lyo are using application/xml and the compact xml rendering previously returned.
I've tested adding org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcXmlProvider to the list of providers while keeping application/xml and it looks like it is producing compact xml.
Mike, while this is consistent with the previous behavior, I'm curious to how this happens as at first glance, OslcXmlProvider just extends OslcRdfXmlProvider. Is there some other way the provider is configured based on the mediatype?

I'll fix this by getting the previous application/xml behavior back via adding in the new XmlProviders into the providers file (new providers created in the bug referred in post 1)
I'll also add text/turtle support in a similar fashion.
Base and TRS endpoints will be updated to support turtle and references to the OslcMediaType files.

bug.short_desc: Remove OAuth code from the default adaptor template

long_desc.thetext: It does not work out of the box and requires twice as much POM dependencies, which complicates the tutorial.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/96087
We should have an alternative.
Note that the OAuth code in org.eclipse.lyo.sample.server used in the generated code does work.
Okay, let Jad decide :) We need to either merge it or abandon it before continuing.
I have no strong argument for keeping Oauth code (or at least I don't recall). So IF the suggestion is to remove it, go ahead. Should I review the code?

If the oauth code is removed from the codegenerator, is there an easy way for developers to put it back? I depend on this oauth code, as will anyone else using OSLC4J, to add friend connections between my OSLC server and the jazz.net apps. The oauth code in org.eclipse.lyo.server is used to authenticate the connections between servers when creating the consumer/friend relationship. This also requires use of the jazz rootservices document to provide the entry point for OSLC discovery.
What ever is in the current codegenerator is working fine re: oauth and I would hate to see this removed.

We can surround the 2 lines of code (that are to be removed in the suggested change) in the "protected area", plus a TODO comment instructing developer on what to do to enable/disable oauth. (plus tips on what to include in the pom.xml file for oauth)

Main reasons for removal:
* does not work out of the box (Jim, please give instructions on how to make it work if you think otherwise) * requires extra maven deps * throws unclear exceptions at runtime if you fail to do the prev step instead of crashing
But if it works, we can fix it in two ways:
* Add a tutorial on OAuth. Maybe Jim can start with adding just a few lines to the OAuth repo README and we can take it from there. * Throw a much more clear exception or stop registering OAuth classes by dynamic classloading (Class.forName()) to make sure the project fails to compile if the maven dependency is missing.

A tutorial on OAuth would be a great start.
I can then fix the adaptors to be generated based on that information.
Jim, an OAuth tutorial and working sample would also be a very good way for us to do some rudimentary acceptance testing during the release process.

bug.short_desc: Failing JUnit: testAllowedValuesResourceShape

long_desc.thetext: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.AllTests org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.TestCoreResourceShapes testAllowedValuesResourceShape(org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.TestCoreResourceShapes) junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: null at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47) at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:20) at junit.framework.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:27) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.TestCoreResourceShapes.verifyResourceShape(TestCoreResourceShapes.java:185) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.TestCoreResourceShapes.testResourceShape(TestCoreResourceShapes.java:158) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.test.test.TestCoreResourceShapes.testAllowedValuesResourceShape(TestCoreResourceShapes.java:43)

I don't think there is a way to fix this unless we give providers a generic way to add dynamic, extended properties to shapes. The AllowedValues resource was updated to use extended properties so it can handle any value type instead of just string. This means the allowedValue property is no longer appearing the shape, and the JUnit fails.
I think it is more important to allow any type for allowed values than to have a proper shape for the AllowedValues resource, which is well-defined in the OSLC Core spec anyway.
We might consider allowing dynamic shapes in the future.

- /* List of secure socket protocols. Note: TLSv1.2 is supported from Java 7, SSL_TLS is specific for the IBM JVMs */ - private static final String SECURE_SOCKET_PROTOCOL [] = new String[] {"TLSv1.2","TLS","SSL","SSL_TLS"}; //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$ + private static final String SECURE_SOCKET_PROTOCOL [] = new String[] {"TLS","SSL","SSL_TLS"}; //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$

bug.short_desc: Migrate Lyo to Java 8

long_desc.thetext: Migrate SDK to Java 8. This necessarily includes migrating to the most recent compatible versions of supporting tools such as Maven, Antlr, etc.

(In reply to Jim Ruehlin from comment #0) > Migrate SDK to Java 8. This necessarily includes migrating to the most > recent compatible versions of supporting tools such as Maven, Antlr, etc.
Does this bug really necessarily require migrating to the most recent compatible versions of all supporting tools? Isn't it sufficient to do only changes which are necessary for build and run under Java 8? I see upgrading the dependencies to supporting tools as optional.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/52954

(In reply to Joachim Engelhardt from comment #1) > (In reply to Jim Ruehlin from comment #0) > Does this bug really necessarily require migrating to the most recent > compatible versions of all supporting tools? Isn't it sufficient to do only > changes which are necessary for build and run under Java 8? I see upgrading > the dependencies to supporting tools as optional.
Thanks Joachim, I'll try and take a look at this in the next day or two. I added fiedler.mf@gmail.com as a reviewer because he's a committer.
We may need to upgrade associated tools (for example Antlr) if they are incompatible with Java 8 on any platform. After moving to Java 8, we should be able install a fresh environment with no more issues than we have now using this information: https://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo#Building_and_running_the_code.

(In reply to Jim Ruehlin from comment #17) > joachim.mobile@gmail.com, I reviewed the changes (had to -1 one of the > change sets due to build errors). > > Could you provide a brief description here of the required/minimum settings > and products, based on your changes? I thought it would be useful to have > that in one place. E.g. > Java - min: 1.6, validated on 1.8 > Antlr - 3.5.2 > ... etc > > Also, please add any settings that might need to be changed in someone's > configuration so we can post that in the environment section. E.g. if one of > the projects must be run at a particular compiler version. > > Thanks
joachim.mobile@gmail.com, could you take a look at the Gerrit change sets that were not accepted and update them so they build? After the last of your changes are committed, then I think we can close this item.

joachim.mobile@gmail.com, I tested your changes with Java8 in a clean install and OSLC4J compiled and the tests ran. However, I didn't upgrade my version of Antlr - I'm still at 3.2. So I was wondering what you got Antlr3 running with Java8. I just want to make sure I'm not missing anything.

Sorry for the delay. I'm quite busy with other projects.
(In reply to Jim Ruehlin from comment #22) > joachim.mobile@gmail.com, I tested your changes with Java8 in a clean > install and OSLC4J compiled and the tests ran. However, I didn't upgrade my > version of Antlr - I'm still at 3.2. So I was wondering what you got Antlr3 > running with Java8. I just want to make sure I'm not missing anything.
The project builds well with JDK 1.6 as before the changes. The changes I made make the project also build successfully with JDK 1.8. If you will build it with a JDK 1.8 compiler, you will need the update of Antlr, even if you compile it with 1.6 compliance.

I noticed, that you already built it using Java8. Then, I don't know, how it works with the older Antlr version. Unfortunately, I am currently not able to run the tests with Antlr 3.2 again. So, if you get it run with Antlr 3.2 configured in the pom and using a JDK 1.8 compiler, then this Antlr version should also be sufficient and can reverted to 3.2.

I re-checked some things in my environment (details below) and my conclusion is that we should close this item as complete. We also need to update our instructions for building and running OSLC4J (https://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildingOSLC4J) to explain that Antlr 3.5 is required for Java 1.8, and 3.2 is required for earlier versions of Java.
It turns out I had Antlr 3.5 installed, not 3.2. The plugins listed by Eclipse were named 3.2.xxx so I assumed that was the Antlr version. But the Maven Install output verified that Antlr 3.5.2 was being used. So my test validated the new stuff runs under Antlr 3.5 and Java 1.8.
It looks like lyo.core.query and ninacrm are the only components that require Antlr. They are not considered part of the required OSLC4J packages. So it looks like Antlr is a non-issue with the required packages.
We can't have it both ways and run Antlr 3.2 with Java 8, or run Antlr 3.5 with earlier versions of Java. So my thinking is that we should move forward by resolving this item and documenting the constraint in the OSLC4J build instructions, particularly since Antlr does not affect the required components of OSLC4J.
If no one has issues with that approach we can complete this item and I will update be build instructions.

We should investigate why Antlr 3.2 won't compile with Java8 and/or why Antlr 3.5 won't compile with earlier Java versions. This could be raised as a defect in Antlr and an update could resolve the issue for us.
In any case, updating the version of Antlr will require a new CQ, and it may not pass if it requires Java8.
Validated under Java 1.8 with Antlr 3.5. Lyo prerequisites page updated to reflect Java 1.8 dependency and Antlr restrictions - see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/prereqs. Resolving this item.
Also, the CQ has been approved for Antlr 3.5 with Lyo.
*** Bug 463324 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Builds under JDK 1.8 on multiple platforms.
Also see Bug 460377 - OSLC4J SDK does not build under Java 8 (partially a duplicate)
