bug.short_desc: Pagination in the Lyo Designer Generated does not work

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 273891 Pagination Issue
The pagination generated in the standard web client of Lyo Designer isn't working as expected. The URL changes but the entries don't.
I'm attaching an image to exemplify the problem:
The image shows the start page of a query capability. When I click on "Next Page", the URL changes but the number of elements and the elements itself don't.

I still cannot reproduce. Are you sure the actual user-code that is meant to be returning the query result making use of the "page" query parameter? For reference, have a look at the adaptor-rm-webapp project under https://github.com/OSLC/lyo-adaptor-sample-modelling.git In the class com.sample.rm.services.ServiceProviderService1, method queryRequirementsAsHtml, you can see that we set the attribute "nextPageUri" httpServletRequest.setAttribute("nextPageUri", uriInfo.getAbsolutePath().toString() + "?oslc.paging=true&page=" + (page + 1)); This is in turn being used in "/com/sample/rm/requirementscollection.jsp" to create the link for the next set of entries. <% if (nextPageUri != null) { %>Next Page<% } %> Which in turn is being handled by @QueryParam("page") in the method queryRequirementsAsHtml().

Got it working!
It was lacking implementation, sorry about that.
But I think that it is important to report here that it was a little bit tricky to implement it since the sample application (adaptor-rm-webapp project under https://github.com/OSLC/lyo-adaptor-sample-modelling.git) doesn't implement pagination.
For further references, to implement pagination correctly, you have to always return the pagination limit + 1 resources in the query result methods. It will trigger the next page elements and the generated code was developed to remove the extra resource.

(I see that the bug is closed, but I did not think we are done).
Hi Fabio,
It has been a while since I had a look at this code, and always good with fresh eyes looking at the generated code.
If you are working with this, and can suggest a more generic template that does not require this strange "+1" expectation, please share and I will update the generator accordningly.
+1 convention is really popular in SQL/SPARQL queries but is indeed strange in Java code. Returning a LyoResult instance is the only clean (but breaking) way I can think of to fix this.

bug.short_desc: Many warnings from org.apache.wink.common.internal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector about the classes in org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena

long_desc.thetext:
we started to see bunch of warnings from org.apache.wink.common.internal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector about the classes in org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena:
Even though this warnings may be harmless, it does cloud the log file. Anything can be done here to remove the warning?
WARN ternal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector - The @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider annotation was found on the superclass or interface class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider of the class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcTurtleCollectionProvider class. Annotate @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider on the provider class directly to ensure portability between environments. 11:40:27,911 [1315851879@qtp-766989675-14 @@ 11:40 ] WARN ternal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector - The @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider annotation was found on the superclass or interface class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider of the class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcTurtleCollectionProvider class. Annotate @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider on the provider class directly to ensure portability between environments. 11:40:27,912 [1315851879@qtp-766989675-14 @@ 11:40 ] WARN ternal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector - The @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider annotation was found on the superclass or interface class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider of the class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcTurtleCollectionProvider class. Annotate @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider on the provider class directly to ensure portability between environments. 11:40:27,914 [1315851879@qtp-766989675-14 @@ 11:40 ] WARN ternal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector - The @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider annotation was found on the superclass or interface class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider of the class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcTurtleCollectionProvider class. Annotate @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider on the provider class directly to ensure portability between environments. 11:40:27,915 [1315851879@qtp-766989675-14 @@ 11:40 ] WARN ternal.registry.metadata.ProviderMetadataCollector - The @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider annotation was found on the superclass or interface class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcRdfXmlCollectionProvider of the class org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.OslcTurtleCollectionProvider class. Annotate @javax.ws.rs.ext.Provider on the provider class directly to ensure portability between environments.

According to http://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/jcp/jaxrs-2_1-pr-spec/jaxrs-2_1-pr-spec.pdf 3.6 p.19,
JAX-RS annotations MAY be used on the methods and method parameters of a super-class or an implemented interface. Such annotations are inherited by a corresponding sub-class or implementation class method provided that method and its parameters do not have any JAX-RS annotations of its own. Annotations on a super-class take precedence over those on an implemented interface. If a subclass or implementation method has any JAX-RS annotations then all of the annotations on the super class or interface method are ignored. E.g.:
So any JAX-RS implementation should allow annotation inheritance. I would say this issue is wontfix until we make a move from Wink to Jersey (hope it to be the least painful move compared to other frameworks like Spring Boot).
BUT as we are not planning a move from Wink anytime soon, I am submitting a patch for this.

bug.short_desc: Problem when setting a public url with an "_"

long_desc.thetext:
When we pass a public url containing an "_" the oslc4j displays it wrong. Ex
public url = http://testing_hostname.ibm.com:12357 the oslc4j displays = http:/testing_hostname.ibm.com:12357
The problem passes by the method resolveURI on the OSLC4JUtils class. The URI builder fails to parse the URL with the "_" character
I can reproduce and have a JUnit for it now. I'll take a look.

Looks like this is not a valid character for a hostname.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname#Restrictions_on_valid_host_names
"The Internet standards (Request for Comments) for protocols mandate that component hostname labels may contain only the ASCII letters 'a' through 'z' (in a case-insensitive manner), the digits '0' through '9', and the hyphen ('-')."
Closing as invalid.

bug.short_desc: Password Autocomplete in Browse for authentication pop-up

long_desc.thetext:
Description
The AUTOCOMPLETE attribute is not disabled on an HTML FORM/INPUT element containing password type input. Password may be stored in browsers and retrieved.
Background
Browsers will sometimes ask a user if they wish to remember the password that they just entered. The browser will then store the password, and automatically enter it whenever the same authentication form is visited. This is a convenience for the user. Additionally, some websites will offer custom remember me functionality to allow users to persist log ins on a specific client system.
Having the browser store passwords is not only a convenience for end users, but also for an attacker. If an attacker can gain access to the victim's browser (e.g. through a Cross Site Scripting attack, or through a shared computer), then that can retrieve the stored passwords. It is not uncommon for browsers to store these passwords in an easily retrievable manner, but even if the browser were to store the passwords encrypted and only retrievable through the use of a master password, an attacker could retrieve the password by visiting the target web application's authentication form, entering the victim's username, and letting the browser to enter the password.
Remediation
To prevent browsers from storing credentials entered into HTML forms, include the attribute autocomplete="off" within the FORM tag (to protect all form fields) or within the relevant INPUT tags (to protect specific individual fields).
Please note that modern web browsers may ignore this directive. In spite of this there is a chance that not disabling autocomplete may cause problems obtaining PCI compliance.
occurrences identified to be fixed in following URLs 1. /iotp/services/oauth/approveKey 2. /iotp/services/oauth/authorize

Note that MacOS uses Keychain to manage these passwords in Safari. Not sure if this solves the problem in this case, but it might provide another way of protecting users.
User already have the ability to turn autocomplete off in their browser preferences. Is this sufficient? Seems like users should have the ability to assess their security needs and determine if they need additional protections by using firewalls, SSL, things like Keychain, turning autocomplete off and not having any master password in their browser, etc.
Is there any reason eclipse/Lyo needs to provide additional protection?
By the way, should these issues be submitted to GitHub from now on?
This has been filed in GitHub now by Jim: https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.server/issues/13
I am erring towards a wontfix. Please see the Github reply.

Hi Andrew, I got the following comments from IBM security team: it is determined that our supported browsers ignore the autocomplete setting for login settings. Our products are not intended for PCI compliant applications. However, we still feel that Lyo should add this setting to the login fields so that scanners do not complain. As a fix, there should be no actual change in the user experience of using autocomplete or not.
From my point of view, I see there no harms of changing the autocomplete='off' and seems very small change. If you agree on this I would certainly submit a pull request for these changes.

Rahul,
Thank you for being ready to submit a patch. That said, I believe autocomplete=off is actually harmful for security. I believe that the chance at least one of the web applications (where I hold an account) will get compromised (hacked, that is) is 99,999% (dream uptime figure, right?). Therefore, I use a password manager and generate a unique password per website and fill it in automatically. autocomplete=off is supposed to tell the browser not to "remember" the password, because the webpage is too "important". You see the differences in the security models I have and website operators frequently do. Therefore, I think that by discouraging users from generating long random passwords by imposing the restrictions of this HTML attribute, we actually force users to reuse passwords (you can only make up as many passwords...). Please read my reply on GH for further information.
If you want to show the secteam something, though, please point them to https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Vulnerable_Remember_Password_(OTG-AUTHN-005) "Since early 2014 most major browsers will override any use of autocomplete="off" with regards to password forms and as a result previous checks for this are not required and recommendations should not commonly be given for disabling this feature."

bug.short_desc: Allow relative URIs in serializations

long_desc.thetext: This will be assigned to David Terry when he gets his bugz ID

Jena cannot serialize or de-serialize models with relative URIs to XML. Turtle works fine, but XML without an xmlns:base or an explicit base passed on the Model read/write methods is prohibited.
I am making an update to the changes at https://git.eclipse.org/r/10344 to set the default behavior to off. We will also document that pure relative URIs are only allowed if the serialization is Turtle.
Additionally, running the OSLC4JTestTest JUnits is only supported if the relative URI behavior is set to false.

bug.short_desc: Catch ARQException

long_desc.thetext:
Jena declared it as a RuntimeException https://jena.apache.org/documentation/javadoc/arq/org/apache/jena/sparql/ARQException.html
Therefore, the caller does not see an error when the call is made to a method that throws ARQException and that exception is not handled.
When we work with Jena, we expect it to throw errors, we need to make them explicit the best option we have is to rethrow a Lyo Store exception that needs to be handled and will make this exception explicit.
This is what I got recently:
com.hp.hpl.jena.sparql.ARQException: Null endpoint for remote update at com.hp.hpl.jena.sparql.modify.UpdateProcessRemote.execute(UpdateProcessRemote.java:68) at org.eclipse.lyo.tools.store.internals.SparqlStoreImpl.removeAll(SparqlStoreImpl.java:296)
I agree that we need make stricter check of the arguments but we need to prepare the developer to runtime exceptions that should be expected and handled (malformed SPARQL, 5xx server codes etc.)

Just got another one:
org.apache.jena.atlas.web.HttpException: 415 - Unsupported Media Type at org.apache.jena.riot.web.HttpOp.exec(HttpOp.java:1118) at org.apache.jena.riot.web.HttpOp.execHttpPost(HttpOp.java:727) at org.apache.jena.riot.web.HttpOp.execHttpPost(HttpOp.java:555) at org.apache.jena.riot.web.HttpOp.execHttpPost(HttpOp.java:525) at com.hp.hpl.jena.sparql.modify.UpdateProcessRemote.execute(UpdateProcessRemote.java:81) at org.eclipse.lyo.tools.store.internals.SparqlStoreImpl.removeAll(SparqlStoreImpl.java:296)
BTW, the bug was very silly: I mixed up the SPARQL Query & Update endpoints.
So not a Lyo bug really. Better error handling would have been better but not a prio now.

bug.short_desc: Make root URI configurable

long_desc.thetext: Currently hardcoded in spots

Now accepts ldp.rooturi property to control the base part of the uri, such as http://host:port/app which defaults to http://localhost:8080/ldp
I didn't fix the visualization app which sets the default to be localhost. I think may be better suited to provide a clean solution, mine was clunky and not quite working.

bug.short_desc: Lyo sample adapter does not honor if the request has been canceled

long_desc.thetext:
Test automation adapter while executing the automation is supposed to poll at rqm_qm:stateUrl URL which is basically state of the automation request It keeps adapter's hearbeat updated even while adapter is busy with execution and it also helps adapter to take action if user has canceled execution of the request.
This scenario missing from sample adapter will cause adapter writes to miss it as well.
Paul and Vaibhav - Let me know if this should be assigned to someone else.
Thanks Mike I'm glad to take this one.

bug.short_desc: Address a significant amount of deprecated methods

long_desc.thetext: Keeping OSLC4J current requires not only managing the dependencies, but also addressing deprecated methods that are currently being used. We can assume that these methods are not going to get any updates, bug fixes, performance improvements, may stop working, and may be removed. Periodically, possibly when updating dependencies for a significant release, we should also sweep the code to address references to deprecated methods.
Cleaning up "3.0.0" bugs.

bug.short_desc: As per OSLC specification for TRS 2.0, the type of the order property in the ChangeEvent must be xsd:integer, curretly it is xsd:int in SDK oslc-trs-2.3.0.jar

long_desc.thetext:
Overview: In order to support TRS for our product, we used oslc-trs-2.3.0.jar implementation. As per OSLC specification for TRS 2.0, the type of the order property in the ChangeEvent must be xsd:integer, curretly it is xsd:int. This requires a datatype change for "order" member in ChangeEvent class.
Actual Results: Following is snippet from a sample changeLog : ------------------------------------------------------------ <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:ldp="http://www.w3.org/ns/ldp#" xmlns:trs="http://open-services.net/ns/core/trs#" xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#" > <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://host:8080/Test/services/trs/changelog"> <trs:previous rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#nil"/> <trs:change rdf:resource="urn:urn-3:cm1.example.com:2018-02-23:05:05:55:c45bfadf-3937-4391-9249-860798056f38:1"/> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/core/trs#ChangeLog"/> </rdf:Description> <rdf:Description rdf:about="urn:urn-3:cm1.example.com:2018-02-23:05:05:55:c45bfadf-3937-4391-9249-860798056f38:1"> <trs:order rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#int">1</trs:order> <trs:changed rdf:resource="http://host:8080/Test/services/changeRequests/100001"/> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/core/trs#Modification"/> </rdf:Description> </rdf:RDF> ------------------------------------------------------------
Expected Results: Expected result sample can be referred from http://open-services.net/wiki/core/TrackedResourceSet-2.0/.
Additional Information: Changing datatype of "order" member in ChangeEvent class to BigInteger can fix this issue.

Thanks for the report, Vaishali.
I know that 'xsd:integer' is the type supported by the spec. However, we are using Java 'Integer' types in Lyo, which corresponds to an 'xsd:int'. Switching to an 'xsd:integer' might require a switch to a 'BigInteger'.
Even if a patch for this core change is contributed, I think we will have to think of backwards compat; this might require using https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/math/BigInteger.html#intValueExact-- in Lyo to still return 'Integer/int' values to the callers instead of 'BigInteger's unless the datatype under the annotation is a 'BigInteger'.

From: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15336872/xsd-what-is-the-difference-between-xsinteger-and-xsint:
The xs:integer type is a restriction of xs:decimal, with the fractionDigits facet set to zero and with a lexical space which forbids the decimal point and trailing zeroes which would otherwise be legal. It has no minimum or maximum value, though implementations running in machines of finite size are not required to be able to accept arbitrarily large or small values. (They are required to support values with 16 decimal digits.)
The xs:int type is a restriction of xs:long, with the maxInclusive facet set to 2147483647 and the minInclusive facet to -2147483648. (As you can see, it will fit conveniently into a two-complement 32-bit signed-integer field; xs:long fits in a 64-bit signed-integer field.)
The usual rule is: use the one that matches what you want to say. If the constraint on an element or attribute is that its value must be an integer, xs:integer says that concisely. If the constraint is that the value must be an integer that can be expressed with at most 32 bits in twos-complement representation, use xs:int. (A secondary but sometimes important concern is whether your tool chain works better with one than with the other. For data that will live longer than your tool chain, it's wise to listen to the data first; for data that exists solely to feed the tool chain, and which will be of no interest if you change your tool chain, there's no reason not to listen to the tool chain.)
So as Andrew points out, simply changing the type from xsd:int to xsd:integer could create issues because it is saying that the RDF resource could have values that can't be loaded in a Java int - which is what's used in the current oslc-trs reference implementation. OSLC Core specifies support for xsd:integer, not xsd:int, so this is consistent with the TRS specification.
Since xsd:int will fit into an xsd:integer (but not the other way around), I suppose the oslc-trs implementation is conferment from the standpoint of compatibility. But the implementation is clearly incorrect. Order should probably be long (which isn't xsd:integer either) or BigDecimal.
The question is, will an RDF parser be unable to do something reasonable with xsd:int in other languages? Is this really a problem?

The difference between xsd:int and xsd:integer becomes more obvious when you use Turtle rather than RDF/XML (and why would any sane person not do so!)
In Turtle, a raw integer literal is of type xsd:integer - so a triple of this form:
[ trs:order 1 ]
specifies an object of type xsd:integer. If I use Lyo today, and translate the output to Turtle, I would get:
[ trs:order "1"^^xsd:int ]
which is not as readable.
The readability concern is comparatively minor. It is also possible that someone might write a TRS consumer that could not handle change events published by Leo-Based code with an xsd:int order value, though that seems unlikely.
More important might be what can be consumed using Lyo: does Lyo have any support for reading a TRS? If so, does it support reading a compliant feed with change events containing
[ trs:order 1 ] ?
If Lyo supports reading a TRS feed, but does not support xsd:integer when doing so, that would be a more serious defect.

Since a TRS resource is RDF, and OSLC4J includes a Java client that can be used to access RDF resources, then I suppose we can say eclipse/Lyo supports reading TRS resources. KTH has also developed a TRS client that more directly supports using TRS resources.
If any modern RDF parser is used, it seems unlikely that there will be a problem parsing xsd:int vs. xsd:integer for trs:order. If tools are using XML parsers or XPath, then that could result in some potential issues.
So although oslc-trs reference implementation is clearly incorrect, I'm not sure there's much practical impact.

FYI https://jena.apache.org/documentation/notes/typed-literals.html#xsd-data-types
I think we need to test. I am pretty sure Jena will throw an exception if we try to unmarshal a xsd:integer that fits only a 'long' into a Java 'int'.
But do we really want to support the BigInteger case for TRS then? We might have to declare the fields to hold a https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Number.html instead of an int.

bug.short_desc: Add file provider to the OAuth consumerstore project

long_desc.thetext:
The current Derby RDF provider in the oauth.consumerstore project breaks under Jena 2.9.x due to the use of the removed RDB factory methods.
To avoid breaking consumers who want to depend on Jena 2.7.x and to allow the default Lyo libraries to move to Jena 2.9.x, create a new consumerstore implementation which uses file storage instead of RDB storage.
The new provider still uses a Jena model to store the OAuth consumer information, but persists it to an xml file instead of a Derby DB.
Base64 encoding is used to obfuscate the consumer secret and the javadoc warns of this.
The Bugzilla samples and Labs will be updated to use the new consumerstore.

bug.short_desc: RdfXmlAbbreviatedWriter is not able to serialize a model with self-reference cycle

long_desc.thetext:
I am trying to serialize a collection of providers that has a self-reference (the subject of rdfs:Container is equal to the oslc:queryBase in a service provider). The output in abbreviated RDF XML should be:
<rdf:RDF> <rdfs:Container rdf:about = "http://server:9080/oslc/pr/collection"> <rdfs:member> <oslc:ServiceProvider rdf:about = "http://test:9999/inlineResources/self-circular.xml"> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <oslc:queryCapability> <oslc:QueryCapability> <oslc:queryBase rdf:resource = "http://server:9080/oslc/pr/collection"/> </oslc:QueryCapability> </oslc:queryCapability> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdfs:member> </rdfs:Container> </rdf:RDF>
This is example of code modeling the scenario:
ServiceProvider sp = new ServiceProvider(); sp.setAbout(URI.create("http://test:9999/inlineResources/self-circular.xml")); Service service = new Service(); sp.addService(service); QueryCapability queryCapability = new QueryCapability(); service.addQueryCapability(queryCapability); queryCapability.setQueryBase(URI.create("http://server/pr/collection")); List<ServiceProvider> list = new ArrayList<ServiceProvider>(1); list.add(sp);
ResponseInfoCollection<ServiceProvider> info = new ResponseInfoCollection<ServiceProvider>(list, null, 1,(String) null); info.getContainer().setAbout(URI.create("http://server/pr/collection"));
If try to serialize the ResponseInfo above, the output RDF does not contain the collection of providers (rdfs:Container):
<rdf:RDF> <oslc:ResponseInfo rdf:about = "http://server/pr/collection?oslc.select=*"> <oslc:totalCount>1</oslc:totalCount> </oslc:ResponseInfo> </rdf:RDF>
Looking at the source code of RdfXmlAbbreviatedWriter, it considers that any resource that is the object of other resource is not a root, and therefore it should not be serialized. But this is not correct for the case above, since it is a self-reference.
I have a tentative fix for the bug, so I'd like to have it assigned to me.
Changes committed at: https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/20072/
Commit has been merged. Thanks, Fabio!

bug.short_desc: Lyo::OSLC::RDF perl module fails find the identifier or title in the records returned from the server

long_desc.thetext:
Lyo::OSLC::RDF perl module fails find the identifier or title in the records returned from the server
The Lyo::OSLC::RDF perl module has methods to return a perl hash that is keyed on the title or identfier of the records that are returned from the server. The module use XML::Simple to convert the XML into an equivalent perl data structure. The logic to get the title and identifier from the perl data structure doesn't handle the different ways the title or identifier might be encoded into the perl structure based on the different record types that might be returned from the server.
For a work item the server returned this XML:
<rdf:Description rdf:about="https://URL/workitem"> <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal">It was broken</dcterms:title> </rdf:Description>
This converts into a perl structure like this:
{ 'dcterms:title' => { 'rdf:parseType' => 'Literal', 'content' => 'It was broken' }, }
So to retrieve the title you would use the syntax $record->{'dcterms:title'}->{'content'}.
But for a query that returned the states in the system we get this XML:
<rdf:Description rdf:about="https://URL/state.s2"> <dcterms:title>CLOSED</dcterms:title> </rdf:Description>
This converts into a perl structure like this:
{ 'dcterms:identifier' => 'state.s2', },
Notice that dcterms:title is no longer a reference to a hash but instead holds the actual title.
So instead to retrieve the title you would use the syntax $record->{'dcterms:title'}.
The Lyo::OSLC::RDF module needs to be updated to deal with both of these scenarios.
Created attachment 221269 Patch to fix the issue

Resolved by the following commit:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=dab0d6049539e56640d0d947fe176b39d7f1dd65

bug.short_desc: Inline resources can be defined using any tag name in the RDF/XML and they still will be unmarshalled to the "original" class instance (no error reported).

long_desc.thetext:
This is working as designed. This is part of the work done for OSLC unknown property support. OSLC providers and consumers must be prepared to handle unrecognized properties gracefully. OSLC does not strictly define the allowed attributes. Consumers and providers very commonly add additional attributes from their own namespaces.
It is critical that OSLC4J behave the way you describe
See the changes for Bug 374125 here: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=cc4e0cb04d7a826e62dc41db97c0c8813378bac9

bug.short_desc: ChangeRequest_Selector.jsp JSON response is missing the "oslc-response:" text string within the select method

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: Version: Indigo Release Build id: 20110615-0604
Within the latest RIO github codebase, the CM RIO file "changerequest_selector.jsp" contains a bug within its select function definition. Specifically, the variable for the oslcResponse is missing a parent tag for "oslc-response:".
Current: var oslcResponse = '{ "oslc:results": [ ' + ' { "oslc:label":"' + option.text + '", "rdf:resource":"' + option.value + '"} ' + ' ]}';
Suggested: var oslcResponse = 'oslc-response:{ "oslc:results": [ ' + ' { "oslc:label":"' + option.text + '", "rdf:resource":"' + option.value + '"} ' + ' ]}';
Without this fix, the selector dialog does not appropriately notify the parent consuming window about the data for the selection. The tutorial and workshop materials all indicate this tag, however the RIO code seems to be missing it.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Follow the workshop steps and attempt to associate the CM RIO with RTC 2. Utilize the selection dialog and attempt to hit the OK button. 3. Validate that nothing occurs within the RTC parent window.

bug.short_desc: Introduce some kind of Scala's Either class support

long_desc.thetext:
Problem -------
You define a Service with a Query cap in Lyo Designer and generate the code. Two methods (actually more, but ignore that) will be generated:
public Blabla[] queryBlablas() in the BlablaService, and public static List<Blabla> queryBlablas in BlablAdaptorManager.
Suppose the request has failed and I want to return OSLC Error resource instance. Returning new org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.Error() results in a compilation error (due to type mismatch).
Background ----------
The true nature of the problem is that in Java type system the top and bottom elements (more on that in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order) ). In plain English, every class in Java is a subclass of Object but also 'null' is a "subclass" of every class. What we need is so that every Lyo Resource class is a subclass of IResource but Lyo Error class should be a subclass of every Lyo Resource class (that's hard).
Solutions ---------
Scala has Either[E,T] class with two subclasses: Left[E] and Right[T] (pun intended the "right" answer and the rest). In this case, E stands for a generic type qualifier for an error type and T for the value type Q. Here is an implementation in Java: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9975836/how-can-i-simulate-haskells-either-a-b-in-java
Then we can have these simple signatures:
public IResource[] queryBlablas() in the BlablaService, and public static Either<Error, List<Blabla>> queryBlablas in BlablAdaptorManager
This way we can return values via static methods eg Either.ok(List...) or Either.error(new Error). The trouble lies in the definition of the OSLC Error class:
@OslcNamespace(OslcConstants.OSLC_CORE_NAMESPACE) @OslcResourceShape(title = "OSLC Error Resource Shape", describes = OslcConstants.TYPE_ERROR) public class Error {
If we don't want to work around and fix it (by having Error class implement IResource), we can do the following:
public Object queryBlablas() in the BlablaService, and public static OslcEither<List<Blabla>> queryBlablas in BlablAdaptorManager
OslcEither will have methods:
static OslcError error(Error e) static <T> OslcSuccess success(T value)
where
OslcError extends OslcEither<T>
Error getError()
OslcSuccess<T> extends OslcEither<T>
T getValue()
Proposal --------
1. Evaluate wgy Error class implement IResource. 2. Define simplification of the Either type (OslcEither, OslcError, OslcSuccess). 3. Replace AbstractResource with IResource wherever possible in the code generator.
This will allow to avoid throwing Exceptions and allow clear error handling in the generated Service code, while giving full control over error handling to the developers (not sure if that will include all of the recently voted Query spec changes).

bug.short_desc: Jazz auth login does not work with Jazz Authenticator Server and OIDC in CLM 6.x

long_desc.thetext:
The Jazz Form Auth Client does not authenticate with any CLM product in version 6.0 if a JAS is being used to support OIDC (for SSO). JazzFormAuthClient.java does not understand the "JAS OIDC Dance" and cannot authenticate.
A fix would allow users of the JazzFormAuthClient to continue to authenticate with CLM by providing a username/password.
Fix: The JAS for CLM 6.0 is n-1 compatible. Basic auth was used in CLM 5.0, so JAS for 6.x must support that as well. It's acceptable to use Basic auth if JazzFormAuthClient detects a JAS server that supports OIDC. Note that this does NOT provide OIDC support for JazzFormAuthClient. We are only making use of the support for Basic auth, which may be deprecated in future major releases of CLM.
Note that the JAR files on the Eclipse download page should be updated to include this fix as well. https://eclipse.org/lyo/download.php
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/82681
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/82681 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=b46b121b428285d8a4067bf0d3e46d61cd12855f

bug.short_desc: Cannot add custom properties to ResponseInfo

long_desc.thetext: We need to add custom properties to the ResponseInfo resource that is included in paged responses to requests that retrieve multiple resources. Currently this is not possible, as ResponseInfo is not an AbstractResource. Is there any particular reason for the FilteredResource (extended by ResponseInfo) class not to extend AbstractResource? If it did, we could simply add our custom properties as extended properties.
Unfortunately, just extending AbstractResource does not fix things since the FilteredResource object itself is not passed to JenaModelHelper.
Hi Sam. When are you planning to fix this one? Any change we could get it by 7/22? Thanks.

Sam, we can contribute a solution for this. You mentioned that the FilteredResource object itself is not passed to JenaModelHelper, but why can't we do that? Instead of passing around parameters such as responseInfoURI, nextPageURI and totalCount, wouldn't it be simpler to pass a ResponseInfo object instead? If we do that and make FilteredResource extend AbstractResource, we would have extended properties available in JenaModelHelper. Thoughts? Meanwhile we will prototype such solution.

Hi, Francisco. Yes, we're thinking the same thing :) Please go ahead and try it out.
You'll need to sign a CLA to submit a change.
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/Contributing_via_Git#Eclipse_Foundation_Contributor_License_Agreement
Thanks!

bug.short_desc: Align tools versioning with the rest of the project

long_desc.thetext: Do you think it's a good idea to keep the Lyo Modelling Tools and Lyo Core in version sync? Or it will be a pain for the releng?

There's two parts to that question - the generators and what they generate. If the generated results stand alone in most deployments then the generators and generated results can be versioned separately from OSLC4J. But if end users combine generated coded with hand crafted code, then it might be better to have at least the generated output release aligned with OSLC4J.

End users (as in developers) do need to add hand-crafted code to the generated code. But the generated code is so far not so dependent on the version of OSLC4J being used, so I am not sure why we need to tie the versions together.
Also note that: * OSLC4J is a set of maven libraries, while the generators are Eclipse Plugins. * Currently the generator projects are distrivuted across Core & Tools repositories. but ultimately, we said we should put all generator code under Tools.
This somehow tells me that we don't need to tie the versions of these 2 different things together. I believe this can also simplify our release process. "major releases" of the generator are not necessarily in synch with major releases of OSLC4J.

Refactoring the code generator into its own repository (not necessarily generic tools) is a good idea no matter what its relationship is to OSLC4J.
What is the code generator's dependence on OSLC4J? Does it use the client and server SDK in the generated code? If so, then there would seem to be some at least potential version dependency. If not, why not and what are the implications for eclipse/Lyo and the OSLC4J SDK?

A summary from an email thread on lyo-dev@eclipse.org:
Jad El-Khoury said: If we take the BugzillaAdaptor as an example (from the org.eclipse.lyo.docs repository), the generator produces all java classes and jsp pages for that projects. All, except for the actual code that communicates with Bugzilla (Calls using com.j2bugzilla.base. BugzillaConnector). That is, (a) the OSLC-Resource classes, extending AbstractResource, (b) the JAX-RS classes that handle the REST services, (b) the main OslcWinkApplication, etc.
The generated code is completely reliant on OSLC4J libraries, and hence depends Wink as well.
Jim Amsden said: Jad, that's exactly what I thought, thanks for the great summary. So although the code generator itself is an eclipse plugin and does not directly use OSLC4J or Wink in its implementation, the code it produces isn't an eclipse plugin, and does use OSLC4J and therefore Wink. So this at least produces an indirect version dependency between the code generator and OSLC4J/Wink through the code it generates.
So it seems reasonable to consider version alignment between the code generator and OSLC4J.
Jad Said: True. And, thats because the generated project (BugzillaAdaptor again as an example) is directly dependent on Wink. We create a WinkApplication.
But, if you consider other (big) changes to OSLC4J such as migrating from Jena2 to Jena3, which will require a change to the OSLC4J version. Such a change is not necessarily visible to the generator, and hence may not necessitate a change in the generator version.

I would suggest a Gedankenexperiment: say we update Lyo to use Jena 3 in Lyo 2.2.0. The generator will break, right?
On the other hand, I would suggest asking if we can keep the versioning separate as it is not convenient to combine those releases. We can say Lyo Generator 1.5 supports Lyo Core 2.1.x. Not sure if this is the best idea.

The question then becomes how do we know if the code created by the generator is consistent with what version of OSLC4J? Keeping them versioned aligned would at least ensure a version of the generator is known to work with the same version of OSLC4J.

bug.short_desc: Testsuite assumes totalCount in ResponseInfo is untyped (value is a plain integer).

long_desc.thetext:
RQM's totalCount predicate in the ResponseInfo resource of a query result has an rdf:datatype attribute.
When Jena returns the value using stmt.getObject().toString(), it appends the type to the value in the usual RDF way. The resulting string looks like this:
"1^^http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#integer"
The test suite tries to do an Integer.parseInt on this and throws a runtime exception. I'm investigating the proper Jena API to use to return the value of totalCount.
Read the object of the statement as a Literal and then convert to integer. If the conversion fails, propagate the DatatypeFormatException.
Tested on QM and regression tested plain int object values using RTC

https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=e2507d09e848a0d0ca257fc17e8d80e7e155bd7d

Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=e2507d09e848a0d0ca257fc17e8d80e7e155bd7d

bug.short_desc: Do not add unique responseInfo URI if parameters do not contain an oslc query.

long_desc.thetext:
The responseInfo should only have a URI differing from the rest of the response if it alters the membership of the response. Since OSLC4J will support the OSLC query syntax, the responseInfo should only have its own URI if the parameters contain a valid OSLC query element.
This is still not perfect (implementers could use a different query syntax, or the query provided could have no effect on the result), but is a step forward.

bug.short_desc: Do not add ResponseInfo when there is not a nextPage

long_desc.thetext: ResponseInfo should not be added to non-paged responses or to the last page of a paged response. This is producing an incorrect response for non-paged queries, because two resources are being created with the same URI and the properties of both are mixed under a single resource. Particularly, we are seeing an oslc:ResponseInfo resource with rdfs:member properties; however, the rdfs:member properties should be under a separate container resource.
We can contribute the code to fix this bug. Please let me know this is OK.

Hi, Francisco. This might be a spec issue. (Adding Steve.)
The problem is that when no query parameters are put on the URL, the URI of the the response info resource and query capability subject resource are the same. Couldn't this be a problem even when there are multiple pages?
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecification?sortcol=table;up=#Resource_Paging
"The subject resource URI of the oslc:ResponseInfo resource representation will be the HTTP request URI, or URI from subsequent redirects."
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OSLCCoreSpecQuery?sortcol=table;up=#Graph_Patterns
"The starting subject resources used for pattern matching are determined by the the Query Capability. A Query Capability defines a starting subject resource, namely the base URI itself (see oslc:queryBase in the OSLC Core Specification - Query Capability). The result of the query is the set of all triples matched by the pattern, beginning the matching processing with the starting subject resource defined by the Query Capability."
Fixes are always welcome of course :)

I'm not sure why this is considered a bug. This is they way this scenario has worked. If the request URI and the container URI are the same, then it is correct that the member resources (rdfs:member) and data about the container (oslc:ResponseInfo, etc) have the same subject URI.
I'm not sure what this has to do with non-paged queries. If it is the last page, or not paged, it shouldn't be determined by the existence or last of existence of the rdf:type oslc:ResponseInfo, instead the client application should be looking for existence of triple with oslc:nextPage and/or oslc:totalCount.
In my opinion this is working as it should (mark as resolved-invalid). Changing the behavior in OSLC4J I'm not sure fixes any scenario. Clients should be written to handle these cases.
OK, I agree with the explanations above. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Lyo Designer should externalize strings to support translations

long_desc.thetext:
Strings in the generated code non-protected user code regions cannot be translated for production server implementations. Lyo Designer should externalize strings that would be displayed to a user so they can be translated. The current English values should be provided in a generated messages.properties resource.
Strings that are written to log files do not need to be translated. However, exceptions that are displayed in end-user dialogs do.
The generated resource preview and delegated dialogs do not need to be included since these are in protected code and will usually need to be changed for a production system anyway.

Let me remind you here that I promised long time ago to decouple the to*(HttpServletRequest r) methods from the POAROs (plain old AbstractResources :) but didn't have time for that. The motivation there was lack of customisations but also to allow producing POARO libraries that do not depend on the Servlet things (and can be used in a client w/o hacks).

If we exclude resource preview and delegated dialogs, what strings are left to externalize? I have viewed the (other) produced html pages as a debugging interface for a developer. Are you Jim envisaging another user of these pages?
But I can see the benefit of providing initially internationalized strings for resource preview and delegated dialogs (which developer can then override).
I'll get you a list

bug.short_desc: Test suite does not handle service URIs with query parameters

long_desc.thetext:
The test suite adds query parameters to service URIs (like query capabilities) by appending "?name=value" to the URI. This doesn't work if the service URI already has query parameters, however.
For instance, the Bugzilla adapter has a query URI like this.
http://localhost:8282/bugz/changerequests?productId=2
The test suite will try to run this query
http://localhost:8282/bugz/changerequests?productId=2?oslc.where=oslc_cm%3Astatus%3D%22NEW%22&oslc.select=oslc_cm%3Astatus
which is not correct.

I have a fix. See this pull request from github.
https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.testsuite/pull/1

Resolved by this commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=bbee50e7e47b59905836040c11fe30555ba1c4ca

bug.short_desc: Allowing duplicate oslcNames "type" for two different OslcPropertyDefinition values, currently it throws an exception if <rdf:type> and <dcterms:type> are used together

long_desc.thetext:
This looks correct to me. You are trying to define two properties with the same name in the same ResourceShape. This should raise an exception.
The @OslcNamespace for these two properties would be defined on the containing class. This would be two properties in the corresponding ResourceShape with the same name but using different property definitions. It doesnt matter what the namespace or name of the property definition is, its the two @OslcName annotations with the same name thats the problem.
<#Dialog> a oslc:ResourceShape ; dcterms:title "Describes information about a dialog such as its title and dimensions." ; oslc:describes oslc:Dialog ; oslc:property <#dcterms-title>, <#oslc-label>, <#oslc-label>, <#oslc-dialog>, <#oslc-hintWidth>, <#oslc-hintHeight>, <#oslc-resourceType>, <#oslc-resourceShape>, <#oslc-usage>.
represents the problem. oslc:Dialog can't have two #oslc-label properties, regardless of what the oslc:propertyDefinition of those two Properties might be.

bug.short_desc: oslc_am:Resource domain model is based on the draft AM 3.0 spec

long_desc.thetext:
The domain specification for Architecture Management resources in org.eclipse.lyo.tools.domainmodels is based on an early draft of the Architecture Management 3.0 specification (http://open-services.net/wiki/architecture-management/OSLC-Architecture-Management-Specification-Version-3.0/) which was never finalized or implemented. It should be based on the 2.0 specification (http://open-services.net/wiki/architecture-management/OSLC-Architecture-Management-Specification-Version-2.0/).
It is fine to include new properties from the 3.0 specification in the domain specification, but existing 2.0 properties cannot be renamed or removed, only deprecated. This preserves interoperability between OSLC 2.0 and 3.0 specifications and the integrations between tools that implement these specifications.

Many of the AM 3.0 specification changes are compatible with AM 2.0 except for the following: * identifier was zeroOrMany, now zeroOrOne in 3.0 * LinkType class is missing 3.0, replaced with dcterms:relation in 3.0
For now, the Lyo domain model for AM can stay at 3.0 since that represents the experience of the original spec developers. However, eventually this domain model should be updated to be consistent with the OASIS Architecture Management specification when it is produced. That will likely involve: 1. putting identifier back to zeroOrMany 2. adding back LinkType but marking it as archaic (deprecated) 3. retaining the new AM 3.0 properties since these don't introduce compatibility issues, and some are consistent with common properties added in OSLC Core 3.0.
In the mean time, the Occurs property for many of the Resource properties need to be updated to be consistent with the AM 3.0 draft spec.
Reschedule it from 2.2.0

bug.short_desc: Use more meaningful about URIs for TRS change events

long_desc.thetext:
Right now the TRS 2.0 reference application is using relative about URIs which cause problems for some TRS consumers. In addition these relative URIs lack any meaningful information about the change event.
We should change from using relative URIs to using meaningful URNs which contain timestamps. This will allow consumers a mechanism for more easily determining if they have encountered a given change set before. The timestamp portion will allow for a way to prune the change log of old events.
Dave, do you want to take this?

bug.short_desc: Incorrect value of the rdf:about field as response to query for change requests

long_desc.thetext:
When following the OSLC workshop (http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/OSLCWorkshop)instructions for lab 2, chapter 2.2 "Define OSLC services using JAX-RS", step 7 -- the result of a request: e.g. http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests with header set to Accept: application/rdf+xml the ResponseInfo has wrong rdf:about value -- see below:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <rdf:RDF> <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/1/changeRequests"> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests/9" /> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests/8" /> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests/7" /> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests/2" /> <oslc:totalCount>4</oslc:totalCount> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/core#ResponseInfo" /> </rdf:Description>
Should be: rdf:about="http://10.0.1.2:8080/OSLC4JBugzilla/services/1/changeRequests
Note: This does not affect the lab itself, hence not found. But when trying the GenericCMSample client, the code in OslcQueryResult that should return a list of URLs fail as the Selector memberResource URL is correct, but RDF model has the wrong URL as mentioned above.
public String[] getMembersUrls() { initializeRdf(); ArrayList<String> membersUrls = new ArrayList<String>(); Selector select = new SimpleSelector(membersResource, (Property) null, (RDFNode) null);
OSLC4JUtils.resolveUri() was not including the servletPath when it resolved the URI from the HttpServletRequest
Resolved by: https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=29c44aef66039f492c9f5d41d488ae3fc1069ba1

Hi all,

bug.short_desc: Wrong URI when requesting HTML representation of Bugzilla change request

long_desc.thetext:
In getHtmlChangeRequest() of BugzillaChangeRequestService.java, line 495, a new URI is created in order to add the "show_bug.cgi?id=" prefix and the new URI is then requested in order to return the HTML representation of the Bugzilla change request. However, a slash is missing in the new URI, resulting in a 404 error in response to the HTTP request.
The prefix should instead include a "/" like this "/show_bug.cgi?id=".

Actually, the slash should ideally be added to the bugzilla_uri as defined in org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.bugzilla/src/main/resources/bugz.properties
The online tutorial at http://open-services.net/resources/tutorials/integrating-products-with-oslc/running-the-examples/
shows this example: bugzilla_uri=https://landfill.bugzilla.org/bugzilla-4.2-branch
but it should be: bugzilla_uri=https://landfill.bugzilla.org/bugzilla-4.2-branch/

(In reply to Axel Reichwein from comment #1)
Thanks, Axel. I think we should accept either and just add the '/' if it's missing.

bug.short_desc: RIO provider query results are incorrect format.

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
The RIO providers were not passing the ChangeRequestRdfXmlTests due to the result rdfs:members occupying an rdf:Description section with an about referring to the query itself, not the query base URL
Please assign to Michael Fiedler
Reproducible: Always

Created attachment 205955 Update buildResponseResource to put query results in own element with correct about
I wrote all this code and have the rights to contribute it to Eclipse under the eclipse.org web site terms of use.
Commits for this bug make changes to the buiildResponseResource for all 3 RIOs. - put query result set in its own rdf:Description element with the proper about - add an oslc:totalCount to the query description section.
The CM RdfXML query tests pass now.

Getting null at end of URI for query URI.
For example when I use the queryBase URL without any oslc.where parameters such as:
GET http://localhost:8080/rio-cm/changerequest
I get a response that looks like:
<rdf:Description rdf:about="http://localhost:8080/rio-cm/changerequest?null">
Notice the extra trailing "?null". This is one of the rare cases where the query URI == the container URI, so all predicates fit under 1 subject URI.

The base RIO code was appending the ?null, so will fix that. But, the proposed patch still was not considering the queryBase case correctly, so will fix that as well.
In my jetty test env, I am also seeing the case where the first GET on the queryBase as a url parameter that we need to ignore...i.e. make sure there is really an OSLC query parameter.
e.g. http://localhost:8080/rio-cm/changerequest?url=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A8080%2Frio-cm%2Fchangerequest

Created attachment 205994 Additional updates to query parm handling
1) Don't add ?null to the queryUri when no parms exist 2) Put query predicates under the baseQuery subject when baseQuery used 3) handle case when all parameters are non-OSLC parameters

Committed http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.rio.git/commit/?id=1090e036e9cd839651127763d08a197029e38806 and http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.rio.git/commit/?id=cbe6129f53c06c080f1aa36f6b699a1d70e4a02f
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

attachment.desc: Update buildResponseResource to put query results in own element with correct about

bug.short_desc: Need more flexible means of specifying baseurl

long_desc.thetext:
It is sometimes useful to calculate the baseurl from information about other servers that might be integrated with a server generated by Lyo Designer.
The ServletListener.java class could support this by:
1. Including the following class attributes inside the user code class_attributes: private static final String DEFAULT_BASE = "http://localhost:8080"; private static final String PROPERTY_BASE = servletContextParameterName("baseurl");
This would allow developers to easily change the defaults for their installation
2. Put the body of the generateBasePath() method inside protected user code.
This will allow developers to provide other means of generating the baseurl.

Jim, did we have this discussion before? I think it's a dupe. But let's keep it until I track down the original bug.
Jad, what is the problem with overriding 'servlet.baseurl' context param in the container?
Jim, please see https://github.com/EricssonResearch/scott-eu/blob/b-lyo-trs-eval/lyo-sandbox/webapp-twin-shelf/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml#L11 for the way I use it.
Accidentally mentioned Jad. All questions are to Jim.
Please see an earlier bug report on this: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=525498

The reason that setting the defaults, or using the web.xml properties isn't always the best choice. If the War file is being deployed into a context with other related servers, we want to set the baseurl based on the initial request so that it is the same as the other already configured apps.
The proposed code is ok for the default values, but we also need the body of the generateBasePath() method inside protected user code so that this method can be overwritten to calculate the baseuri in a custom way - that doesn't involve the defaults or require users to edit web.xml files to deploy the server.

Sure, we can put the comment guard around the generateBasePath() body. Do you want to make a patch for it, Jim?
BTW, editing source is always more involved than editing web.xml. Most containers allow you to override those params & you can edit the web.xml by hand in the war file (I am sure there are tools for that).
This all applies unless you have some other source of config, the logic for which you want to put into that method. Now that I think about this, your proposed change will later help us to use https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/dns-pod-service/, eg via https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/environment-variable-expose-pod-information/ env vars.
Also see https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSEQTP_8.5.5/com.ibm.websphere.base.doc/ae/crun_app_upgrade.html

Let me explore calling call OSLC4JUtils.setPublicURI(...) from xManager.contextInitializeServletListener(). That would certainly be the preferred solution. Having the defaults be in protected use code in the servlet listener might still be useful.

Would the servlet listener generateBasePath overwrite what was set in the connection manager?
I'm beginning to think its better to do this in one place in the ServletListener class. Putting the generateBasePath() call in protected code so a different method could be called would be fine.
xManager.contextInitializeServletListener() Is called at the end of the contextInitialized() method in the Listener class. So it has the last word.

So basically we can ignore what's done in ServletListener, and do whatever we want in xConnectorManager.contextInitializeServletListener(), including lazily initializing the baseurl using OSLC4JUtils.setPublicURI()?
If so, I will test this and if it works, we can close this bug as works as designed.

Yes, please test, and tell us if it works.
But don't close.
Now that I put the effort to analyse the code, I would like to improve the comments (& code) in ServletListener, since it is not so obvious how all this works. I think the knowledge we have gained here could be useful to share.

bug.short_desc: Specification code generation does not produce code for imported domains

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 271036 the spec
Say we import the FOAF domain. We set (or don't) it's Java code generation properties. We create and use a reference property in another domain that points to one of its resources.
See the attached screenshots.
Created attachment 271037 the missing code generated

This is feature (not a bug) but I am sure we can improve it.
What is your though on the 2 alternatives below? (including the consequences of choosing alternative2, detailed also below).
The original idea is that the generation should ONLY generate classes for the resources defined WITHIN that specification model. if you import another specification model, the assumption is that the imported specification model is to be generated as a separate activity. (or maybe you have already generated it, and simply want to refer to it).
This is of course confusing to the end-user. Plus it is not consistent with the generation of a toochain/adaptor, where we generate for all specification models, even the ones that have been imported.
I see 2 alternatives:
1. Keep it as it is, where we do NOT generate classes for imported models. Instead, generate a README.TXT file (or a pom.xml) to explain to the developer that certain classes were not generated and need to be imported (as a maven dependency), or generated separatly.
2. Generate imported models as well. The classes will then be generated at the same destination folder as the main Specification model.
Spontaneously, it seems that alternative 2 is much better. The problem arises however if the end-user has already generated the imported model (into another destination folder), and they planned to simply add a maven depenedency to the imported model. So, it was not necessary to generate the imported model. Morover, the end-user ends up with the imported model generated twice.
To solve this new issue (If we go for alternative 2) I think we need to provide the user with an new "don't generate" check-box, where they can control whether a specificaiton is to be generated, or not.
Is this getting complicated for the user to have good control? Are there too many options to explain?

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J refers to J2SE1.5 but requires 1.6 compliance compilation

long_desc.thetext:
The OSLC4J Eclipse projects contains references to J2SE1.5. But several of the source files are using the @Override annotation for methods in classes implementing interfaces (e.g. not extending subclasses). That type of construction is only allowed in Java version 1.6 (and beyond), so one get a lot of compilation errors in Eclipse (and during the Maven Install procedure)
A remedy solution is simply to re-configure each project to use the 1.6 compiler compliance level.
One solution is to refer to JavaSE-1.6 as execution environment and let the compiler settings be detected and set when doing the m2eclipse command Maven Update Project Configuration.
The documentation needs to be updated as well to cleary describe that 1.6 is the target (even if it is quite possible to compile with 1.6 compiler compliance set and to generate 1.5 compatible bytecode - but that seems a bit too complicated and 1.5 somewhat outdated)

Updated the prereqs here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildingOSLC4J#Prerequisites
Testing new project .settings and .classpath now

Resolved by the following commits:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=7721f606223261d79b90e4f1e25b68b77a8b85d3
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.rio.git/commit/?id=d6b7b81252485f4717d19416741ad76d595b07c1

bug.short_desc: Adaptor generator case sensitve

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
We have been using the Adaptor Code Generator in order to support the OSLC specification for our Requirements Management tool (using the 2.0 specification). We have created a resource called Requirements and then generated the code, but this code generates the resource requirement (lower case). As far as I understand RDF is case sensitive so my question is, is this a bug? This happens also when generating foaf:person resources, that are generated with lower case (instead of foaf:Person)
Im attaching some examples of the code generated
<oslc:ResponseInfo rdf:about="http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8080/ReqAdaptor/services/serviceProviders/1/resources/Requirement"> <rdfs:member> <oslc_rm:requirement> <dcterms:title rdf:parseType="Literal">Satisfaction</dcterms:title> <dcterms:contributor> <foaf:person>
As you can see, both person and requirement are in lower case
Thanks in advance
I managed to push directly to the master, bypassing Gerrit. But fix should be available now.
This bug was filed against 2.1.0 (not 3.0.0) and the fix was likely released in 2.1.2.

bug.short_desc: An IllegalStateException occurs instantiating OslcRestClient

long_desc.thetext:
I got the following exception when creating a consummer for an AM OSLC provider using librairies provided in Lyo 1.1.
"java.lang.IllegalStateException: Detected both log4j-over-slf4j.jar AND slf4j-log4j12.jar on the class path, preempting StackOverflowError. : Detected both log4j-over-slf4j.jar AND slf4j-log4j12.jar on the class path, preempting StackOverflowError."
It seems that wink-client-apache-httpclient-1.2.1-incubating.jar requires log4j-over-slf4j.jar. Is that someone has already got this problem?
The complete stacktrace:
SLF4J: The requested version 1.5.8 by your slf4j binding is not compatible with [1.6] SLF4J: See http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#version_mismatch for further details. SLF4J: Detected both log4j-over-slf4j.jar AND slf4j-log4j12.jar on the class path, preempting StackOverflowError. SLF4J: See also http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#log4jDelegationLoop for more details. Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError at org.apache.log4j.LogManager.getLogger(LogManager.java:42) at org.slf4j.impl.Log4jLoggerFactory.getLogger(Log4jLoggerFactory.java:73) at org.slf4j.LoggerFactory.getLogger(LoggerFactory.java:253) at org.slf4j.LoggerFactory.getLogger(LoggerFactory.java:265) at org.apache.wink.client.ClientConfig.<clinit>(ClientConfig.java:55) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.client.OslcRestClient.<init>(OslcRestClient.java:60) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.client.OslcRestClient.<init>(OslcRestClient.java:95) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.client.ServiceProviderRegistryClient.<init>(ServiceProviderRegistryClient.java:56) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.client.ServiceProviderRegistryClient.<init>(ServiceProviderRegistryClient.java:64)
...
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Detected both log4j-over-slf4j.jar AND slf4j-log4j12.jar on the class path, preempting StackOverflowError. See also http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#log4jDelegationLoop for more details. at org.apache.log4j.Log4jLoggerFactory.<clinit>(Log4jLoggerFactory.java:49) ... 11 more

Have not seen this before.
What JVM and JVM version are you using for your Eclipse IDE?
Can you try clearing all log4j and slf4j versions out of your local Maven repository and then doing a Maven install?
- go to your <home_dir>/.m2/repository directory - remove the following directories (and all sub-directories): org/slf4j log4j apache-log4j slf4j-log4j12
- right click the pom.xml in the org.eclipse.lyo.client.java and org.eclipse.lyo.samples.clients projects -> Run As -> Maven install
By "what JVM", I mean is it an Oracle JVM or an IBM JVM?

Idrissa, does the project you're working on bring in any dependencies beyond the Lyo ones?
I see the Jena includes slf4j-log4j12.jar.
I am not sure where log4j-over-slf4j.jar is coming from. I don't see wink-client-apache-httpclient requiring it unless I am missing something. It includes jcl-over-slf4j, but that shouldn't be an issue.
Some background on the problem:
http://www.slf4j.org/legacy.html http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#log4jDelegationLoop

Hi Michael and Samuel,
Thanks for your reply. I use an Oracle Java JVM for my Eclipse IDE. Currently, in my scenario I don't use Maven to compile. I just include provided jars by Lyo 1.1 in the classpath of my plug-ins & reexport them.
I will try to compile against these jars using Maven & try to use those new created as suggested.
(In reply to comment #1) > Have not seen this before. > > What JVM and JVM version are you using for your Eclipse IDE? > > Can you try clearing all log4j and slf4j versions out of your local Maven > repository and then doing a Maven install? > > - go to your <home_dir>/.m2/repository directory > - remove the following directories (and all sub-directories): > org/slf4j > log4j > apache-log4j > slf4j-log4j12 > > - right click the pom.xml in the org.eclipse.lyo.client.java and > org.eclipse.lyo.samples.clients projects -> Run As -> Maven install

I looked the problem in more detail. My Eclipse target platform contains one plug-in that wrap SLF4J version 1.5.8. That's caused conflict at plug-in resolution.
I think it was a real Lyo problem. Sorry for the caused inconveinients.
I close the bug
Thanks, Idrissa.

bug.short_desc: Inconsistent behaviour when deleting Domains Specifications and Vocabularies

long_desc.thetext:
Domain Specification (DS) ------------------------ When the user presses <delete> on a Domain Specification (DS), the graphical Element of the DS is deleted, but the DS is not actually deleted from the (EMF) model.
The argument has been that the DS might be represented in a number of Diagrams, and deleting a DS implied deleting its graphical representation only.
Vocabulary ----------- When the user presses <delete> on a Vocabulary (V), the V is deleting from the (EMF) model, which also means all graphical Elements of the V are deleted from all Diagrams.
This may be surprising for the user, and might not be the intended effect of deleting the V from all diagrams.
Suggestion ---------- When the user presses <delete> on a DS or V:
* If the DS/V is represented by 1 graphical element, then delete the graphical element and DS/V from the (EMF) model.
* If the DS/V is represented by more than 1 graphical element in different diagrams, then prompt the user to decide whether (a) the DS/V model should be deleted, including its graphical representations or (b) only deleted the selected graphical element.
I like the proposed behaviour.

bug.short_desc: Incorrect type for oslc:allowedValue,defaultValue,allowedValues properties for oslc:Property resource in ResourceShapes

long_desc.thetext:
The allowedValue and defaultValue field (and corresponding add/get/set methods) in the org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.Property class, and the allowedValues field in the org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.AllowedValues class only support String value type for those properties. However, OSLC CORE v2 Spec (http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OSLCCoreSpecAppendixA?sortcol=table;up=#oslc_ResourceShape_Resource) says that the value type of these properties will be "Same value-type as property" - so any type.
I am seeing following issues when using these classes to deserialize ResourceShape resources from RTC and RRC. The properties have value types of Resources:
1) A warning message in the log when the JenaModelHelper.fromResource encounters allowedValue Property with a URL value to a resource in the Property resource that is actually in the same Model: The warning message states: <date> org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper fromResource WARNING: Set method not found for object type: java.lang.String, uri: http://open-services.net/ns/core#property Also, the allowedValue array (and defaultValue field) in the Property Class is empty for that Property.
I saw the above problem with the instanceShape property for a ResourceShape of a Requirement resource in RRC. The allowedValue was the URL to the ResourceShape itself.
2) allowedValue array is empty for any allowedValue where the value of the allowedValue is a URL. I noticed this problem with the AllowedValues class when processing the ResourceShape resource for a Defect Work Item Type in RTC - Filed Against property for example.
3) allowedValue array is empty for any allowedValue where the value of the allowedValue is a blank node. I noticed this problem with the Property class when processing the ResourceShape resource for a Requirement Type in RRC - Priority and Status properties for example.

We should be able to fix this reading allowed values from other providers. Unfortunately, due to limitations on Java annotations, I'm not sure we can fix the @OslcAllowedValue annotation to support things other than Strings.

Resolved by commit:
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/17174/
I've left the old methods in place for backwards compatibility. I've added new methods that return Objects instead of strings to allow for other types (URI, Integer, etc.) and added some JUnit tests.
The @OslcAllowedValue annotation works the same as before (see comment #1).

bug.short_desc: Resource RDF XML payloads always must contain an rdf:type element matching the Java class name or @OslcName annotation

long_desc.thetext:
When using OSLC4J to parse incoming requests, we noticed that the OSLC4J JAX-RS media body reader (OslcRdfXmlProvider) will not map a payload like this to a specific Java class unless the rdf:type matches the class short name or the @OslcName annotation. This behavior is exclusive to the RDF XML JAX media body reader, it does not happen in the JSON media body reader.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:j.0="http://jazz.net/ns/ism/registry#" xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:j.1="http://domain.com/sometype#" > <rdf:Description rdf:nodeID="A0"> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://domain.com/sometype#"/> </rdf:RDF>
The "describes" parameter from @OslcResourceShape annotation is not being used when parsing the resource, i.e. the rdf:type does not match the java class defined in the "describes" parameter. Because of this, the parsed resource is created as null.
In our understanding, the matching should be based on the "describes" parameters of the @OslcResourceShape annotation. If even with this validation, the rdf:type of the resource does not match, then we should try to match it with the specified Java class.
The media body reader would consider the @OslcResourceShape.describes attribute instead of the Java class name or @OslcName annotation. In absence of the @OslcResourceShape.describes attribute, the parser would assume the incoming payload is always mapped to the specified Java class, with the excess attributes being placed inside AbstractResource extended properties.
I have a implemented a fix for this problem and will submit it through eGit.

Hi,
I tried to push the code fix, but I've got an error.
I created a new branch Bug412755 and commit the code to it. Then I tried to push it to target ref: refs/for/refs/heads/Bug412755
and got the following error message: Repository ssh://myUser@git.eclipse.org:29418/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git
branch Bug412755 not found Processing changes: refs: 1 Processing changes: refs: 1, done
What is the correct branch? What is the correct target ref? Am I missing something here?
Thanks, Fabiana

Hi, Fabiana. You should just push to HEAD:refs/for/master. See
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/ContributorsGettingStarted
Also make sure you've signed the Eclipse CLA or you won't be able to push to Gerrit.
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/Contributing_via_Git#Eclipse_Foundation_Contributor_License_Agreement
Thanks for your contribution!

Hi Samuel,
Thank you for your help! The target ref was wrong, I just put refs/for/master in the target ref and it worked.
I added you as the reviewer. https://git.eclipse.org/r/14482
Thanks, Fabiana

So the problem is that there isn't a good class name or @OslcName to set here because of the unusual rdf:type value (http://domain.com/sometype#) in your example?
I'm not sure about the second change, always assuming the class is right. What happens if the resource inlines other resources of different types in the same model?
Also, have you tried setting @OslcName("") on the class?

Hi Samuel,
In our case we have a RegistrationRecord class with the annotations: @OslcNamespace(OslcConstants.RR_NAMESPACE) @OslcResourceShape(title = "Registration Record", describes = OslcConstants.RR_NAMESPACE + "RegistrationRecord") @OslcName("RegistrationRecord")
Our resources are Registration Records but it can have different types, for example: ComputerSystem, SoftwareServer, etc. If a try to create a ComputerSystem Registration Record using the following payload and without specifying rdf:type as RegistrationRecord: <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:crtv="http://open-services.net/ns/crtv#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:rr="http://jazz.net/ns/ism/registry#"> <crtv:ComputerSystem rdf:about="http://test1234/1234/1234"> <oslc:serviceProvider rdf:resource="http://9.6.138.181:9081/oslc/providers/1372358317798"/> <crtv:test rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#decimal">1700.0</crtv:decimal> <crtv:integer rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#integer">9223372036854775807</crtv:integer> <crtv:double rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#double">1.7E3</crtv:double> <crtv:float rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float">1.3E5</crtv:float> </crtv:ComputerSystem> </rdf:RDF>
OSLC4J returns a null object after parsing it, because it tries to find the java class that matches @OslcName annotation, which is RegistrationRecord and not ComputerSystem. Although the resource has two different types (RegistrationRecord and ComputerSystem), it is possible to omit the RegistrationRecord type in the payload.
Right now, with this problem, the only way to make it work is giving the rdf:datatype as <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://jazz.net/ns/ism/registry#RegistrationRecord"/> in the payload, which is not an option for us, because we already have clients coded this way.
I just tried using @OslcName(""), but it has the same behavior, the RegistrationRecord is parsed as null. If I'm not wrong, it tries to get the @OslcName and if it does not find it, it gets the class name.
Thanks, Fabiana

(In reply to comment #7)
OK, I think I understand the use case better, but I don't know how using the describes value helps here. Describes is also set to RegistrationRecord in your example.
Removing the type check can cause problems for requests that have more than one resource, so I'm concerned about that change. I think if we want that we'd need some utility method that took in a Java class and the URI of the resource we want.

Hi Samuel,
As part of the fix, there is a flag that says if the new behavior should be done or not depending on the flag. The flag is based on the new property org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.useOslcResourceShapeDescribesAttributeForParsing and by default the flag is set to false. If the flag is false, we keep the existing behavior we have today, this way we don't change the existing behavior.
When the flag is set to true, the new code does the following: - tries to get the object result using the describes property - if even with the describes, it is not possible to get the object result, then it tries to get the listSubjects without passing the type.
Do you think this is a problem?
Thanks, Fabiana

(In reply to comment #9)
Do you still need the describes change for other scenarios? Because I don't think it addresses the one from comment #7. If so, I'd recommend two flags, one for using describes and one for removing the type checking against the class annotations. If not, we should focus on just removing the @OslcName check based on a flag.
I'm not against the change, I just want to understand. Thanks for your patience with me :)

Hi Samuel,
We agree with you, there are two behaviors here, it should have two flags instead of only one.
In our case, what really matters is the second part of the code fix (force the mapping to the bean class passed as a parameter: RegistrationRecord in our case). We would like to contribute only with this part. The "describes" attribute in OslcResourceShape may be useful to other teams, but we will not pursue it at this point.
Is that fine for you?
Thanks, Fabiana

(In reply to comment #11)
That sounds good. Sorry again if I'm making things hard.
Do you mind amending the commit with the change and pushing a new patch set to Gerrit? Let me know if you need help with this.
There's a chance you might run into a conflict with https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/14566/, but I can help resolve that.

Hi Samuel,
Thanks for your help... I just submitted the code fix and added you as the reviewer.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/14650/
Please, let me know if you have any question on this.
Thanks, Fabiana

bug.short_desc: Relax status code test in updateCreatedResourceWithInvalidContent

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, the test fails if for any status code other than 400 Bad Request. I don't see anywhere in OSLC Core 2.0 that 400 is required (except for missing If-Match headers), and I'm not certain it's really the right status code.
For what it's worth, LDP says this
"4.2.4.3 If an otherwise valid HTTP PUT request is received that attempts to change properties the server does not allow clients to modify, LDP servers must fail the request by responding with a 4xx range status code (typically 409 Conflict)."
I'm going to relax the check to 4xx.
