bug.short_desc: generated OslcDomainsConstants.java should use the same names (and naming conventions) as OSLC4J OslcConstants.java

long_desc.thetext:
For example, one class says "PATH_CHANGE_REQUEST" while the other says "PATH_CHANGEREQUEST".
Change the generated OslcDomainsConstants.java to match OSLC4J OslcConstants.java. Since, we don't want to change core.

I think it is the case that the generated OsclDomainsConstants.java will define all the constants for the OSLC core domain as defined in the oslcDomainSpecifications.xml specification model. The generated code will use these constants, and not the similarly defined constants in core OslcConstants.java. So having the names be different probably isn't a problem, but might be confusing.

Agree(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #1) > I think it is the case that the generated OsclDomainsConstants.java will > define all the constants for the OSLC core domain as defined in the > oslcDomainSpecifications.xml specification model. The generated code will > use these constants, and not the similarly defined constants in core > OslcConstants.java. So having the names be different probably isn't a > problem, but might be confusing.
Agree. This fix is simply to avoid confusion in the naming conventions. Generated code will always depend on what we put in the model instances.
A fix is made through https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/119527/

bug.short_desc: Generated adaptor does not allow assigning URLs flexibly

long_desc.thetext:
There are problems with the current URL generation and setup. ServletListener tries to guess the domain name of the host machine.
This approach fails is there is no Reverse PTR record for the IP address (typical on the ISP network) and/or if more than one domain points to the IP address.
In the former case, localhost will always be substituted for the machine IP address (which usually changes all the time due to DHCP) and in the latter case, it's impossible to deploy the adaptor on a server with multiple domains or behind the reverse proxy (e.g. nginx).
Finally, in order to use SSL/TLS, we have to always add port 443 to the URL (as well as port 80 for HTTP).
I suggest a patch that will:
* by default always use "http://localhost:8080" * allows to override this "base path" via web.xml (or context.xml on the server) to something like "https://md.kth.se"
This will still leave the case of full URL rewrite (i.e. removing context path from the URL) unsolved but it will cover most of the cases.

bug.short_desc: index.jsp is generated but needs to be user editable

long_desc.thetext:
The codegenerator generates an index.jsp page with simple default content that provides a link to the service provider catalog page. This is fine for initial testing. But any OSLC server will very likely have to completely replace any generated welcome page to meet its unique application needs.
There is currently no user code regions marked in the index.jsp page, and there is no way to protect this page from getting regenerated. So the OSLC server does not have adequate control of its welcome pages.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/97382

I recalled this trick where we can put the default content within the protected user code area. This means one can freely change the default content, without risk of loosing changes upon subsequent generations.
I believe this is what you are after jim? Please check my suggested patch!
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/97382 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=fad73880a42cfa5688a27abc97e38187e702af8c

bug.short_desc: RDF/XML creation tests still run with supportCreationFactory set to false

long_desc.thetext: The dynamic suite builder excludes the XML and JSON creation and update tests if the provider does not support creation factories. It still includes the RDF/XML creation tests, however, leading to errors for providers that don't have a creation factories.

bug.short_desc: Java client dependencies on core result in large client SDK

long_desc.thetext: The OSLC4J Java client currently depends on module org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core:oslc4j-core. This may result in the Java client including JAR files that are only used in the development of OSLC servers using the OSLC4J SDK. It would be helpful to separate the core client and server dependencies if possible in order to reduce the size of the Java client library.

bug.short_desc: Do not reify objects of type AbstractReifiedResource (such as Link) unless there are additional statements to reify

long_desc.thetext: Every time I create a new Link between two resources (by using the generated setSomeProperty method), the property gets reifed (consequently creates a bunch of blank nodes) which is not always necessary.

This issue is related to JenaModelHelper, and not necessarilly the generated code.
If a OSLC-annotated Java class has a property of type Link, JenaModelHelper reifies Link to a set of statements. This is fine, when the Link contains additional properties (such as label).
However, when a Link instance only has the URI property set, it does not make sense to create the statements rdf:subject, rdf:predicate & rdf:object, when there are no additional statements to add to thew blank node.
Change JenaModelHelper to only create these additional statements, when there are properties to add to the Link.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/110348
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/110348 was merged to [master]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=c383740a44c58343fcc2452db68db7a80e9aaefe
Looks like it has been resolved, closing as fixed.

I try to build the project org.eclipse.lyo.rio.core with Eclipse as described by http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/BuildRIO#Building_and_Running_Lyo_reference_implementations_.28RIOs.29_in_Eclipse
But the Maven install fails with the following error : ArtifactDescriptorException: Failed to read artifact descriptor for org.openrdf

I tried to solve the problem by copying a newer slf4j api and by adding target/generated-sources/antlr3 to the project build path (as suggected in the description) but I didn' succeed.
I'm new to Lyo and i tried looking for a similar bug but couldn't find any...Can you give me some hint to solve this problem? Thanks in advance for your help,
Jacques

bug.short_desc: Ensure dependency convergence on release artifacts

long_desc.thetext:
Easiest way is to run 'mvn clean package javadoc:javadoc site' and check that there are no dependency conflicts and that for all non-lyo packages there is convergence.
NB! Do it for client and core.
Created attachment 267101 maven site for core
Created attachment 267102 maven site for client

There is no dependency convergence neither in core nor in client.

20090617 @ net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4 20100527 @POM
== org.apache.httpcomponents:httpclient ==
4.0 @ net.oauth.core:oauth-httpclient4 4.1.3 @ org.apache.wink:wink-client-apache-httpclient 4.5.1 @POM
== org.apache.jena:jena-core ==
2.13.0 POM 2.7.1 lyo-core
See maven sites attached.

These transitive dependency issues are likely being caused by not picking a necessarily compatible set of dependencies. We can attempt to repair these, but possibly the worst outcome will be bloated JAR files.
New Gerrit change created: https://git.eclipse.org/r/92292

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #4) > These transitive dependency issues are likely being caused by not picking a > necessarily compatible set of dependencies. We can attempt to repair these, > but possibly the worst outcome will be bloated JAR files.
If you take a close look at the site report, maven actively picks the version for us. My patch makes those version decisions explicit (I lean towards older versions that our dependencies were built against, less surprises, esp. for the service release). That one is for client.

I just looked at core, I don't want to deal with those issues until we do POM reorganisation.
For example, jaxb-impl is dependencyManaged in oslc4j-wink, but once it is used by other core package this managed version has no effect. I would just count on maven resolution for this release (as previous releases did).
I mark this one as resolved for client and create a separate issue for core for 2.2.0.
Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/92292 was merged to [2.1.2-service]. Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=e35dbc241c4ef893ac6e8190ab032c48826edcca

bug.short_desc: JazzFormAuthClient should throw all exceptions

long_desc.thetext:
Hey,
Is there any reason to not throw all exceptions in the 'formLogin' method? In this case I would like to catch the ClientProtocolException (if it is thrown). At this time only the stack trace is printed (except for 'JazzAuthFailedException' and 'JazzAuthErrorException').

Ben, I'm not sure why we're not just throwing other exceptions. It doesn't seem like a good practice. I notice we do the same in getArtifactFeed().
I might deprecate the old methods and add new ones to avoid changing method signatures in our API.

Resolved by
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/36690/

The new method is
org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.jazz.JazzFormAuthClient.login()
It behaves like the old method, except it throws more exceptions. getArtifactFeed() was an unused private method, so I removed it.
I kept the previous formLogin (now deprecated) to avoid API changes.

(In reply to Samuel Padgett from comment #3) > The new method is > > org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.jazz.JazzFormAuthClient.login() > > It behaves like the old method, except it throws more exceptions. > getArtifactFeed() was an unused private method, so I removed it. > > I kept the previous formLogin (now deprecated) to avoid API changes.
Patch looks great, thanks!
Will be released in 2.1.2.

bug.short_desc: Lyo Designer model should allow user to tag DomainSpecs as "Do Not Generate"

long_desc.thetext:
There are scenarios where the user needs to model a domain, that (1) is already implemented in java (2) yet is needed in the model so that other domains can refer to it. For example, the ResourceShape or ServiceProvider resources may need to be inclueded in domain specifications, yet they are already implemented in OSCLC4J.
The user should be able to check any modelled DomainSpecification as "Do Not Generate", indicating to code generator that the java classes need not be produced.
The only thing that needs to be produced is the package name, so that the existing classes can be referenced in the generated classes.
Question to investigate: Is it still necessary to produce the domainConstants.java class?

bug.short_desc: oslc4jclient unable to find message bundles when runtime is en_GB

long_desc.thetext: Gettting a MissingResourceException trying to output a message when the runtime is en_GB (likely any non en_US as well).

This is a packaging issue related to exporting from Eclipse. The resolution is to use Maven to build the jar:
- add the maven-assembl-plugin to the pom - run mvn assembly:single
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/574594/how-can-i-create-an-executable-jar-with-dependencies-using-maven for additional information.

bug.short_desc: Rename default servlet name from "JAX-RS Servlet" to "oslc-servlet"

long_desc.thetext: This is a unique identifier and using something like "JAX-RS Servlet" says literally nothing about the nature of the generated servlet.

We need to do the following changes:
1. Update the web.xml file to use the new name in the sample project under https://github.com/OSLC/lyo-adaptor-sample-modelling.git
2. Update the instructions under https://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/creating_OSLC4J_project#Customise_the_web_configuration
3. Modify the code generator, generateAdaptorServletListener.mtl file to handle both "JAX-RS Servlet" & "oslc-servlet", in order to handle already existing project models.
servletName = "JAX-RS Servlet" --> replaced by a set.
servletContext.getServletRegistration(servletName) --> loops through the names until it finds one that exists.

Not sure about the 3. My idea was to remove confusion and make it obvious that we are dealing with the OSLC servlet here, not something JAX-RS internal. And the whole backwards compat thing (esp. with the Set and the enumeration logic) is just going to be the opposite so we might as well not touch it at all :)
Concerning 3, we can add comments in the code to clarify that the "JAX-RS Servlet" value is deprecated.
Jim, what do you think?
Wontfix due to compat issues

bug.short_desc: ServiceProviderXmlTests test optional serviceProviderHasValidDetails capability as a MUST

long_desc.thetext: The serviceProviderHasValidDetails test in org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.oslcv2.ServiceProviderXmlTests asserts that an OSLC service provider must have a details node, however this is an optional part of the OSLC specification according to http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecification?sortcol=table;up=#Service_Provider_Resources which states that the a service provider may have zero or many oslc:details nodes. Currently the test fails if no details node is found and it appears as a MUST pass on the assessment report.
Yuhong, Can you please take a look at this one?
Working on this now.

Change this test as "MAY" requirement.
Also added back the missing assessment ant script for RQM.
Ran through all tests without regression.

bug.short_desc: Add prefix/suffix to the resource class names

long_desc.thetext:
Jim:
> Not a problem, but you cant use "Application" or "Service" as a resource names as they conflict on import with the generated servlet name Application.java and Service.java. The boiler plate class names should use some prefix to avoid class name collisions like that - allowing the modeler to use the good names.
Jad:
> The domain prefix can be used. I do similar thing if a resource has 2 properties with the same name (from different Domains). There are 2 parts: (1) avoid Java keywords which we can list out for all adaptors (2) avoid application-specific terms that might turn out in the code of the adaptor. For the latter, I need to give the modeller a way to give such a list.
Andrew:
> The clash will happen with any class name you have imported in the template. E.g. ApplicationDSR (DSR for Domain Spec Resource). Also, if you have defined an RDF prefix, we can add a prefix to the class as well. oslc_rm:Application can become OslcRmApplicationDSR. I know its ugly but will certainly help. We can then allow resources with the strangest names like Object and Class.

Eclipse has wrapping problems:
Jim:
> Not a problem, but you cant use "Application" or "Service" as a resource > names as they conflict on import with the generated servlet name > Application.java and Service.java. The boiler plate class names should use some > prefix to avoid class name collisions like that - allowing the modeler to use > the good names.
Jad:
> The domain prefix can be used. I do similar thing if a resource has 2 > properties with the same name (from different Domains). There are 2 parts: (1) > avoid Java keywords which we can list out for all adaptors (2) avoid > application-specific terms that might turn out in the code of the adaptor. For > the latter, I need to give the modeller a way to give such a list.
Andrew:
> The clash will happen with any class name you have imported in the template. > E.g. ApplicationDSR (DSR for Domain Spec Resource). Also, if you have defined an > RDF prefix, we can add a prefix to the class as well. oslc_rm:Application can > become OslcRmApplicationDSR. I know its ugly but will certainly help. We can > then allow resources with the strangest names like Object and Class.

We should only add prefixes to the boiler plate class names if there is a conflict. Reason: In most cases, the models do not contain "Application" terms, and it would be a pity to make the class names cumbersome.
I'm happy enough to put the prefix on the resource names in the domain specification.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #3) > I'm happy enough to put the prefix on the resource names in the domain > specification.
Then it means you would be comfortable with a stop-list of resource names in the modelling tool?
If by stop-list you mean a list of reserved names that should not be used for domain specification resource names, then yes.

But I would recommend avoiding using good names like Application and Service for class names in generated code. That is avoid, reserving good names by adding your own prefix: TcgApplication, TcgService (for Toolchain Generator). This leave the good names available for users models and reduces the possibility of collisions.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #6) > But I would recommend avoiding using good names like Application and Service > for class names in generated code. That is avoid, reserving good names by > adding your own prefix: TcgApplication, TcgService (for Toolchain > Generator). This leave the good names available for users models and reduces > the possibility of collisions.
I actually like the idea because once accustomed, developers will easily distinguish the custom code from the generated one. And it will leave the nice names available to the developer, as you have pointed out.

(In reply to Jim Amsden from comment #6) > But I would recommend avoiding using good names like Application and Service > for class names in generated code. That is avoid, reserving good names by > adding your own prefix: TcgApplication, TcgService (for Toolchain > Generator). This leave the good names available for users models and reduces > the possibility of collisions.
Good idea actually. i now get your main point Jim!
Luckily, the only "bad" names we have to fix is Application (might as well avoid "ServletListener"). All other class names are quite specific.

bug.short_desc: Tutorial: Integrating Products with OSLC - Fix incorrect or incomplete steps and improve instructions

long_desc.thetext:
There are incorrect or additional steps required to complete the Integrating Products with OSLC tutorial (http://open-services.net/resources/tutorials/integrating-products-with-oslc/). The tutorial could also be improved by providing screen shots.
The following issues were identified using Mac OSX 10.10.3 and Eclipse 4.4.2. See also https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=469315
Section: Running the Example Applications
Subsection: Installing Pre-requisites
Downloading and installing Eclipse The JVM should be added to Eclipse > Preferences > Installed JREs (Use Java 7 instead of Java 8 - see below). The Maven Install step below fails on the Mac because JAVA_HOME is not set. It would be best if Maven could be set up to use JRE defined in Eclipse, or edit a Maven file that would provide JAVA_HOME. This may be a bug in the version of Maven being used. The only solution identified so far is to run Eclilpse.app from a shell that has JAVA_HOME set manually. You can do the following: Create or edit ~/.bash_profile to read: if [ -f ~/.bashrc ]; then source ~/.bashrc fi Create or edit ~/bashrc to read (the single quotes are important): export JAVA_HOME=`/usr/libexec/java_home` Launch a command line window. Go to [eclipse directory] type: open ./eclipse.app
Installing M2 Eclipse There is an issue with using JavaDoc in the tutorial on the Mac and it must be turned off. This needs to be noted in the tutorial or fixed. Set the JVM argument -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true to turn off JavaDoc generation. This can be done in Eclipse > Preferences > Installed JREs. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=463217.
Build the OSLC4J projects The version of Antlr that OSLC4J currently uses is only compatible with Java 7, so users with Java 8 must install and set up Java 7. There should be instructions on this, or better yet update the version of Antlr so OSLC4J can use Java 8. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=463324. Warnings are reported when Maven Install is run (warnings are shown in red). They should be eliminated or the student should be notified that the warnings are OK.
Subsection: Downloading, building, and running the sample applications
Building the Applications In ninacrm there were the following errors and resolutions that should be fixed or described in the tutorial: "Java compiler level does not match the version of the installed Java project facet". Appears to be a Maven issue? Right-click project > Properties and search for "facet". Changed Java to version 1.7. fixed the issue. "Cannot change version of project facet Dynamic Web Module to 2.4." It's currently set to 2.3. De-selected it from the facet properties then did project > Maven > Update Project. Eclipse updated it to 2.4 and checked it back on automatically. 3 errors remain in jetty.xml in the test directory indicating the type IDs musts be unique within the document. However, the sample builds and can be used. The code (or the project setup) should be fixed. There are 6 additional errors in org.eclipse.lyo.server.oauth.webapp. All are the same JSP error: "Can not find the tag library descriptor for "http://java.sun.com/jst/jstl/core". The sample runs but the code (or project setup) should be fixed.
More to come...

bug.short_desc: Generated coded does not follow platform line delimiters

long_desc.thetext:
The Toolchain codegenerator uses template files that appear to have been developed on a Windows machine - the lines are terminated with \r\n. On a UNIX machine, these files result in inconsistent line delimiters when checking the file into RTC SCM since the plain/text MIME type property for the source files is platform, while the line delimiters in the source files are \r\n.
The code generator should honor the eclipse preference for line termination so that issues aren't created when source files are edited on different systems.
I initiated a thread on Acceleo forum to see how this can be solved. https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=msg&th=1086244&goto=1763529&#msg_1763529

The recommendation seems to be that the generator files (*.mtl) should use the Unix delimiter (\n). Somehow this is less problematic for Windows text editors, and solves the problem with Mac/Linux.
worth trying?
I am just concerned that in the future, a Windows user would have similar problems with \n, as Mac users have with \n\r today.
experiences on this? Is it generally safer to use Unix delimiters on Windows, than vice versa?

Is this still a problem?
I think the best way would be just to force line conversion at the Git level.

Proposal for test suite package refactoring. Please comment in this Bugzilla if you have comments/concerns/suggestions to improve.

bug.short_desc: Test suite requires oslc:totalCount even though the spec says it's optional

long_desc.thetext:
See
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecification?sortcol=table;table=up#Resource_Paging
"This optional property indicates the total number of results across all pages, its value should be non-negative. In the context of a query resource, this value SHOULD be the total number of results, i.e. the number of resources that match the query. In the context of other resources, the value SHOULD be the total number of property values (i.e. RDF triples) of the resource. Unless Stable Paging is in effect, the total count MAY vary as a client retrieves subsequent pages."
We should validate oslc:totalCount if it's there, but the tests should not fail if it's not.
Pull request: https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.testsuite/pull/2

Resolved by this commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.git/commit/?id=7633e12937f90c22c1a2398be84151a225a39734
resolved by commebnt 2
Closing...

bug.short_desc: Add more value types in the properties of Resource Property in Specification Diagram

long_desc.thetext:
JenaModelHelper can support more value types than those which are supported by Lyo Designer. Currently, Lyo Designer supports only these value types (see attached image). It will be nice to add further value types. Those include: 1. Short 2. Byte 3. Long 4. BigInteger
This needs a change in underlying EMF model, Graphical Interface of Lyo Designer and Code Generator.
Created attachment 274036 Currently supported value types in Lyo Designer

Do you think it will be more valuable to use XSD types, such as xsd:int, xsd:integer etc? I think this comes back to Lyo not hiding any complexity. In this case if you add BigInteger, a person should know 2 things:
1) xsd:integer is too big to be stored in a Long 2) Jena maps BigInteger to an xsd:integer
In other words, I suggest we hide the Java details from the Lyo Designer users and expose the OSLC terminology to them.
See Bug 531428 & Bug 534343
Jim, what do you think?

I agree. Using XSD types is a good approach here.
In addition: Currently, Lyo Designer have "Integer" as a value type and it is mapped to xsd:int by Jena which seems ambiguous.

The types that should be supported are defined by OSLC Core ResourceShapes: http://docs.oasis-open.org/oslc-core/oslc-core/v3.0/oslc-core-v3.0-part6-resource-shape.html Literal Value Types:
rdf:XMLLiteral xsd:boolean xsd:dateTime xsd:decimal xsd:double xsd:float xsd:integer xsd:string rdf:langString

Can't seem to find the list of value types the Core library supports. Yash! Where did we find that when we looked together?
I think we should support the list referred to by Jim at a minimum. Comparing it to the current list supported by LyoDesigner, we are only missing decimal and langString.
But then of course, it does not hurt to support a few more that might be of use.
1. Start by changing the underlying EMF model (preferbly add, but do not change), and then regenerate the java classes. This allows for modelling.
2. The Graphical Interface of Lyo Designer needs not be changed. Sirius picks stuff up automatically.
3. Change in code generator - i can give you some pointers once model is in place. This part of hte code is very old and ugly. so it might need to some reworking.
see https://github.com/eclipse/lyo.core/blob/master/org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core/src/main/java/org/eclipse/lyo/oslc4j/core/model/ValueType.java#L30

This issue also seems to block Bug 531428, which hit the bug in Lyo regarding xsd:int/integer: Jena will serialise our ints as xsd:int while our constants declare only xsd:integer, as expected by the spec...
Bug 531428 should be tested once we have a patch here.
Jad, Jim, Yash, what should we do with this issue?

attachment.desc: Currently supported value types in Lyo Designer

bug.short_desc: The adaptor codegenerator fails if no selectionDialog and/or creationDialog is defined for all resources.

long_desc.thetext:
the code generator currently assumes that a selectionDialog and a creationDialog are specified in the adaptorModel for each resource to be managed. It will fail otherwise. For example, in the GenerateResourceService template, creationDialogs.any().dialogURI will fail if creationDialogs is an empty set.
Solution: Only generate the selector/creatorDialog methods (& annotations) if there is at least one dialog specified in the model. While at it, extend the adaptor model to allow the designer to specify exactly which of the CRUD methods to be generated.
Please assign to me.

Resolved by
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/35104/
This bug was filed against 2.1.0 (not 3.0.0) and the fix was likely released in 2.1.2.

bug.short_desc: Code generator wrongly defines an interface as well as superclass for the same parent exenting class

long_desc.thetext:
In some cases, when (1) a resource A extends resource B, and (2) A extends C which itself extends B, an exception "OSLC002: Duplicate property definition annotation ..." occurs.
This occurs since the corresponding class B gets defines as A's superclass (through 1), as well as its interface (through 2).
The java code compiles, but when the server starts, exception OSLC002 occurs since the properties of class B are defined in the resource shape twice.

bug.short_desc: No compact rendering hover in some browsers

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
The cm [am, rm] resource listing web page only shows a compact rendering of the resource upon hover in certain browsers, as follows:
Hover No Hover -------------- ---------------------------------- FireFox 3.6.25 Internet Explorer 8.0.6001.18702CO Chrome 16.0.912.75 Opera 11.60 Safari 5.1.2
Patch forthcoming shortly.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to http://localhost:8080/rio-cm/list/changerequest 2. Hover a resource URL 3. Look for the compact rendering

Created attachment 209982 Fix compact rendering hover in several browsers
I ran into the problem with change requests, but requirements and resources had the same problem, so the patch corrects all four instances. The fix is in handling of namespaces when parsing the XML response. This fixes Chrome, Safari, and Opera. IE still doesn't work for me, not sure why.
The older RIOs are deprecated and will not be enhanced

bug.short_desc: Persist change log for the TRS reference application

long_desc.thetext: As the TRS reference application operates it creates in-memory change events for any create, modify, or delete operations. When the server is restarted these events are lost and information is moved to the base. While this is a valid TRS use case it would be helpful to persist the change log so that it may be reloaded at startup time. This allows a mechanism for consumers to optimize the way they retrieve information in certain cases. For example, a consumer won't have to take a performance hit to reprocess a potentially large base if the change log disappears.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/14475/

Resolved by commit:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.rio.git/commit/?id=d6dbe27678fad54faa8958967381a38cc87d43f0

bug.short_desc: OSLC008 OslcCoreMissingAnnotationExceptio

long_desc.thetext:
javax.servlet.UnavailableException: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.exception.OslcCoreMissingAnnotationException: OSLC008: Missing mandatory OSLC annotation org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.annotation.OslcResourceShape for class java.net.URI
Full trace:
sandbox-twin_1 | Caused by: org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.exception.OslcCoreMissingAnnotationException: OSLC008: Missing mandatory OSLC annotation org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.annotation.OslcResourceShape for class java.net.URI sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.ResourceShapeFactory.createResourceShape(ResourceShapeFactory.java:121) sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.ResourceShapeFactory.createProperty(ResourceShapeFactory.java:300) sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.ResourceShapeFactory.createResourceShape(ResourceShapeFactory.java:153) sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.ResourceShapeFactory.createResourceShape(ResourceShapeFactory.java:110) sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.application.OslcResourceShapeResource.<init>(OslcResourceShapeResource.java:65) sandbox-twin_1 | at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.application.OslcWinkApplication.<init>(OslcWinkApplication.java:56) sandbox-twin_1 | at sandbox.servlet.Application.<init>(Application.java:159)
Another warning I can see is:
WARN org.apache.wink.server.internal.application.ApplicationProcessor - The sandbox.resources.Mission class is neither a resource nor a provider. The runtime is ignoring this class. It was returned from a javax.ws.rs.core.Application subclass. Add either a @javax.ws.rs.Path or a @javax.ws.rs.core.Provider annotation to the class.
sandbox.resources.Mission class in that adaptor is consumed from another adaptor in the toolchain.
Running the latest codegen plugin & 2.2.0-SNAPSHOT libraries.

The problem seems to be resolved by commenting out all RESOURCE_CLASSES and RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP registration calls for all but the produced resources.
Jad, why are consumed classes registered anyway? For the case if we want to serialise them back?

Okay, with all the consumed classes unregistered, I fail to unmarshall the retrieved resource:
A javax.ws.rs.ext.MessageBodyReader implementation was not found for class sandbox.resources.Waypoint type and application/octet-stream media type.

Okay, I have figured out that the application/octet-stream media type was returned for the 404 NOT FOUND pages. I have configured the adaptor URI base wrong in my client.
I think Lyo client needs to handle 404 errors with a proper good exception that I can catch and process accordingly.
And yes, I brought back the RESOURCE_CLASSES registration calls but not the RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP. The latter ones need to be removed for sure unless the SHACL library that is on the way to be committed is relying on this when I use the client (should not but who knows).
So, Jad, in this bug we decide how to proceed with the OslcCoreMissingAnnotationException and we take the exception I want to see added in Bug 519478.

1. It is strange that the system is trying to create a shape for java.net.URI. I have not encountered this before. Can you share some code?
2. The warning "WARN ...ApplicationProcessor - The sandbox.resources.Mission class is neither a resource nor a provider." is valid.
The generated Application.class wrongly includes statements such as RESOURCE_CLASSES.add(Person.class); RESOURCE_CLASSES should only include JAX-RS resources (and not OSLC resources). I will report and fix as a separate issue.
3. "why are consumed classes registered anyway?" Can you clarify what you mean by "consumed" resources?
4. "I brought back the RESOURCE_CLASSES registration calls but not the RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP."
RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP is needed! I can't detail why here, but I can't see how this helps solve your problem. Or, are you debugging/guessing still?

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #5) > 1. It is strange that the system is trying to create a shape for > java.net.URI. I have not encountered this before. Can you share some code? > > 2. The warning "WARN ...ApplicationProcessor - The sandbox.resources.Mission > class is neither a resource nor a provider." is valid. > > The generated Application.class wrongly includes statements such as > RESOURCE_CLASSES.add(Person.class); > RESOURCE_CLASSES should only include JAX-RS resources (and not OSLC > resources). I will report and fix as a separate issue. > > > 3. "why are consumed classes registered anyway?" > Can you clarify what you mean by "consumed" resources? > > 4. "I brought back the RESOURCE_CLASSES registration calls but not the > RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP." > > RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP is needed! I can't detail why > here, but I can't see how this helps solve your problem. Or, are you > debugging/guessing still?
1. Yes, https://github.com/EricssonResearch/scott-eu/tree/b-lyo-initial/lyo-sandbox, specifically https://github.com/EricssonResearch/scott-eu/tree/b-lyo-initial/lyo-sandbox/sandbox-twin-webapp/src/main/java/se/ericsson/cf/scott/sandbox
2. Thanks!
3. I add those resources as "consumed" in the toolchain diagram.
4. I am not guessing any more, commenting out those declarations helped to get to the 404 error, which set me back as described in Bug 519478.

Commenting out lines like
RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP.put(PpConstants.PATH_ACTION, Action.class);
in the Application class has resolved the problem.
Jad, I remember you told me that these declaration were not strictly necessary any more?
I have even done a bug fix on this. So it depends on which plugin version you have, but the lattest code on master does no longer generate this code

>Now, the generator defaults to Link, if no range is defined. This seems obviously >bad. What should it default to? AbstractResource?
AbstractResource is no good, since it does not have annotations, and hence leads to same problems.
Alternativly, we can have a validation rule on the EMF model.

Maybe int or string. Or define some new object called Undefined. But I'm inclined to treat this as a validation error as long as users can figure out from the odd exception that they are missing a range. This was of course not obvious.
*** Bug 531214 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Hit it again on Docker. But from the bug description seems like Docker or other exec env variables do not play any role in it.

Okay, now I see it. Jad, shall we just avoid registering resources that are not served by any REST service in the RESOURCE_SHAPE_PATH_TO_RESOURCE_CLASS_MAP? There is no way for such resources' shape to be served anyway.

bug.short_desc: Add library to simplify triplestore operations with Lyo OSLC resources

This allows to perform READ operations (from CRUD) without touching the tool.
A library can be used that handles triplestore operations and uses JenaHelper to perform marshalling and unmarshalling of the OSLC resources.

bug.short_desc: Reorganize Lyo Eclipse projects to improve understanding by OSLC adopters

long_desc.thetext:
Lyo projects are currently organized around specific internal functionality (core, build, query, etc). It would be helpful to new OSLC adopters if we provided projects focused on their common goals. Those higher-level projects would have dependencies on internally focused projects, hiding details that adopters may not be interested in. Potential new projects focused on adopters might include:
Client API Server SDK Server Reference Implementation Test Suite (test client and server implementations) Samples and Tutorials

bug.short_desc: Incorrect path to images in manage.js

long_desc.thetext: The manage.js file in oauth-webapp.war creates image nodes with paths like "../../oauth/images/yes.gif". Such path is resolved based on the manage.jsp file, where the image nodes get added. The path goes down one extra level than necessary. The path should rather be "../oauth/images/yes.gif"

The JSP is included from
org.eclipse.lyo.server.oauth.webapp.services.OAuthService.showConsumerKeyManagementPage()
via url
/<webapp-context>/services/oauth/admin
The expectation is not that the JSP will be invoked directly, so I think path is correct.

bug.short_desc: Generated toHtml methods for properties that are zeroOrOne and exactlyOne do not handle null values

long_desc.thetext:
For properties that have cardinality zeroOrOne or exactlyOne, the generated toHtml methods simply call getValue() on the property, which assumes that the property value is set.
Need to first check that the property itself is not null, before calling getValue.
This applies to both zeroOrOne or exactlyOne cardinality. Even if cardinatly is exactlyOne, there are no guarantees that the property value is set, leading to exceptions otherwise.

bug.short_desc: Generator: Support for multiple ServiceProviders

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, the generator does not handle the generation of more than one type of ServiceProviders. that is, different serviceProviders can have a different services (query capabilities, factories) that can target different resource types.
This change will require a major restructuring of the way the generator currently works. New approach: * Each Service for each ServiceProvider will correspond to a JAX-RS Resource, with methods to handle the defined capabilities withing that Service.
Current approach: * Each Resource corresponded to a JAX-RS Resource, with methods handling defined capabilities from across the many ServicePRoviders defined in the model.
Please assign to me.

bug.short_desc: Updating a resource fails with HTTP 405 "Method not allowed"

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 265195 wire/head log of the failed request
Update a resource, e.g. a Test Plan, using "OSLCOAuthClient.updateResource()" fails with HTTP 405 "Method not allowed". From the logs it seems that the PUT requests uses a wrong URL. It is "/qm/auth/authrequired" when it should be the resource URL. Using the exact same request body with the resource URL via a REST Client instead works fine. Seems to be a problem with the OAuth dance. Please find the original request log attached.

If you login to a Jazz application such as RQM, and then access a Test Plan resource using its URI in a REST client running in the same browser instance, then the authentication has already been done, and the browser will automatically provide the proper cookies for the REST client request.
However, your OSLC client application will need to authenticate in order to access the same URI because it does not have the same cookie store that the browser has. So it will get a redirect from the server with the qm/auth/authrequired URI that you are experiencing. You need to do JEE FORM based authentication in response to the authentication challenge, and then perform your request again. Subsequent requests should not be a problem as the client API should retain the cookies for subsequent use. However, not that authentication challenges can reoccur anytime due to server timeouts, or for other reasons. So your app should be prepared to deal with an authentication challenge on every request if it is a long running client.
OAuth authentication is not needed for client to server authentication. FORM based authentication is sufficient.

Generally, updating a resource works fine. The creation of a new test plan, for example, does not produce an error, as well as many other operations, like updating test case attributes. So why is updating a test plan a special case?
Additionally, i dont see a way to intercept that authentication challenge.

I don't know why updating a Test Plan would be different than updating a Test Case. This is likely something specific to the RQM server, not necessarily a defect in Eclipse/Lyo.
You can intercept authentication challenges by examining HTTP response codes. Lyo likely has specific APIs for dealing with this that you are already using. Looks like there's some unique exception happening with Test Plans.

So I understand that updating a Test Plan should be no different than updating a Test Case. Also creating a Test Plan should have the same requirements regarding authentication as updating a Test Plan.
I already spoke to the RQM team about that issue. We saw three possible causes for that behaviour and eliminated two of them. The remaining cause was a bug in Lyo.
Allow me to citate what I got from the CLM/RQM team:
---------------------------------------------------------- This request is used to authenticate with the RQM server. The Eclipse Lyo client has attempting to PUT the test plan RDF/XML without (successfully) authenticating with the RQM server.
A couple of things that might be causing this symptom:
1. Using the wrong credentials. 2. Attempting to PUT to a different server. 3. Eclipse Lyo bug. ----------------------------------------------------------

I did check my code again and have to correct me: We only create but not update resources so far. It seems updating a test plan was the first resource modification we tried to implement up to this point. In brief: Creating resources works fine for us, but updates don't. Sorry for the confusion. But I still have no idea why creation (POST) works, but updates (PUT) don't.
You may be missing a required header or eTag. Usually a PUT requires a GET first and then use the eTag header to ensure the resource hasn't changed when the PUT request is received.

Thanks for the hint with the "etag". I did not expect that to be necessary, but now it seems to work perfectly fine. I tried different things today and also saw updates succeeding with form based authentication. But, when using OAuth it seems that I really need to add the "etag", although I am already providing a full resource URL for the update and the "etag" is obviously just the last part of that URL. Anyways, its fine now that I know that one has to provide the "etag".

bug.short_desc: Container type is missing in serialized collections/arrays

long_desc.thetext:
When returning arrays or collections, the response must include a Container element that lists all the resources returned. Currently the rdf:type property is missing in such responses.
For example, as part of one response I get: <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/rr/registration/collection"> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286771"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286781"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286780"/> </rdf:Description>
while the correct output should be: <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/rr/registration/collection"> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286771"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286781"/> <rdfs:member rdf:resource="http://nc050057.tivlab.raleigh.ibm.com:9080/oslc/registration/1372337286780"/> <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#Container"/> </rdf:Description>

Hi, Francisco. I can't find anywhere in the OSLC specifications where it requires or recommends using rdfs:Container in query results. It's not also not used in any example on open-services.net that I can find. For instance,
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OSLCCoreSpecRDFXMLExamples?sortcol=table;up=#Specifying_the_shape_of_a_query
Is this breaking something? What is the benefit of adding this type?
OSLC query responses also do not use rdf:_1, rdf:_2... container membership properties, which from what I can tell is implied by specifying the type as an rdfs:Container. (I could be wrong...)
http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-mt/#Containers
I also looked at RDF and RDF/XML specs and I couldn't find any usage of it. It doesn't appear to affect the behavior of any tools. So I'm curious the value of adding this.

I cannot comment on the value/benefit of adding this (copied Joe Ross in the bug who can help here), but we do have that requirement and there should be ways to customize the ResponseInfo construct. Any resource can have as many rdf:type properties as desired. Is it possible to make ResponseInfo customizable in that regard?

One approach to add this functionality would be to introduce a new class-level annotation, say "@OslcContainerTypes", which would take as value one or more types to be added to the enclosing container resource when a collection/array is returned. We will prototype such solution and submit for review.

Francisco, if we go this way, we'll probably want to fully support query shapes. That means being able to also change rdfs:member and provide a corresponding shape to the query capability. See
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OSLCCoreSpecRDFXMLExamples?sortcol=table;up=#Specifying_the_shape_of_a_query

Sam, we really need a quick solution now (even if temporary) in order to avoid breaking backwards compatibility. The simplest way of doing this is to have a global switch that controls whether the Container type is added or not.
Would it be OK to contribute a solution along the lines of Comment #6 ?

It is hard for us to still understand what is broken or what adding this gives us. If you can provide that, it would help. Though we'd still need someone to produce a fix, then integrate it. Committers aren't responsible for providing fixes to these bugs but to ensure consistency and apply contributions to the code. So yes, a contributed fix/enhancement will greatly improve the chances of it being fixed.
Could you please assign this bug to csaad@br.ibm.com? As discussed via email, we will submit a solution that uses a system property to decide whether to include the Container type or not. Thanks.
Is it possible for the application to create a Contaneir class and annotate it with OSLC4J?
(In reply to comment #10) Hi Denilson. It is possible, but then we would have to give up on the ResponseInfoCollection support we have from OSLC4J.

Resolved by commit:
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/14891/
It adds new Java system property
org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.queryResultListAsContainer
which can be set to "true" to use rdfs:Container. Thanks, Francisco.
Most of the code was implemented by Paulo. Thanks Sam and Paulo.

bug.short_desc: The OSLC4J release version 2.1.1 has the wrong release ID

long_desc.thetext:
The latest OSLC4J downloads say org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j-2.1.1.zip but the component Version in Bugzilla (above), and the versions of the jar files in the zip file say 3.0.0.
Specifically: the lyo.version in the pom.xml files should be 2.1.1, not 3.0.0-SNAPSHOT for this release.
A release should never be based on a SNAPSHOT Maven install.
Version 3.0.0 should be reserved for updating to OASIS OSLC Core 3.0 if the project team decides this is something that should be done.
I think we should roll 2.1.1 downloads back to 2.1.0 and make 2.2.0 release.

There may be some other problems with 2.1.1. I'm seeing some updates regarding antlr version, and changing references to CommonTree to Tree when merging core HEAD into my workspace, but I'm not sure those changes are in 2.1.1 or not.
Also org.eclipse.lyo.client.java, and its sample apps don't compile or run in 2.1.1.
A simple solution might be to create 2.1.2 just to clean these few things up, then focus on reducing the technical debt in the OSLC4J modules to create 2.2.0.

I think if we really want to fix something in 2.1.0, we should release a bugfix by cherry-picking necessary commits onto a new branch made from 'f9e69dae' commit.
Otherwise I think that 78 commits (`git rev-list f9e69dae..HEAD --count`) made since 2.1.0 is a bit too much for the bugfix 2.1.2 release.
Do you think somebody might not be able to upgrade to 2.2.0 once we release it?

If 2.2.0 contains some minor fixes necessitated by the dependency updates, that might not be too much of a problem. The previous versions are still available if a client finds they can't move forward for some reason.
The immediate concern is the amount of work required to finish up the changes for 2.2.0, get the CQs done, and test everything. The changes we need in 2.1.2 should be able to be done much faster.
Cleaning up "3.0.0" bugs.

bug.short_desc: Define a deployment architecture for Lyo

long_desc.thetext:
Lyo uses a number of tools to build and deploy itself and we have run into issues with version incompatibilities, complex setup, etc.
Defining a formal deployment architecture would document all the needs, motivations, constraints, applications, components, versions, dependencies, and processes that are required to build and use Lyo. Ideally, after defining the architecture we could create a package that automates deployment on a consumer's platform.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4JJenaProvider: add encoding to xml declaration

long_desc.thetext:
The XML declaration produced by OSLC4JJenaProvider does not currently contain an encoding attribute. According to [1], the way to do this when using Model.write() is to set showXmlDeclaration to false and then write the declaration to the outputStream prior to Model.write().
[1] - http://incubator.apache.org/jena/documentation/io/iohowto.html#advanced-rdfxml-output

Sam, gave that a try, but it did not include the encoding attribute in the xml declaration. From the javadoc [1], it doesn't look like providing a Writer necessarily has the expected effect.
[1] - http://incubator.apache.org/jena/documentation/javadoc/jena/com/hp/hpl/jena/rdf/model/RDFWriter.html#write(com.hp.hpl.jena.rdf.model.Model, java.io.Writer, java.lang.String)

(In reply to comment #3)
OK, thanks for trying. I agree with what you have in the patch.

bug.short_desc: Support for Hosted Bugzilla on Landfille

long_desc.thetext:
We can use the hosted Bugzilla on Landfill ( http://demo.bugzilla.org/create.cgi )
However, once its instance is created, it has already more than 6 products, and each product has 500 ~ 5000 bugs ! Since the current TRS implementation tries to get change logs for (the number of product) x (max bugs=1000) at the first time, at worst, it tries to access around 6000 bugs ! which might cause the performance issue.
So if the Bugzilla is hosted at Landfill ( in this case, uri has "demo.bugzilla.org" ),
The max number of Products to be searched : 1 (default is 5) The max number of bugs in a product to be searched : 3 (default is 100)
so that TRS can return the ChangeLogs quickly.
"I wrote all this code, and have the rights to contribute it to Eclipse and contribute it under the EPL and EDL"
Gerrit review - https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/13611/

While changing the code to support the hosted Bugzilla, I found another issue.
Currently, when TRS is called at the first time, it is going to get *all* change logs, which might be huge.
So adding another properties to specify the start check date could solve this.

Adding the special meaning to rebuild_interval.
If rebuild_intervalis -1, TRS Provider won't rebuild Base and its ChangeLogs so that TRS Provider will always get the updated Bugs only.
I did --amend, so still Geriit is https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/13611/

Thanks, Matsumoto-san!
Resolved by commit
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.docs.git/commit/?id=d0e610650c24ce0cf6097d5bb0c04307f34bb0ac
I've verified, so closing it

bug.short_desc: License token is never released on DOORS 9.6.1.4

long_desc.thetext:
General:
When 'org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.OslcOAuthClient.getResource' is executed to retrieve a DOORS module information, a "DWA_Review" token is taken and never released. Only rebooting DWA the license is released.
Detail:
Debugging 'DoorsOauthSample.java', I realized the problem is when the requirement is retrieved. When I execute:
ClientResponse getResponse = client.getResource(requirementURL,OslcMediaType.APPLICATION_RDF_XML);
and
OslcQueryResult result = query.submit();
The 'DWA_Review' token is taken and never released.
Using CCM, I add a link in DOORS using a 'DWA_EDIT' token. Once the timeout is achieved, the token is released.
What is the difference between CCM and 'DoorsOauthSample.java' behaviors?
Why CCM takes a 'DWA_EDIT' token and 'DoorsOauthSample.java' a "DWA_Review" token?
When I use 'org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.OslcOAuthClient.getResource' in 'DoorsOauthSample.java': - during authentication process (Steps 1-4) -> no token is taken - finding ServiceProvider (Steps 4-5) -> no token is taken - finding QueryCapability (Step 6) -> no token is taken - finding CreationFactory (Step 7) -> no token is taken - finding RequirementsInstanceShapes -> no token is taken - submitting OSLC query (Steps 8-9) -> "DWA_Review" token is taken and never released - getting requirement (only Steps 12, without Step 10-11) -> "DWA_Review" token is taken and never released
In conclusion, "DWA_Review" token is taken and never released only when an OSLC query is executed for a DOORS module and when it's retrieved a requirement (object) of a DOORS module.
Created attachment 265642 DoorsOauthSample Oauth danse modified

Comment on attachment 265642 DoorsOauthSample Oauth danse modified
I found the problem. The last authentication in 'validateToken' is not needed. In fact, it blocks the license once a GET/PUT is performed for a module object. See the attached code.

(In reply to Carlos Gomez from comment #2) > Comment on attachment 265642 [details] > DoorsOauthSample Oauth danse modified > > I found the problem. The last authentication in 'validateToken' is not > needed. In fact, it blocks the license once a GET/PUT is performed for a > module object. See the attached code.
Thanks Carlos for attaching the code! Jim, could you please check if this problem is still relevant and whether we should commit this fix?
My problem is I don't have access to a DOORS Web Client on a DOORS 9.x to test against.

bug.short_desc: Align folder names with maven artifactId

long_desc.thetext: Most eclipse/Lyo projects in all repositories are maven projects. Generally the groupId is the same as the repository while the artifactId is a somewhat descriptive name of a project in the repository. Unfortunately the folder names representing the project, and therefore the eclipse project names are different. The folder/project names also often resemble package names and this is not a good practice for project names. The "namespace" for a project in a repository and an maven artifact in a group should be aligned. This will avoid confusion when loading maven project in eclipse since the artifactId is displayed in the project explorer, not the folder name.

Now that eclipse .project, .classpath and .settings are no longer being stored in git, these project now need to be loaded as maven, not existing eclipse projects. This will be confusing to users when the folder names visible in the repository don't match imported project names.

I agree, but we should consider avoiding breaking artifactId changes within a major release. According to the http://semver.org/, we would need to release new artefacts under 3.1.0 version (as we agreed that 3.0.0 SNAPSHOT was misused).
Agreed
Wait till the lyo-trs refactoring.
I think lyo-trs has been refactored, we are not waiting for anything here.

Changing eclipse project names to match the artifactId shouldn't have any impact on Java imports since we're not changing any packages.
But it will probably break the build - there's probably lots of references to those project names.
This might be more trouble than its worth.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4j does not validate XMLLiteral fields in ServiceProvider

long_desc.thetext:
I can create ServiceProvider from following payload: <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:oslc="http://open-services.net/ns/core#" xmlns:oslc_data="http://open-services.net/ns/servicemanagement/1.0/"> <oslc:ServiceProvider > <dcterms:title> 1 < 2 </dcterms:title> <oslc:service> <oslc:Service> <oslc:domain rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/monitoring/1.0/"/> </oslc:Service> </oslc:service> </oslc:ServiceProvider> </rdf:RDF>
dcterms:title is XMLLiteral field and "1 < 2" in not valid XMLLiteral.

An XMLLiteral is anything that is valid when embedded between a balanced XML start and end tag.
Your example is valid and passes the W3C validator fine when I add the XMLLiteral type to it.
See http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-concepts/#dfn-rdf-XMLLiteral

I think it is not valid XMLLiteral. please consider that these two statements are quivalent: 1 < 2 and 1 < 2 and the first one is obviously incorrect. In my example I send 1 < 2 which is valid XML with additional information (from resource shape for Service Provider) that title is XMLLiteral. In OSLC Core specification I see: http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OSLCCoreSpecAppendixA?sortcol=table;up=#Dublin_Core_Properties dcterms:title - Title of the resource represented as rich text in XHTML content. SHOULD include only content that is valid inside an XHTML element. In my example value for dcterms:title is "1 < 2" just escaped in XML with 1 < 2. And I cannot have 1 < 2 . I think that the trick here is we send dcterms:title as normal string and only from the definition of property we know that it is XMLLiteral. Quotation is just because of XML, real value is not valid XMLLiteral. And simple experiment with jena: System.out.println(com.hp.hpl.jena.datatypes.xsd.impl.XMLLiteralType.theXMLLiteralType.isValid("1 < 2")); System.out.println(com.hp.hpl.jena.datatypes.xsd.impl.XMLLiteralType.theXMLLiteralType.isValid("1 2")); It returns: false true
Reopening for further investigation
Tried your examples and got false for both in jena 2.6.4

Resolved with the following commits:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=5a1d8418815287175e06873b17977f1595f59cad
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

bug.short_desc: Migrate to a better configuration approach

long_desc.thetext:
Widespread use of system properties (coupled with static classes) leads to implicit behaviour, is hard to override, test, and use in multi-tenant situation (when more than one OSLC server is deployed on a single app server).
A better way is to:
* migrate to configuration objects * pass them in constructors * switch to a config library like
- https://github.com/typesafehub/config - https://github.com/Netflix/archaius/ - https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/
At the very least, we should aim to use web.xml params as much as possible in the libraries that are not intended for standalone usage.

Also we might want to look at something like
- https://google.github.io/dagger/ - https://github.com/vanillasource/jaywire/wiki/Comparison
For a DI framework to prevent pain once we start passing config objects around.

I think system properties are actually better than custom configuration libraries after some discussion with Jim.
We still need to:
* migrate to configuration objects * pass them in constructors (and eliminate most of the static code that only relied on global state) * document all system properties * think about a DI framework

Configuration has to be done somewhere. Application designers need to assess their end users' variability needs and provide some means of setting configuration parameters. Ideally applications should be able to run out of the box, and have a consistent place to address user preferences after the user has run the program for a while and understands what the preferences mean to them and therefore have some reasonable idea on how to set them.
The opposite of this would be the poor practice of distributing configuration information as control couples using multiple techniques: .ini files, .properties file, XML files, environment variables, system properties, installation scripts, etc.
A good practice is to minimize the unnecessary variability, and use a consistent approach to setting configuration properties that have to be set before the app can run, handling all other app configuration by the app in a consistent way (e.g., MacOS use of properties). If we do this for OSLC4J, then maybe a couple of System properties for startup would be fine. They are easy to set on the command line and are therefore easy to script.

bug.short_desc: Add more resource classes to org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.resources

long_desc.thetext:
There are several common OSLC classes missing from the package org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.resources (or whatever replaces it if changes are made to resolve bug 512849 &/or bug 389660).
Client programming would be easier if Lyo supplied classes for: foaf:Person oslc:Comment oslc:Discussion oslc_config:Component oslc:config:Configuration (or Baseline and Stream)

All requested OSCL resource classes look OK, but for FOAF there is
https://jena.apache.org/documentation/javadoc/arq/org/apache/jena/sparql/vocabulary/FOAF.html#Person
I would suggest not to overwrite all kinds of standard classes. I understand that we need to have Resource Shapes etc.
Jad? Jim?

Also there will be no end to these classes. We could restrict them to only the common properties in OSLC Core. It would be better to use facilities like the Toolchain Modeler and Code Generator to handle domain classes and extensions. It is not sustainable to add new domain classes to the client. If we want convenience classes for clients, we should be using more dynamic and adaptive techniques like hash tables.
We can have multiple packages for the OSLC domains, e.g. oslc-domain-cm could contain all the necessary classes. The developer would just need to add another dependency in Maven.

I agree with the general concerns noted in comments 2 and 3 - but note that oslc:Comment and oslc:Discussion are core resources, not specific to any domain.
For comment 1 about foaf:Person, there is unlikely to be too much confusion between the Jena field and an OSLC Class - but we could easily call the class something different such as PersonResource to avoid the name clash.
The config classes are part of a domain - and moreover, one that we have not yet published as an approved specification. So I would be fine with not having those in a common client package.

Concerning foaf:person, I might be still confusing Vocab and shapes, but it seems that Jena is providing the vocabulary. We are after classes that define the OSLC shape for a person?
Concerning Jim's suggestion on using the Modeler/Generator, I am working on an extension that allows for the generation of the the classes only (not necessarily associated with a toolchain nor adaptor). Idea is to share the plugin and instructions, to let anyone build their own set of domain classes as a library. But this does not hinder the need to provide classes for common resources.

The classes in org.eclipse.lyo.client.oslc.resources are convenience classes representing a subset of the OSLC core and RM, QM and CM domain classes. The are used to provide java representations of the RDF classes. At the time these were developed, there were no resource shapes formerly defined for these classes. The members of the java classes should reflect the constraints, but may not due to changes in the specifications.

bug.short_desc: separate generic oslc client and Jazz client into 2 separate eclipse projects

long_desc.thetext:
Currently the org.eclipse.lyo.clients.java project containts client support for both generic OSLC and for the different IBM Rational Jazz tools.
My suggestion is to separate these features into 2 different eclipse projects. The main reason is to avoid some confusion it might create to have them in the same project and also to encurage other vendors with OSLC enabled tool to provide client implementations (much easier when in separate project)
There will of course be a dependecy (inheritance) between the projects.
This also implies a separation of the samples provided.
I think this is a good idea, but with low priority.

The use of Rational tools was likely mostly because it was something to test against. I don't recall any product specific code in the OSLC4J client API, except in the samples.
However, the client is duplicating some OSLC domain classes which should be reused from the domains and not duplicated.

bug.short_desc: OSLC Query does not work correctly when Global Configuration is enabled in DNG

long_desc.thetext:
Using DNG Query capability we are not able to retrieve Requirements.
I think the problem is the query capability url.
When GC is enabled the query capability url is:
https://<host>:<port>/rm/views?oslc.query=true&projectURL=<project_area_url>&vvc.configuration=<stream_url> so there is the parameter vvc.configuration
this url is not contained in the RDF Triples. For example the Predicate is http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#member, the Subject is https://<host>:<port>/rm/views?oslc.query=true&projectURL=<project_area_url>, without vvc.configuration parameter.
In class OslcQueryResult, the method initializeRdf() set membersResource = rdfModel.getResource(query.getCapabilityUrl()); but in the model there isn't memeber resource with "query.getCapabilityUrl()" subject.
so rdfModel.listStatements(select) is empty in method getMembersUrls()
Removing vvc.configuration from capability url, all works correctly.

Hi Massimo,
Sorry for a delay in my reply. Have you already resolved the issue? As far as I recall from some SO questions, it is Doors' limitation as vvc.configuration query parameter is not supposed to be used with OSLC query.
Anyway, Jim (CC) knows much better about this.
/Andrew
I am setting a 'minor' priority as it's not an issue from the Lyo SDK side, but from the IBM Doors' side.

bug.short_desc: Move lyo project mirrors on Github under OSLC organisation

long_desc.thetext:
In bug 513090 I was asking for access to Lyo repositories under Eclipse org on Github. This is deprecated and we should be mirroring repos on our own in the future.
As I understand, Github only allows such automated mirroring for select OSS projects but I am sure we can implement the same behaviour with Eclipse Hudson (and possibly our own server to do push/pull on any new commit to our repositories).
Will be especially helpful if we want to move some of the projects (samples etc.) later outside Eclipse process.
P.S. I found that there is a "lighter" IP process in Eclipse where we bear most of the responsibility for verifying that only properly licensed code goes in. Found this out when filing for a new release.
See Bug 518773.

bug.short_desc: Update OSLC4J samples to let them run in same app server as OSLC4JRegistry

long_desc.thetext:
Currently the OSLC4J samples are unable to run in the same app server as OSLC4JRegistry. This is due to the way they register them selves in the servlet init handler. Since there is no guarantee which app inits first, the sample app registration can timeout since it is blocking OSLC4JRegistry from initializing.
Fix is to change the registration logic so that it is scheduled to be performed outside of the init handler.
De-registration needs to be addressed to. Proposal is to not try to de-register when running in same hostname/port as the registry, since the registry is going away as well on app server termination.
Resolved by https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=f1d4cb36a3b23db4c9e6c694eb43ff35d0deca60

bug.short_desc: Add JUnit tests for abbreviated XML writer

Need unit tests for RdfXmlAbbreviatedWriter covering
- basic OSLC resources - anonymous and non-anonymous nodes - multiple root nodes - cycles (direct and indirect) including the root and not including the root - reification

bug.short_desc: OSLC Core: resource paging, provider must respond with 302 status code and redirect URL for large resource

long_desc.thetext:
If the OSLC provider has resources that it considers to be too large to return in one response, and uses resource paging to return the resource split between multiple resource pages even if the client has not requested paging, then the OSLC provider must comply with the following requirements:
OSLC provider must respond with a HTTP Found (302) status code, and a redirect URL that contains a partial representation of the resource. The redirect URL provided by the OSLC provider must include the oslc.paging key/value pair.

bug.short_desc: Make use of OSLC4JRegistry optional for OSLC4J sample apps

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, the OSLC4J samples rely on OSLC4JRegistry as the catalog for the service providers. This adds complexity to the OOTB experience but is a nice additional feature.
Need to make the use of the registry optional as many implementers of OSLC4J providers will not want a separate registry for the catalog.
The architectural design of OSLC4JRegistry is unclear to me, will try to figure it out while working on this bug.

The OSLC4JRegistryApplication is a sample OSLC server application that provides a reference implementation of the OSLC Discovery capability, primary the ServiceProviderCatalog, ServiceProvider and Service resources. The samples that use the registry are using it for a reusable implementation of the Discovery capability.
I'm not sure removing this capability from the samples will simplify anything or improve the OOTB experience. A consistent implementation of Discovery might be quite useful and actually improve the OOTB experience if implemented properly.
This can perhaps be closed and more specific issues raised. Use of the registry is already optional for server implementations, and there's likely no reason to remove the registry from existing sample.
Postponed till 2.4.0

I'll check it in as a sample. Also, I opened bug 376906 to adopt it in OSLC4J.

bug.short_desc: Code generator - Support different URL strategies

long_desc.thetext:
As highlighted under https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=423711, the url strategy currently adopted in the code generator (which is based on the Bugzilla sample implementation refernced in teh bug report) is not always desirable. It would be good if different strategies can be adopted, based on the user preferences.
For Service Providers ----------------- 2 parameters are defined for the ServiceProvider EClass of the adaptor model to support different URL strategies: * classURISegment - specifies the relative path for the ServiceProviderService JAX-RS Resource class. A typical example is "projects." The default is "serviceProviders".
* instanceURISegment - specifies the relative path for the method/requests(s) for a single service provider (such as getServiceProvider). A typical example can be "{projectId}" or "{collectionName}/{projectName}". The default is "{serviceProviderId}".
Resource -------- 2 parameters are defined for the Resource EClass of the adaptor model to support different URL strategies: * classURISegment = specifies the relative path for the OSLCResource JAX-RS Resource class. User can choose between * relativeToManagingServiceProviderURI - leading to relative URI of the form SP-->classURISegment + SP-->instanceURISegment + "/" + resourceName + "s". * independantOfServiceProviderURI - leading to relative URI of the form resourceName + "s"
* instanceURISegment - specifies the relative path for the method/requests(s) for a single resource (such as getBugzillaChangeRequest). A typical example can be "{collectionName}/{changeRequestId}". The default is "{" + resourceName.toFirstLower() + "Id}".
Please assign this bug to me /Jad

https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/28191/

bug.short_desc: Introduce constant for OSLC core-version header

You are right; The Apache Wink library is only using Strings to represent the header and the header value. My bad.
Perhaps more an improvment sugggestion for the Wink project.
But a more stringent handling of the constants usage is prefered, e.g. replace all occurences of "OSLC-Core-Version" with a constant.
Agree with comment 2. Thanks.
OSLC 3 discourages the use of versioning headers as the future specs shall be backwards-compatible and clients shall instead discover available capabilities.
Let me contradict myself here! https://issues.oasis-open.org/browse/OSLCCORE-188

bug.short_desc: Provide a way to add new namespaces prefixes at runtime

long_desc.thetext:
The only way to map namespaces prefixes to URLs in OSLC4J is by annotating java classes, thus after compiled the java code it is not possible to add or remove namespaces prefixes, since the .class definitions can not be changed at runtime.
This enhancement will let new prefixes be added or removed at runtime, these prefixes will be kept in memory and take precedence over the annotated ones, in case of prefixe's name conflicts.
There is a different behavior when writing an annotated entity, with this enahcement OSLC4J will check the custom map first, instead of the default read annotations, and if the prefix was not found inside this custom map, it will try to get it from the default map and proceed normally.
Please could this enhancement be assigned to me? I'm already working on it.

https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/16416/
I integrated the change, but Daniel, I'm hoping you can submit another change set with some JUnit tests. Have a look at these for some examples:
/org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core/src/test/java /org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena/src/test/java
Thanks!

I've added some JUnit tests. If you have any suggestions, I'm here.
Thanks

bug.short_desc: Improve experience for running OSLC4J samples

long_desc.thetext:
Currently the OOTB experience for running the OSLC4J samples is somewhat cumbersome. See http://wiki.eclipse.org/Lyo/LyoOSLC4J. It involves setting up Tomcat runtimes, running the sample app and the OSLC4JRegistry app on separate Tomcat instances (on separate ports).
Proposed improvements to this experience:
Bug 384395 - Do not require Tomcat runtime Bug 379689 - Provide Jetty launches and jetty configs in pom.xml Bug 376588 - Update Jetty version dependency Bug 384469 - Allow sample apps to run in same app server as OSLC4JRegistry Bug 384470 - Make use of OSLC4JRegistry optional for sample apps

I think we need to consider a couple of goals: - Consistent project naming, they lack the org.eclipse.lyo.* prefix - Folding *Test projects into a src/test folder within the base project and not require another separate project - Providing domain resource definitions in the base project or some consistent place so it can easily be reused, like CM:ChangeRequest, QM:TestCase, etc

(In reply to comment #1)
Steve's last point should be addressed by Bug 409728.

(In reply to comment #1)
Consistent project naming is complete (Bugs 412988).
We should revisit the evaluation of current state of OOTB experience.

This issue may be out of date. Improving OOTB experience isn't specific enough to be actionable. It should be refactored into separate issues that are still open, possibly including:
- Using Jetty instead of Tomcat
- Folding *Test projects into a src/test folder within the base project and not require another separate project
- Providing domain resource definitions in the base project or some consistent place so it can easily be reused, like CM:ChangeRequest, QM:TestCase, etc.
Some of these may be done too, but possibly not in all projects. It may not be necessary to do these improvements in all the projects either.
Should be considered for 2.2.0.
All of the issues are fixed except the last one. It is reported under Bug 384470. Jim's suggestion regarding the test projects has been reported under Bug 518149.

bug.short_desc: Investigate replacing explicit reference of maven repository location in test suite reports with environment variable

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, the compliance reports need to be configured with the location of the Maven repository to satisfy prereqs. Need to investigate an alternate approach. Possibilities:
1) Determine if the m2eclipse plugin has an environment var where this is already stored.
2) Determine if there is an OS env var when Maven is installed indicating repository location
3) Investigate alternative packaging of prereqs or require users to download them
Others?

I think I had tried ${settings.localRepository} and ${env.M2_HOME} - neither returns a value.
One thing we can do which is little better is to have the compliance ant script to use "${user.home}/.m2" as the default Maven repo location. If will check whether ${user.home}/.m2/repository exists. If it does not exist, then user needs to specify a maven_top in the compliance.props file. And if the maven_top parameter is defined in the compliance.props, it is used (overrides the default ${user.home}/.m2 location.

I suggest we look at Maven Ant Tasks.
http://maven.apache.org/ant-tasks/
I believe it can set up your classpath from a POM for you.
