bug.short_desc: Update the url strategy for the example

long_desc.thetext: Ref note in Lyo forum, see http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/628209/

I wonder if we should not use this bug report to handle a more general improvement of doing the URL structure that we'd really do in a production version of it.
Example: http://<host>/<app name>/<resource type>/<resource id>
http://<host>/oslc4bugz/products/{id} http://<host>/oslc4bugz/bugs/{id} http://<host>/oslc4bugz (serviceProviderCatalog)
I wonder if any of the path segments would have any of the OSLC terms like (service provider, change request, etc).
This is just me putting out suggestions and discussing. Be interested to hear if others have better suggestions.

(In reply to Steve Speicher from comment #2)
I prefer these URLs since they're more readable and mirror what I'd want to use in a real Bugzilla implementation.
The services/ segment is difficult to get rid of since it's there for JAX-RS. You define a pattern in web.xml to tell Wink what URLs to handle and what ones to leave alone. If we leave services/ out, Wink will try to process requests for static resources likes images.

(In reply to Samuel Padgett from comment #3) > The services/ segment is difficult to get rid of since it's there for > JAX-RS. You define a pattern in web.xml to tell Wink what URLs to handle and > what ones to leave alone. If we leave services/ out, Wink will try to > process requests for static resources likes images.
Yes frameworks are helpful but may present some unwanted fluff in our URL space. This is important to explain as well, as we are using JAX-RS with this. Can you elaborate on the "full" URL design you might suggest based on that?
So a proposal such as something like: http://<host>/oslc4bugz/service/<jax-rs managed resources> http://<host>/oslc4bugz/<non jax-rs resources>
Make sense or other suggestions?

In reply to Steve Speicher from comment #4)
> So a proposal such as something like: > http://<host>/oslc4bugz/service/<jax-rs managed resources> > http://<host>/oslc4bugz/<non jax-rs resources> > > Make sense or other suggestions?
IMO sounds like a good suggestion.
The other question: should OSLC terms be in url? Not strong opinion, but one idea could be making the general adapter/example help to show there is a decision to be made, advice and give a single point of change - i.e. have static fields e.g. in the Application class like SERVICE_PROVIDER_PATH_SEGMENT = "products" and CHANGE_REQUEST_PATH_SEGMENT = "bugs" and use in code.

Is there an update on how to best handle the URL strategies discussed here?
I would like to make the code generator support different strategies (See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=433168) and it would be nice to get suggestions on the best practices.

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #6) > Is there an update on how to best handle the URL strategies discussed here?
To summarize, I believe we have this as the suggestion for Bugzilla:
http://<host>/oslc4bugz/service/products/{id} http://<host>/oslc4bugz/service/bugs/{id} http://<host>/oslc4bugz/service (serviceProviderCatalog, do we need a separate special place to serve up this near static file? don't think so)
http://<host>/oslc4bugz/ (static web content, non-JAX-RS)
This sound right? Assigning to Sam to determine next steps.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J: Preserve rdf:type information in AbstractResource

long_desc.thetext:
Currently OSLC4J does not save actual rdf:type information. Even if you know the Java class, this is not always sufficient. RDF resources can have multiple types, and some type information is lost.
When reading resources in, OSLC4J already has the rdf:type. It just discards it. We can easily save this infromation in the AbstractResource.

bug.short_desc: Improve JAX-RS Producer Infrastructure to Allow Better Serialization Control

long_desc.thetext: Collections of resources are generally wrapped in oslc:ResponseInfo elements, when serialized. Want a more transparent way to control the serialization of collections and filtering response properties as specified by oslc.select or oslc.properties.
I think at KTH we shifted focus from OSLC Query almost completely to SPARQL, so I tent to close this as a wontfix. Jim, Jad?

There are many OSLC servers and adapters that are on data sources that don't support SPARQL. So OSLC Query may still be the only option in some cases. OSLC selected properties are also independent of OSLC query and can be specified on any single resource to return a subset of its properties (a projection).
But this bug seems related to the Wink technical debt issue.
The original issue does not describe the problem well enough for me to know how important this is.

bug.short_desc: Contribute a set of PERL modules for OSLC Scripting

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
This is to contribute a set of PERL modules for OSLC scripting and sample clients to Eclipse Lyo project
Reproducible: Always
This has been some related work announced on the OSLC-CM mailing list http://open-services.net/pipermail/oslc-cm_open-services.net/2012-May/000374.html
See also http://arroway.github.com/Net-OSLC-CM/

Thanks Steve for the pointer.
I can't formally speak for the original author of http://arroway.github.com/Net-OSLC-CM/, but being her adviser on that work which was conducted as a study project, I can probably comment.
I think she is willing to contribute that code, as-is, to Eclipse Lyo.
The code is far from offering complete OSLC-CM consumer coverage, but if there's enough interest, it should probably serve as a good starting point for improvements.
At the moment, the code is under the Perl license, but this could probably be changed if needed, to be contributed to Eclipse.
So, any more hints on how to practically contribute it would be helpful, if you're interested (Yes, I'm a member of Eclipse Lyo too, and interested in principle, but I guess I'm biased here).
Again, the author is Stephanie Ouillon, so it will be her decision in the end, and some formal copyright/IP process will have to be made by her.

Resolved (finally) by the following commit:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.client.git/commit/?id=08804e250cb976ddcc103536126a593397b71f71
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

bug.short_desc: OSLC Core: responses containing OSLC resources must include the OSLC-Core-Version header

long_desc.thetext:
OSLC Core
All OSLC provider responses containing OSLC resources must include the OSLC-Core-Version header with the value set to the OSLC Core specification version with which the representation complies.

Can we add this to
org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.server.util.OSLCUtils.getResponseFromUrl(String, String, Credentials, String, Header[])
as an optional behavior with a flag to control the check? Would it work as a static property for an entire test class?
We have existing method to check the header, but it's not used anywhere that I see.
org.eclipse.lyo.testsuite.server.util.OSLCUtils.checkOslcVersion(String, Credentials, String)
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecification?sortcol=table;up=#Supporting_pre_Core_clients

Bulk update: The future focus of Lyo test suites will for OSLC 3.0, likely using the same framework as the LDP test suite. We'll evaluate 2.0 test suite improvements based on usage and need.
If you feel like this bug should not have been closed, feel free to reopen and update its status.
Closed due to inactivity.

bug.short_desc: Ensure QM preview supports JSTL

long_desc.thetext: For security reasons, it would be good to make sure that the previews for QM resources support the use of JSTL.

To clarify on the security reasons: using JSTL <c:out> avoids cross-site scripting problems. It also looks like there might have been other problems in the preview before this change, but everything works great now. Thanks, Tori!

bug.short_desc: Visual Basic.NET - Requirements Management 1.0 Consumer

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 211658 Source code for the VB.NET RIO
This is a simple reference implementation of a Requirements Management 1.0 Consumer.
This implementation is tooled towards using Rational DOORS as the OSLC Provider, however anything specific to DOORS has been segregated into a separate module.
The reference implementation currently takes a Requirement Collection URI, and GETs the requirement collection. It will then iterate through the list of requirements linked within the collection and GET each one, and export each requirement as a row in a CSV document, along with exporting the raw RDF/XML of each requirement and the requirement collection to the output folder.
Note, this RIO depends on one external open source project - OAuthDotNet, which can be found at http://lab.madgex.com/oauth-net/ & at http://code.google.com/p/oauth-dot-net/ When coding this, I placed the OAuth.Net.Common.dll and the OAuth.Net.Components.dll files into the lib folder within the project. Solution made in Visual Studio 2010.
This work is all my own and I have the right / permission to contribute this to the Eclipse Lyo project.
Requested advice from the PMC on the auto-generated source that comes from Visual Studio. Will possibly have to exclude it from the contribution.
We will host this at Codeplex along with other .NET samples. Resolving this as WONTFIX since we will not host this on Eclipse.
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J core changes to support dynamic schemas

long_desc.thetext:
This is related to Bug 392780. That bug will not be implemented at this time as we need to figure out how to make the JenaProvider (JenaModelHelper, et al) more extensible to reduce duplicate code.
However, there are a few core OSLC4J and OSLC4JWink changes which can be done to support the current dynamic schema code without causing external changes for other consumers. These changes will be made using this bug.
Changes include:
- change ResourceShape property implementation from a SortedSet to a TreeMap using the required (by OSLC) propertyDefinition URI as the key. - add a method to retrieve a property using its propertyDefinition key.
- add a new constructor to OslcWinkApplication to allow instantiation with a set of dynamic resource classes and a dynamic resource shape

Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=0c373b0de9cf29381e011393ae3e24f4baea2569
Bulk update: Closing out Lyo bugs fixed long ago. Feel free to reopen if you feel your bug was closed in error.

bug.short_desc: Code Generator: Support for anchors and/or reified resources

long_desc.thetext:
Has anyone tried to implement anchors with OSLC4J?
We are looking for ways to implement a link that also includes properties, which leads to the recommendation of using Anchors (which I assume are a realisation of RDF Reification in OSLC). (https://tools.oasis-open.org/version-control/browse/wsvn/oslc-core/trunk/supporting-docs/link-guidance.html)
Any hints or code samples would be appreciated.

Support the modelling of resource properties that also includes properties. This should result in the generation of POJO classes that are simliar to OSLC4J Links class. That is, a specialisation of the AbstractReifiedResource abstract class.
Refer to recommendation of using Anchors in OSLC (https://tools.oasis-open.org/version-control/browse/wsvn/oslc-core/trunk/supporting-docs/link-guidance.html)

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #0) > Has anyone tried to implement anchors with OSLC4J? > > We are looking for ways to implement a link that also includes properties, > which leads to the recommendation of using Anchors (which I assume are a > realisation of RDF Reification in OSLC). > (https://tools.oasis-open.org/version-control/browse/wsvn/oslc-core/trunk/ > supporting-docs/link-guidance.html) > > Any hints or code samples would be appreciated.
I hit "save" prematurely. Ignore this description, and refer to comment1 below instead.

(In reply to Jad El-khoury from comment #0) > Has anyone tried to implement anchors with OSLC4J? > > We are looking for ways to implement a link that also includes properties, > which leads to the recommendation of using Anchors (which I assume are a > realisation of RDF Reification in OSLC). > (https://tools.oasis-open.org/version-control/browse/wsvn/oslc-core/trunk/ > supporting-docs/link-guidance.html) > > Any hints or code samples would be appreciated.

bug.short_desc: Rename OSLC4J projects to follow Eclipse and Lyo conventions

long_desc.thetext:
Proposed names:
* org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core * org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena * org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.json4j * org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.wink * ...
This means the projects to be removed and re-imported from your Eclipse workspace. We'll also need to update our wiki and Hudson builds.
Note that the packages name won't change, and the artifact IDs and group IDs in the POMs won't change. This means there's no impact unless you build the libraries from source.

Resolved by commits:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=8075d6e67109f56096a8af7f100573a4e02b0757
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.rio.git/commit/?id=3dffdec5737b7cffa03a467ae9788aae48be2785
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.docs.git/commit/?id=b2dd24b24932e1923d7e2464114f6b4ee4c023b9
You will need to remove the OSLC4J projects from your workspace before your next git pull, then re-import.
Here are the steps you need to take if you have the OSLC4J projects loaded. This impacts the lyo.core, lyo.rio, and lyo.docs repositories.
1) Back up any work you have made! Git stash is good, but you might also manually copy the projects somewhere else just in case. 2) Remove the projects from your Eclipse workspace. Right-click on the projects and select delete. DON'T delete the project contents from disk :) Leave that checkbox unchecked. 3) Do a git pull. 4) Re-import the projects from the Git repository view.

bug.short_desc: OSLC4J should support globalization/translation of resource shapes

long_desc.thetext:
1. OslcResourceShapeResource class in the OSLC4JWink project needs to extract the Accept-Language header from the request and pass it on to ResourceShapeFactor.createResourceShape()
2. ResourceShapeFactory needs to try treating the values of the OSLC annotations as message bundle keys and retrieve the value based on locale and use the actual string value of the annotation as the default.
I haven't fully tested using message bundle keys as annotation values, but a quick search indicates it is feasible.

bug.short_desc: OAuth Webapp Framework: Don't prompt for ID and password again if user already has session

long_desc.thetext:
We always prompt for an ID and password in the OAuth authorization dialog, even if the user already has a valid session. This can be annoying and isn't really necessary. Instead, we can show an approve / deny dialog without forcing users to type their password again.
Anyone using the OAuth framework can disable this behavior by always returning false in the Application.isAuthenticated() method.

bug.short_desc: Support RDF reification in OSLC4J

long_desc.thetext:
Link labels in OSLC are handled using Reification. See
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/OslcCoreSpecAppendixLinks
Also some specifications use reification to add additional metadata about links, such as the Asset resource in the Asset Management 2.0 specification.
http://open-services.net/bin/view/Main/AssetMgSpecificationV2?sortcol=table;up=#Asset
The OSLC4J SDK currently only supports links as URIs, however. This enhancement is to add reification OSLC4J for these use cases.

Resolved by commit b30695fda6a05bd13e2aa4437947d700904dd00f
http://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=b30695fda6a05bd13e2aa4437947d700904dd00f

bug.short_desc: OSL4J-jena-provider should be made configurable to not become provider for media types other than application/rdf+xml

long_desc.thetext:
We are doing as follows :
Without OSLC
1) Create a JPA entity for the Underlying table . Add JAXB annotation to it (basically the root element and access Type) 2) Create a Wink Asset class which wraps the jpa entity and this User Asset is returned by the GET . Wink looks up at the requested Media Type and invokes the required providers(json provider here) to translate the same entity to either xml or json . So we are able to get either xml or json by changing the media type .
With OSLC
After step 1 above , we add OSLC annotation to the same JPA entity and register the jena provider in the application class . This is what we see :
a) For application/rdf+xml : RDF representation of JPA along with the OSLC tags - which is correct b) For application/xml : Same as above c) For application/json : Json format of RDF representation .
Seems like this is a bug in the OSLC4J-jena provider implementation where its becoming proivider for application/xml as well which is fed to json provider for application/json media type too and hence leading into translation of OSLC annotated RDF tags for application/xml and application/json media types.
The need of our application is to support OSLC for application/rdf+xml and return POJO's xml and json representation for application/xml and application/json media types.
Also jena provider required to be explicitly registered in Application class where are all the wink providers get automatically registered upon dropping in the lib folder . Is there any specific reason for this ?
1.2 candidate

Resolved by:
https://git.eclipse.org/c/lyo/org.eclipse.lyo.core.git/commit/?id=90353cc431eb5d628636310340c30b15ee66802b

If a LDP server creates this associated LDP-RS it must indicate its location on the HTTP response using the HTTP Link response header with link relation describedby and href to be the URI of the associated LDP-RS resource [RFC5988].

bug.short_desc: Add system property to ignore invalid datatype formats in extended properties

long_desc.thetext:
Some providers will specify a datatype, but then provide an empty value or another value that is invalid for the datatype. For instance, RTC sometimes provides an empty value for fields with datatype long, which causes errors when read in using Jena:
com.hp.hpl.jena.datatypes.DatatypeFormatException: Lexical form '' is not a legal instance of Datatype[http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#long -> class java.lang.Long] Lexical form '' is not a legal instance of Datatype[http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#long -> class java.lang.Long] during parse -org.apache.xerces.impl.dv.InvalidDatatypeValueException: cvc-datatype-valid.1.2.1: '' is not a valid value for 'integer'. at com.hp.hpl.jena.graph.impl.LiteralLabelImpl.getValue(LiteralLabelImpl.java:326) at com.hp.hpl.jena.graph.Node_Literal.getLiteralValue(Node_Literal.java:40) at com.hp.hpl.jena.rdf.model.impl.LiteralImpl.getValue(LiteralImpl.java:101) at org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.provider.jena.JenaModelHelper.handleExtendedPropertyValue(JenaModelHelper.java:1078)
Provide a system property (off by default) to log these problems are warnings.

bug.short_desc: More flexible way to define @OslcDialogs and specify usage

long_desc.thetext: Today OSLC4J forces you to put the @OslcDialog for selection on a GET method and the @OslcDialog for creation on a PUT method. Since query capabilities and creation factories are optional, there should be an alternative way to define the dialogs for the service provider. Optional additional attributes for the notation could be used to identify them without relying on the JAX-RS notations for GET and POST methods.

Proposing to add a new OslcDialog parameter called dialogType which can have one of two values (right now) from an OslcDialogTypes enum -> selection or creation.
If @OslcDialogs/@OslcDialog are not tied to a particular GET or POST method, where should they be allowed? First thought is to put them on the constructor for the JAX-RS service class. The other possibility would be the class itself.
Martin, any preference? alternate ideas on how to do this?

If you're using MVC and the requests for the dialogs go through the JAX-RS service class, then I believe it would make most sense for the @OslcDialog annotations to go on the methods that respond to those requests.
However, if the dialogs are plain JSPs, generic dialogs or on another controller/service class, then to me it would make most sense for them to be on the class itself.

OK, I think the logic in ServiceProviderFactory should be
1. Look for the dialogs on the class first - OslcDialog must have a dialogType if it is on the class, else it is an error.
2. Check all class methods for dialogs - if the OslcDialog has a dialogType attribute, use it - if it does not, look for @GET (selection) or @POST (creation). If it is not an @GET or @POST, it is an error.

(In reply to comment #3)
That suggestion sounds good to me
